Mining and farming colonies are the lifeblood of governments and corporations alike. Both success stories and severe failures have led to some worlds thriving while others simply die on the vine of the trade routes that branch from the Outer Rim to far off sectors to the unknown.

While the Outer Rim Territories has been claimed, there are many dark corners of it that have yet to be explored.  Sometimes something comes out of those shadows to fuck up your home.

SECTOR 949

GJ1105 SYSTEM

 

Located on the edge of known space and settled by famous industrialist and xenobotanist Henry De Pype, the colony on Rim was destroyed under mysterious circumstances in 2179.  A Colonial Marine contingent responding to a distress call found the colony of Pype's Dream to be suffering from a redacted outbreak.  The platoon came under attack by unknown forces and suffered near total losses.  To contain the epidemic, the atmospheric processor's reactor was purposely set to overload.  Only two survivors escaped Rim—USCMC Corporal David Wilks and a young colonist named Billie. Both were cleared of contagion some months later, sworn to never speak of the incident, and released.

While the planet's atmosphere was damaged by the reactor's explosion, the ECA has recently cleared the planet for recolonization.

 

The 340-kilometer area of the former colony is a radiation dead zone, so caution is recommended.  Nearing completion, the new colony is to be called Pype's Line for the many pumps and conduits used to siphon the crude oil deposits from deep under the irradiated zone safely to the colony kilometers away.

OMNI CETI SYSTEM

 

When several mineral assets were discovered in the Omni Ceti system, the fourth planet was colonized by the Omni-tech corporation in 2085.  A domed colony was set on the surface of Mira Ceti IV and terraforming efforts began using traditional techniques.  After 15 years of terraforming and mining, the colony sent out a distress signal.  With their cargo fleet spread thin and no Colonial Coast Guard in place yet, it took the nearest Omni-tech ship four and a half years to respond.

Of the 532 colonists assigned there, only 104 severely mutilated bodies were found.  Investigators concluded the colony succumbed to a mass hysteria that resulted in deaths and rioting.  Panicked survivors must have fled into the cata­combs and wastelands and died of exposure there.  Conspiracy theorists claim the colony was attacked by technologically advanced alien lifeforms, who killed those who resisted and took the others back to their home world as slaves.  

 

The recently leaked journals of a colonist named Lumley suggest that a demonic entity was summoned and dragged the missing colonists back to hell with it.  While pure nonsense, the journals have revived interest in the Tulitu esoteric brotherhood that Lumley belonged to.

GL268 SYSTEM

 
 

Sitting just outside 3WE space, GL268 is a yellow star with no planetary system.  There are no natural celestial bodies in the star's orbit—just a human-made deep-space transit space station.  Called Station 949, this large service terminal is considered the hub to the Rimward colonies.  Equipped with two drydocks for repairing M-Class freighters, the station also sports four ecological gardens on arms that extend from the station's central stem.

268G.CET SYSTEM

 
WHAT IS THE COMPANY UP TO?

LV-426, Rim, and countless other small moon-colonies—why does Weyland-Yutani pour so much funding into terraforming these barren lumps of rock? What purpose could they serve? The mineral content of these worlds seems hardly worth the bother—colonial wildcatters stationed there barely eke out a nominal living.  On the diminutive side, these colonies rarely exceed sixty to eighty families.  These worlds may hold some strategic value to the company—although what that value is is lost on the colonists forced to forge a living on these frontier wastelands.  Whatever it is, you can be sure it isn't for the benefit of the settlers themselves.  

 

This mineral-rich system, dominated by the planet Traon, has been leased to the Kelland Mining Company to exploit for Omni-Tech.  Large automated mining facilities cover Traon, extending deep beneath the surface.  The machines are powered by geothermal taps.  A contingent of 300 miners and wildcatters maintains the digs and scouts for new mining sites.

The Frontier is where explorers are pushing the boundaries of human knowledge and colonists are expanding civilized space.  Unfortunately, the frontier is also under attack by threats both human and alien.

WEYLAND ISLES SECTOR

A small hold out from the Weyland Era of expansion, the Weyland Isles lie just beyond the Outer Rim Territories.  The sector was established by the 3WE in the late 2080s as a link between Earth and the now long-abandoned far spinward colonies.  Containing a number of favorable stars, the sector drew the attention of the 3WE nobility.  Nonetheless, funding was cut for sector development when Weyland Corp stocks dropped in the 2090s.

Sections of claimed space here are referred to as separate isles and are designated I through V.  When the UPP formed in the early 2100s, the isles became even more isolated.  Only the precious metals found in the area kept the 3WE from abandoning it completely.  For decades, the royal marine contingent assigned to the sector has kept the Weyland Isles from leaving the empire.  That changed when the local government of New Albion declared their world independent, leading what has become known as the 3WExit.  The entire area is now contested by the 3WE, the New Albion rebels, the ICSC, and the UPP.

P PELOPS SYSTEM

 

Pylos is a gas giant situated in a forgotten and secluded part of space.  The United Nations Interstellar Settlement Corps set up space station ATOL Sphacteria orbiting Pylos here to act as a spinward Frontier fuel depot.  A Colonial Marshal's office and a platoon of UNISC troops are stationed on Sphacteria.  Along with its massive fuel pods, this depot has two internal drydocks and outer docking facilities for up to twelve class F to M starships.

The station is neutral, servicing all nations and ships alike.  The station's central tower maintains two extendable fuel grapplers that can capture a ship and pull it in for refueling.  A Lockmart towing shuttle is docked here to assist in starship repairs.

BETA CANUM VENATICORUM SYSTEM

 
 

Located in the Beta Canum Venaticorum (Chara) system, LV-187 is a mineral and oil rich rocky planet.  While the system's sun is a main sequence star, the constant cloud cover makes day here akin to dusk on most worlds.  Its breathable atmosphere is constantly wracked with storms and high force winds.  Severe flooding and wind damage are the norm here.  The surface is covered with mud and runoff from the frequent storms.

The colony itself is two kilometers of interconnected corridors stretching east to west with a central hub in the middle.  The planet was recently the victim of a biological outbreak that may have been caused by the Border Bombers.  Forces of the ICSC, NAPRO, UPP, and 3WE blockaded the system in a stalemate, each waiting for the other to make the first aggressive move.

IOTA PERSEI SYSTEM

 
 

Iota Persei is a main sequence star with a system of three worlds.  Only one is the correct distance from the star to support life—and support life it does.  Iota Persei III is a lush jungle world of amber alien plants similar to the foliage discovered by the USCMC on Fujima 514.  A dismissed survey report suggests massive archaeological ruins with equally massive stone heads jutting from the jungle floor lie hidden in the dense banana-yellow foliage.

SZ URSAE MAJORIS SYSTEM

 

Featuring a flare-type star, Sz Ursae Majoris is a deadly system with a scorched barren super earth called Suzie 2—replete with mineral-rich moons and asteroids.  A flare star is a variable star that can undergo unpredictable dramatic increases in energy output for short intervals.  Analogous to solar flares, these outbursts eject magnetic energy stored in the stars' atmospheres, causing periodic loss of comms and power outages to ships, vehicles, and equipment in the system.

Any colony here would need specially hardened electronics. The system's most eligible moon for colonization is Selene, a deep blue hunk of azurite with a tenuous atmosphere ripe for taming via atmospheric processors.

 

Large veins of copper exist here as well. On the surface, the skies periodically flash as crystalline particles in the upper atmosphere react to the flaring star.

GJ1187 “SHĀNMÉN” SYSTEM

 

[QUARANTINE ALERT]

Targeted by the Border Bombers, the UPP and Jùtóu Combine mining world of Shānmén was a vital source of the rare mineral eitr. The lush planet once supported several colonies along with some minor research outposts. The local fauna included meter-long flying insects and large predatory cats. Megafauna ranged from sauropods to large flying hawk-like creatures—all of which have now been mutated into monstrosities by the black pathogen dispersed in the atmosphere.

While the Border Bomber craft responsible for attacking the colonies here was destroyed by the multi-national marine force called the Jackals, only survivors from two settlements were confirmed to have been recovered. The various governments involved are currently in UNISC sessions to discuss the viability of nuking the planet.

 

The 340-kilometer area of the former colony is a radiation dead zone, so caution is recommended. Nearing completion, the new colony is to be called Pype's Line for the many pumps and conduits used to siphon the crude oil deposits from deep under the irradiated zone safely to the colony kilometers away.

THETA PERSEI SYSTEM

 
 

This binary system consists of a main sequence star (Theta Persei A) and its red dwarf companion (Theta Persei B). While this system has been noted for the possibility of earth-like planets in the star's habitable zones, only one has been cataloged—a dead rock with a red sand desert moon designated LV-139. High temperatures dominate the day with freezing temperatures at night. Blue lightning electric storms are common. Other than the moon, Theta Persei has strangely remained unexplored for nearly a century.

JPG-973 SYSTEM

 

Discovered in 2061 in a cooperative effort between industrialist William Tark and the Weyland Corp, the third planet here is home to numerous colonies of simple xeno-bacteria.  A permanent research facility was established here called Tark-Weyland Station.  The station's microbiological and biochemical engineers have put together a think tank to combat new forms of cancer that do not respond to established treatments.

Recently, Tark-Weyland's Molecular Science Group assigned a think tank to work on developing an antigen that would slow the advance of the black pathogen deployed in the Border Bombers' attacks.

 

Unfortunately, the project's lead scientists—Professor Hugo Cléas and Doctor Hide Tajima—went missing while attempting to obtain samples of the pathogen.  Their current status is unknown.

The POL-6362 system features a world named for Weyland Corp's Jacob-Tellis expedition.

This primordial world was settled in 2071, but its small colonial outpost was abandoned when Weyland Corp stocks fell in the 2090s.  Covered in volcanic ash, its structures still stand on an equatorial island chain.  The planet is home to numerous forms of aquatic xeno-microfauna.  Science teams from Tark-Weyland Station make several expeditions here every year, collecting and cataloging microscopic protozoa and arthropods.

GL537 SYSTEM

 

Supplies to the Weyland Isles Sector and other outer colonies are distributed through the barter station at Delos.  Here, freighters take on frontier-mined ores and other cargoes intended for the core systems.  They also bring supplies from the core to the Frontier.

Under normal circumstances, treaties allow civilian freighters to pass through UPP space to reach Delos.  The Frontier War disrupted those routes for nearly two years.  While trade routes have been re-established, Delos has been over-tasked with getting the colonies much needed food, fuel, and medicines.

 

A strategic asset, Delos is a prime target for an invasion by the New Albion Protectorate.

IOTA PISCIUM SYSTEM

 

This somewhat barren system has a large main sequence variable star orbited by a cold debris disk rich in rare earth metals.  The largest piece of debris is called Ockham's Asteroid—a 12 km wide misshapen rock that sports an ICSC sponsored mining colony.  As the first mining site (A) failed to reach ore, it was the second that was colonized.

Called Mining Site B, the facility has recreation bars, a solarium, and cage accommodation for over 2,000 miners.  A single marshal with a dozen deputies maintains order.

The mine itself is over two kilometers deep, causing a severe change in pressure with any descent.

 

Rumors persist that something unearthed in that deep mine has caused several accidents amongst the miners, but these reports are unconfirmed.

LHS-1140 SYSTEM

 

Located in unclaimed space, LHS-1140 is a red dwarf star system with three rocky planets.  The planet LHS 1140b is a super-Earth in the habitable zone and transits the star every 24.7 days.

Gravity on the planet is 2G.  Anyone on the surface will have trouble moving around and get a -2 modification to all MOBILITY, CLOSE COMBAT, and STAMINA rolls.  After a period of acclimation (D6 days), this modification disappears.

UPSILON ANDROMEDAE SYSTEM

 

Upsilon Andromedae is a binary star system of a main sequence star and a red dwarf.  There are three gas giants—Saffar, Samh and Majriti, and a hidden fourth planet (Dybbuk) lurking within the system's solar ionized radiation belt.

The gas giants are home to three Working Joe-run trawling platforms designated DSMO Joe One, Two, and Three.  These stations process metallic hydrogen and metallic helium from the gas giants' cores.

Once major contributors to humankind's expansion, these worlds were abandoned when the 20-parsec limit was established in the 2110s.  While the colonies were ordered to evacuate, no one made it back after the recall.  The information presented in this section details these settlements at the sector's height, circa 2071.  Even if your PCs never visit these planets, they offer a good example of older, more established colonies.  The current disposition of some of these worlds is covered in The Lost Worlds campaign.  What has happened to the rest is up to you.

THE ISOLATION

At the turn of the century, several star systems between the Middle Heavens and the Far Spinward Colonies went supernova, flooding the region with star remnants, intense gamma radiation, and violent neutrino bursts.  This interstellar haze has permeated the area for decades, making travel there impossible—several ships were lost in the attempt.  As of the 2180s, the interference has begun to dissipate enough to risk an expedition back to the FSC—the UNISC Great Mother Mission.  The question remains, what will they find out there—a thriving interstellar civilization of joint colonies, or isolationist chaos and death?

ARROGANCE OR PROPAGANDA?

The large population numbers of the Weyland era colony worlds are in direct contrast to the smaller numbers on distant frontier worlds of this century.  Weyland Corp colony records tend to boast numbers in the tens to hundreds of thousands and more, while Weyland-Yutani worlds support a more modest hundred to a few thousand colonists.  It is possible that ambition and earthly overpopulation caused so many to leave earth for the stars.  It is also true that more advanced technologies were in play in the beginnings of space colonization than the economy versions in use today.  

For example, a Weyland Corp atmospheric processor could reportedly clean a moon or small planet's atmosphere within a decade.  Weyland-Yutani's models can take some twenty to forty years to do a subpar job.  While we may never know for certain, it is likely that at least some of the population numbers were inflated to make extrasolar colonization seem that much more attractive to a civilization hesitant to leave their own solar system.  After all, if everyone else is leaving the planet, why aren't you?

KOI-610 SYSTEM

 
 

In the latter half of the 21st century, this system housed a major European military base in the Far Spinward Colonies.  When the 3WE was formed in 2088, May Outpost became home to a full Commando of royal marines.  After the Weyland Corporation collapse, many of the marines and colonists returned to the core systems, leaving only a reserve contingent here with their families.

KOI-784 SYSTEM

 

Spearheaded by cosmologist and philanthropist Eldridge Dylan Sanchez, the establishment of the system KOI-784 was a long and arduous task.  A systemic failure of the atmospheric processor plant on Dylan City brought a pause to the initial terraforming effort, which was eventually restarted eight years later in 2062.

While an independent science team determined the trouble to be the result of indigenous subterranean single-cell life forms, the company chose to ignore their recommendation to stop colonization.  The process was finally completed by 2069.  A precious metal mining colony, alternately called Dylan City, Dylan Colony, or just Dylan, this world was a thriving center for the Far Spinward Colonies.

KOI-1430 SYSTEM

 

Ute Colony in the KOI-1430 system was the first to introduce Kelland Mining Company's advanced extrasolar mining technologies and techniques to their mining operations.  Within a month of installation, they had increased their production by 130%.  Ute also processed hydrogen cells from the planet's black seas, making the colony essential to the sector's energy needs.

KOI-2770 SYSTEM

 
 

Several millions of years ago, KOI-2770.01 collided with an asteroid enriched with large quantities of palladium.  The impact created massive deposits of the mineral which were targeted for exploitation by Weyland Corp.

Instead of simple mining, Izvinite Outpost also had the facilities to refine the precious metal.  Massive sub-surface electrolysis turbine plants are used to break down water molecules into its hydrogen and oxygen components for separate export to other worlds.

KOI-1938 SYSTEM

 

Named after famous cosmologist and philanthropist Eldridge D. Sanchez, Sanchez Outpost's industry featured arrays of automated deep mining machines.  While it started as a small outpost, within a few years it had become a sprawling colony powered by a substantial dam system.  In addition to the Outpost, this system is known for the massive gas giants Ojo and Atomos and the many moons that surround them.

In 2105, the last message transmitted from the outpost was from Sanchez himself, proclaiming an in-system discovery that in his own words would, “change human life as we know it.” What that was remains a mystery to this day.

Affiliation Weyland Corp, 3WE

The following planets are also located in the FSC sector, although a solar flare accident at a Weyland Corp data center wiped out most records on these colonies.  Here's all we know:

KOI-1361.01 BLUE JAY COLONY: This hot and arid world colony has more than half its water supply imported from nearby worlds.  The colony's endless deserts support massive deposits of thulium, europium, neodymium and copper.

KOI-817.01 BRAHMS OUTPOST: One of the coldest terraformed planets as of 2071, with night-time temperatures down to below −67°C.  Built on the precipice of an active volcano, the outpost soon spread to sweep down the entire side of the volcano.  Key resources include cerium, lithium, aluminum and methane.

KOI-2418.01 CURZIC OUTPOST: This outpost grew into a major manufacturer of commercial fuel cells.  The colony was also known for mining and refining lithium and helium-3.

KOI-1686.01 NIGHTINGALE COLONY: Assigned to the second Jacob-Tellis expedition, Theodore Nightingale was a geologist who was killed in an abseiling accident while exploring the super canyons of the first planet in the system.  When the mining colony was founded, it was named after him.  Resources include helium-3, wolframite, and gadolinium.

KOI-323.08 PLATTE OUTPOST: A world of steam vents and hot springs, this scientific outpost is home to aerobic microfauna of small plant-like organisms.  Nearly fifty researchers called this smallish world home.

The company's species guide is well known on the Frontier—although most of the creatures recorded here aren't included in the public catalog.  Abominations are mutated versions of other extrasolar fauna, so they have no official specification.  Weyland-Yutani's XX designation is applied to redacted creatures that the company considers both deadly and exploitable.  Creatures perfect for their bio weapons division.  Creatures like the xenomorphic and protomorphic species.

ABOMINATIONS

Somewhat different from the Anathemas who are the victims of the Border Bombers, Abominations are humans, animals, and sometimes even androids who have been genetically accelerated by different variants of the Chemical A0-3959X.91-15.  Composed of countless micro-fauna, this dangerously virulent mutagenic pathogen was cultivated by the mysterious and ancient Engineers to create life and destroy it.  Abominations are the unfortunate victims left in the black pathogen's wake.

XENOCOBRA “HAMMERPEDE”

The Xenocobra or Hammerpede is a mutation that occurs when worms are infected by the black pathogen.  Pale with translucent gray-white skin, the Hammerpede's coloration can be likened to that of the Neomorph.  The Prometheus mission recorded specimens with a length of 1.2 meters, but some scientists claim the creature's biology suggests they can reach lengths of up to 10 meters.  The smooth serpent-bodied creature has a head that resembles a knob or clenched fist—until, of course, it is threatened.  The Hammerpede then unfolds its hood to expose its mouth.

CONTAINMENT AND TERMINATION PROTOCOL: These creatures have acid for blood and can regenerate their severed parts the Round after they are lost.  They also like to force themselves down your throat, suffocate you and rearrange your internal organs to create a personal corpse-den for themselves.  Cute little bastards.  The best way to kill them, as always, is with fire.

HUMANOID ABOMINATION, SPINWARD VARIANT

A monstrous mutation of both humans and androids brought about by exposure to certain strains of the black pathogen, Humanoid Abominations go through several stages of gestation.  While many become disintegrating monsters, some survive these transformations, eventually becoming Perfected (Fulfremmen “The Perfected”).  For alternative variations of the sickness, see the cinematic scenarios Chariot of the Gods and Heart of Darkness.

STAGE I: PATHOGEN CARRIER “THE TAINTED”

Changes begin with the onset of rapid surface mottling in the infected victim's extremities and move inward towards the core body.  Eventually the victim's cranium begins to soften and elongate as their higher functions are rewired.  By the end of this stage, the process becomes excruciating, and the victim lashes out.  As acidosis takes effect, the victim's pH levels shift significantly.

INFECTION: Exposure to the black pathogen is treated as a disease with Virulence 6.  If the Sickness Roll fails, the patient enters Stage I.  If the roll succeeds, the patient is clear until exposed again.  

Within one Shift, the victim starts to exhibit the first symptoms.  For humans, this causes their STRESS LEVEL to increase by one.  Androids will simply be confused.  Within another Shift, the patient typically advances to Stage II.

STAGE II: PATHOGEN DEVIANT “MUTATE”

Painful cellular mutations ravage the Abomination's body, causing them to take on an aggressive posture.  The victim's limbs distend and become pliable, allowing them to contort into strange positions.  The brain and skull continue to elongate, and the victim takes on a feral appearance and attitude.  Strength, speed, and agility are all heightened.  Only a rudimentary knowledge of their former self remains, but they are still aware enough to use basic tools and weapons.

EFFECTS: The victim gains Speed 2, i.e., it gets to act twice per Round.  STRENGTH increases by 3 (and Health along with it).  AGILITY is increased by 1, while EMPATHY is reduced to 1. EMPATHY-based skills cannot be used.  Firearms and other technological items cannot be used.  The victim becomes immune to MANIPULATION.  The victim becomes aggressive and attacks others on sight.  An infected PC can play out one such attack, then the victim turns into an NPC controlled by the GM.

STAGE III: PATHOGEN HUSK “REVENANT”

TRAITS: Instinctual Aggression, Advanced Dementia

The subject's body is in an advanced state of DNA recoding.  A translucent gelatinous cowl has grown over most of their head, revealing a sunken hideous caricature of their former visage beneath.  As the structure of the subject's original features dissolves into the acidic gelatin, their skull becomes more pronounced.  Eventually, any semblance of human origin recedes and remains barely visible within the cowl.  The subject's feet each splay into three thick toes, their arms elongate like a primate's, and they sprint using their knuckles to propel themselves.

RULES: As with Stage II, Strength increases by 2 more (and Health along with it).  Agility is increased by 1 more.  Wits is reduced to 1.  No skills based on Wits except OBSERVATION can be used.  Immune to MANIPULATION and panic.  The cowl gives a natural Armor Rating of 3.  The subject is now handled as a full Xenomorph and gets its own table for signature attacks (Abomination Attacks (Stage III & IV)).  Within four Shifts, the subject advances to Stage IV.

FULFREMMEN “THE PERFECTED”

In search of perfection, the Engineers inadvertently unleashed the Perfected and their Protomorphs on the galaxy millennia ago.  Faced with the protomorphic outbreak overwhelming vast regions of their space, the Engineers began annihilating entire Proto-Hiveworlds.  They also began wiping out their own colonies and creations to prevent the Perfected from transforming them.  The Perfected and the Engineers nearly wiped each other out—the few remaining specimens of Homo Genitor retreating to deep space and the Perfected hibernating to await the coming of new life for them to transform.

Many millennia later, human colonists in the Far Spinward Colonies disturbed dormant Proto-Hive worlds and awakened the Perfected from their long slumber.  After the Perfected consumed those colonies, they returned to their dark slumber—until a colonial expedition exploring the region recently disturbed them anew.  Resurrected once more, the Perfected seek to transmute humankind and the beings who engineered them.

SHADES OF BLACK AND FUTURES LOST

A genetic accelerant created by the Engineers, chemical agent A0-3959X.91-15 is a black, tar-like substance with both destructive and life-generating capabilities.  While it exists in a viscous liquid form, it atomizes when released in the atmosphere, killing or altering all living things unlucky enough to be within range.  While the full extent of its mutagenic potential is unknown, Agent A0-3959X.91-15 and its derivative strains are best described as transformative pathogens.  Any living thing that comes into direct contact with the black goo will either die horribly, give birth to monsters, or become a monster themselves.

Different strains of the Engineers' black pathogen were developed to create variations on genetic acceleration.  Stored at different planetary facilities, many were used to bioengineer entire worlds and species.  Others were weaponized, transforming the Engineers and their genetic offshoots into abominations, anathemas, neomorphic, protomorphic, and xenomorphic mutations, as well as other abhorrent creatures—including the Engineers' worst enemy—the Perfected.

The original unmutated 26 Draconis Strain that created the Perfected is lost—all remnants of it destroyed by the Engineers in this region of space millennia ago.  Developed in the Middle Heavens at the Engineer facility on the now destroyed planet LV-1113, this strain is needed for the Perfected to evolve to their next state of being.  What that new form will be is unknown, but it is terrifying to even contemplate.  

A NOTE FROM MU/TH/UR: The fate of the only known remaining ampules of the 26 Draconis Strain is covered in the Colonial Marines Operations Manual and the Chariot of the Gods, Destroyer of Worlds, and Heart of Darkness Cinematic Scenarios—but that doesn’t mean there aren’t more out there.  It’s rumored that some ampules of 26 Draconis were even stored in one of the Engineer pyramids on LV-223.  Until they rediscover the original formula, the Perfected will blanket the stars, transforming human and android alike into more of their kind as they go system-to-system in search of the strain.

A CRISIS OF FAITH

The Perfected and the Engineers both revere the same alien form—a cosmic horror that infests entire populations and births sleek ebony harbingers of death—the Destroying Angels.

Stone tablets found in archaeological ruins on remote worlds suggest the Engineers were masterful genetic manipulators who spanned the stars, creating life in their own image.  If the translations are correct, these beings sought to achieve perfection by recreating this Destroying Angel and then holding dominion over it.  The text suggests the Engineers created the Perfected in their quest to perfect their own Destroying Angels.  Infecting their masters and transforming them into a new form of life, the Perfected themselves believe they must transform the universe for the coming of the Destroying Angels.

Some scholars argue the translation speaks only of a particular sect of Engineers, while others conclude that there is not enough surviving text present to make an accurate translation of any kind.  One thing is certain—the Perfected and Engineers' differing ideologies over this Destroying Angel brought them into conflict with each other.

These Destroying Angels are evident in the Engineer's objet d'art—a cruciform being with an elongated curved head dominates their sculptures.  Whether this form is Xenomorph XX121 or a similar progenitor to it is unclear—but what is known is that the Engineers destroyed themselves in their dark genetic attempts to re-create what they saw as the perfect organism.

PROTO-XENOMORPHS

THE LIVING PROTO-HIVE

Some strains of the black goo biogenetic accelerant can fuse with mechanical forms.  Invading power systems, they leech energy to alter the machine's molecular structure to accept a self-replicating parasitic growth of proto-plasmamorphic life within it.  The infected machinery is altered as the lifeforms take root, growing acidic tendrils and secreting resin that begins to form on the machine's surface.  This melding of biology and technology produces the Living Proto-Hive.

PROTO-HIVE SPECIAL ABILITIES

The special abilities described here are common to the Living Proto-Hive.

RADIATION:

Most forms of radiation will nourish the Proto-Hive rather than harm it.  Any section of Hive bombarded with radiation will regenerate 1 Health per Round for up to ten Rads without ill effects—i.e., the first 10 points suffered are ignored from any radiation rolls.  After that, the overload of radiation takes its toll and damage is suffered as per normal radiation effects (Radiation in the core rulebook).

NO HEAT SIGNATURE:

Using infrared and thermographic sensors to locate someone or something within the Living Proto-Hive is impossible—the entire structure radiates a mask of thermal energy.

ACID SPLASH:

When a tendril, membrane, wall, vein, or artery of the Proto-Hive is damaged some of its acid blood may splash on its attacker and anyone within ENGAGED range.  Only damage that draws blood causes an acid splash—hence a fire attack does not have this effect.  

The strength of an acid splash is the Acid Splash rating of the Hive segment plus the amount of damage that the segment took from the attack, in Base Dice, with Damage 1.  Armor reduces the damage, but for each rolled, its Armor Rating is reduced by one, as the acid eats through it.  The acid blood will also affect the environment, and may splash nearby ammo and grenades, or burn through floors, wiring, a ship's hull, and so on (GM's discretion).

The acid blood continues to burn after the initial splash.  A victim who suffers damage from the initial splash suffers another attack each Round, at the start of the Round, just like for fire damage (Fire in the core rulebook).  However, the number of Base Dice rolled for the attack is halved (rounding fractions down) at the start of each new Round, as the acid is slowly used up.  If at any point an acid attack roll fails to inflict any damage the acid has burned itself out and the acid effect is over.

If a victim is Broken by the acid splash, or suffers further acid splash damage when already Broken, they must make a Death Roll every Round until they either die or are saved by a MEDICAL AID roll.

IRRITATING SPORES:

These spore polyps grow around sensitive areas of the Living Proto-Hive and act as an early warning system for the Fulfrem­­men.  Anyone within ENGAGED range of a polyp must make a MOBILITY roll (no action) each Round to not disturb it.  Failure means the polyp bursts, spreading its spores.  They can cause a nasty rash and irritation (+1 STRESS LEVEL), but no real damage.  The spores can be washed off (and the stress modifier removed with it)—or the effects can be negated by an anti­allergic from any medkit.

Similar to other Plagiarus lifeforms, the Protomorph is a parasitic organism that gestates within a living host.  A Protomorph's blood is only mildly caustic, but not acidic enough to cause damage.

Protomorphs are genetically linked to the Fulfremmen (Fulfremmen “The Perfected”) and will always respond to their empathic commands.  Their life cycle goes through at least five known stages of evolution, the details of which are covered on the following below.

A NOTE FROM MU/TH/UR:

In Building Better Worlds, the planets the PCs explore and colonize are all unique characters in their own right.  Some will be angry worlds, battering you with their high winds and abrasive storms, while others will be placid and nurturing worlds, welcoming you with their sunny uplands and fertile plains. But they all hold secrets to be uncovered.

This appendix gives you all the tools you need to create expanded solar systems and the planets that populate them, to colonize those planets with new settlements full of exciting opportunities, to see those colonies grow and thrive, and become the stage for thrilling adventures in the far frontier.

These rules should be used in conjunction with The Lost Worlds campaign, where the PCs will survey, explore and colonize planets during their expeditions.

They also allow you to create new solar systems and planets to expand your campaign beyond the expeditions contained in this book and take it wherever you want it to go.

THE COLONY ATTRIBUTES

Every colony is measured by six numerical attributes and has a command team (PCs and/or NPCs) with influence over how well these attributes perform.

  • ECONOMY: The financial health of the colony, the value of imports and exports and the “soft” economy, created by enterprising colonists themselves.
  • POTENTIAL: The colony exists, in large part, to exploit the potential of this new world.  This attribute covers the prospecting operations to find, and make the most of, that potential.
  • PRODUCTIVITY: The industrial output of the colony, with factories, construction projects and mining operations, all delivered through the sweat of the common workers.
  • MAINTENANCE: The mechanical health of the colony.  Do the lights flicker? Does the water taste worryingly like metal? Do critical systems break down every day? Or does the colony hum like a well-oiled machine?
  • SCIENCE: Research and innovation, science is essential for two things: analyzing the hazards of your new world and finding ways to manage them; and finding every scientific advance available and making a lot of money.
  • SPIRIT: The spirit of the colony represents the atmosphere of the growing society and consists of both the morale of the people and the general level of law and order.

Each attribute is measured by a number that can be as low as one and has no theoretical upper limit.  The attribute scores will grow as the colony develops.

COLONY ATTRIBUTES IN PLAY

Attributes do not only apply to the development of the colony.  In play, they can be used by the GM to determine how the colony as a whole responds in certain situations.  In these cases, the colony would roll a number of Base Dice equal to the relevant attribute, and its ability to cope or its reaction as a community would be driven by the number of successes scored on that roll.

COLONY DEVELOPMENT

The colony's Development Level is measured by totaling all the attribute ratings into one score.  This level dictates how many colony initiatives can be progressed during any one six-month period of time, called a Cycle (The Colony Cycle).  The lowest Development Level, for a colony that's brand new and just starting out, is officially classified as Inceptor.  There are five more levels of development that reflect the status and profitability of the colony.

COLONY INITIATIVES

A colony can only grow and thrive if its leadership and people help it develop.  They do this by choosing and running initiatives that influence the health and strength of the colony's attributes.  There are three types of initiative:

  • POLICY: An approach to life that will encourage certain behaviors within the population, a policy costs nothing to implement but once chosen it lasts for two full Cycles and cannot be changed until those two Cycles are complete.
  • INSTALLATION: A physical asset or facility that delivers a specific and ongoing capability for the colony. An Installation is built once, and its effect is always available or applied every Cycle thereafter.  It has a build cost of one point of the relevant attribute to which it applies.
  • PROJECT: A short-term initiative intended to resolve an immediate need rather than a long-term venture, projects cost one Economy to run, and last for one Cycle.

THE COLONY COMMAND TEAM

The command team are not only in positions of authority in the colony but are each responsible for a specific attribute and how that develops, with a key skill that applies to their attribute.  The team is led by the Colonial Supervisor, the only officer who can influence all the attributes.  In order of Command authority:

  • THE COLONIAL SUPERVISOR: Usually a government appointee, in overall command.  This job can influence all the colony attributes, and the key skill is COMMAND.
  • CORPORATE DIRECTOR: Always a corporate appointment, this role is responsible for economic affairs and keeps an eye on the company's investment.  The Corporate Director is responsible for the Economy attribute, and the key skill is MANIPULATION.
  • CIVIL MARSHAL: Responsible for law and order and the well-being of the colony's people.  The Marshal takes responsibility for the colony's Spirit, and the key skill is COMMAND.
  • PROSPECTOR GENERAL: Responsible for making the most of the colony's Potential.  The key skill is OBSERVATION.
  • UNION STEWARD: The voice of the workforce and responsible for the colony's output.  However, while this post is in the command chain it is a notional corporate nod to the workers, and carries no real authority.  The Steward is responsible for Productivity, and the key skill for this job is HEAVY MACHINERY.
  • CHIEF ENGINEER: Responsible for the smooth running of the colony, and the colony's Maintenance attribute. The key skill is COMTECH.
  • SCIENCE ADVISOR: Leads all scientific research that both benefits the colony and will bring a substantial dollar return.  Responsible for the Science attribute, the key skill is OBSERVATION.

You can start your campaign with an established colony your players already call home or with them about to arrive to start their new lives.  In this case the GM should generate the system, planet, colony, and the command team in advance of your first session.  Then move on to the section The Colony Cycle.  Alternatively, you can start your campaign with the PCs about to embark on their journey, looking for a new home and surveying as they go.  This makes for a thrilling first session as the players search the heavens, discovering the wonders and dangers of the world they are about to make home.  When having found the planet to colonize, follow these steps:

  1. The PCs choose which region of the planet they wish to colonize.
  2. Determine the starting attributes of the colony, rolling D3+1 per attribute.  These scores are then modified by the expedition’s primary mission (Primary Mission Attribute Modifiers) and the resource potential of the region (Resource Potential).
  3. Determine the colony’s starting Development Level, by adding together all the attribute scores and comparing the total to the Colony Development table.  A new colony is almost certainly going to be an Inceptor level settlement—just established and still finding its feet.
  4. Determine the colony’s starting policies, installations and projects.  The colony will be able to initiate a number of these initiatives depending upon its Development Level.  These should be chosen by the players, and any costs and bonuses are applied to the attribute scores immediately.
  5. Establish the colony command team.  The player characters may take these roles, with the GM’s approval.  Command NPCs are important in the running of the colony.

HOW MANY FOLKS?

We have not included rules to track the population of your colony.  Many colonies would be set up with only dozens, or a few hundred, colonists. Others would involve huge colony ships with thousands of colonists and any number of embryos aboard.  But this doesn’t mean they can all immediately set up home on the new colony.  An advance party would be revived from hypersleep to set up the colony, and additional colonists would only be revived when there’s space and a need for them.  As such, the colony progression as described will work for any colonist scenario you want, and it’s up to the GM to decide the size of your campaign’s expedition.

THE COLONY CYCLE

The colonist’s story is one of opportunity and adventure, but it’s also one of hard work and the passage of time.  To reflect this, colony campaigns work to a Cycle.  Each Cycle lasts six months in game time and allows for two things to happen.  First, the players will take forward their adventures in the usual way, through two or three scenarios or gaming sessions.  Second, after those stories are concluded, that period of six months will pass, and the Cycle completes.

The End of Cycle process tells the players how well the colony has performed, through a short series of dice rolls and skill tests and is the opportunity for the players to decide what initiatives they should run during the cycle to come.  By following this process, the individual stories told by the players progress well, and the colony grows in an appreciable way as the game develops.

The End of Cycle is divided into four phases, described below.

PHASE 1—COLONY INCIDENTS

Over the last six months a lot may have happened around the colony.  These incidents are managed by rolling on the Colony Incidents Table (below).  For each of the global or regional effects listed below, the colony is subjected an extra D66 roll.  Keep the highest result.

  • GLOBAL RADIATION: Strong or Extreme
  • GLOBAL ATMOSPHERE: Corrosive
  • GLOBAL CLIMATE: Frozen, Hot or Burning
  • ANY OF THESE REGIONAL EFFECTS: Howling outgassing, many earthquakes, hurricanes, active volcanoes, tornados, or acid rain.
PHASE 2—THE COMMAND TEAM DOES ITS JOB

Each member of the command team has an attribute for which they are responsible, and a key skill that applies to it (The Colony Command Team).  They (either PC or NPC) each make a skill test against the key skill for their job, to see how they have performed.  These rolls cannot be pushed but they can gain a bonus of up to +3 dice for assistance from other colony workers and may have other modifiers at the GM’s discretion.

If the roll fails, the relevant attribute rating is reduced by 1.  If the roll achieves one success, there is no change to the attribute rating.  If the roll achieves two or more successes, the relevant attribute is increased by 1.

The rule is different for the Colony Supervisor, as they have greater impact and can influence any attribute.  If the Colony Supervisor fails their roll, the colony loses two points, from attribute rolled randomly.  If the Colony Supervisor succeeds with one success, there is no change.  If the Colony Supervisor succeeds with two or more successes, the colony gains two points, added to random attributes.

PHASE 3—GROW OR DECLINE

A colony develops to the next stage when its Development Level total reaches the next threshold ().  The colony immediately gains the benefits of being a more developed facility:

  • The colony can now commission more initiatives per Cycle than before.
  • The colony has made a break-through in its primary mission, as decided by the GM (for example, a terraforming colony might see an improvement to the planet’s atmosphere score by one point).
  • Each PC gets a reward of their choice, to be agreed upon with the GM.  This could be a new job, or a bonus or promotion in the current one, or the granting of a specific favor.

It is possible that the Development Level of the colony goes down, and if so, the colony immediately reverts to that lower level:

  • The colony must manage with the lower number of initiatives.
  • There has been some terrible set-back in the colony’s primary mission, as decided by the GM.
  • The players lose out on something important, as decided by the GM.

If any colony attribute is reduced to zero at the end of a Cycle, the colony fails.  Perhaps supplies run out, the local environment proves too tough to resist or political infighting causes the settlement to implode, but the colony is done for and disbands over the next Cycle.  What this means for the PCs and their survival is up to the GM to decide.

PHASE 4—COLONY INITIATIVES

There are two ways of managing this process, depending upon your style of game:

  1. Regardless of whether any PCs are members of the colony command team, the players make the choices for the colony as a whole.
  2. If there are no players on the colony command team, the GM decides any new initiatives until a player takes up a position of responsibility.

Colony life can be mundane and back-breaking blue-collar work, toiling to earn your shares and gain those all-important bonuses.  But between the sweat, the aching muscles, the broken-down machinery and faulty emergency wiring, there are many other stories waiting to be told if you just know where to look.

THE PLANET STRIKES BACK

The planet is a key character in a colony campaign, so don't forget to make the most of it.  The place the PCs now call home has many characteristics that can be the inspiration for challenging stories of exploration, wonder and survival.  Each region will have features just waiting to be explored or to heap disaster upon your PCs' heads.

PRIMARY MISSIONS

The colony's primary mission may not be at the forefront of the PCs' thinking as they play through scenarios on their new world.  But these missions provide the backdrop for the entire campaign and should feature from time to time.  Keep the colony's primary mission as an overarching theme of the campaign.

PC CHOICES

During the End of Cycle, the players will choose policies, installations, and projects to help develop the colony.  These initiatives build the colony from a mechanical standpoint and are also story hooks in themselves.

COLONY INCIDENTS

The colony incidents rolled during the End of Cycle can also bring story hooks for future scenarios.  Make the most of these incidents and roll them into your campaign.

POLITICS

There will be maneuvering for political advantage in a colony of any size, especially where more than one sponsor is jockeying for primacy.  There are many story opportunities in the rivalry between competing sponsors.  On top of that, the command team may be more or less popular, or seen as expert or incompetent.  Power can be seductive and alluring, and people kill to keep it.

All the wonder and danger of the stars is yours—if you can just wipe the grime off your face and dig the dirt out from under your fingernails first.  Airless moons circle swirling gas giants, eager to be transformed into tomorrow's paradise.  Dark ancient mysteries wait to be unearthed beneath a millennium of debris.  Searing solar flares boil your flesh and blacken your bones as you harness their power to light a hundred worlds.  Long lost mysteries lie entombed in the frozen hearts of icy comets.  Unstable tectonic plates shift to drown iridium mines in scalding lava.  Even the truth of humanity's origins awaits you out there, orbiting some dying star.  And out there amongst it all is something truly horrifying—something that nature never intended.
Something alien.


WHAT'S IN THIS BOOK

This book is a complete campaign module for the ALIEN RPG, giving you all the tools you need to run a full open-world campaign as a pioneering explorer or colonist.  This is the second in a series of modules dedicated to the Campaign play mode (as opposed to Cinematic play, see GAME MODES in the core rulebook).  Each campaign module will focus on one main career in the ALIEN universe.

Just like the core rulebook, this book is divided into a Players' Section (Chapters 1-5) and Game Mother's Section (Chapters 6-10).  All players are allowed to access the Players' Section at any time—this is your field guide to the weapons, vehicles, and protocols of the Extrasolar Colonization Administration (ECA) and its affiliates.  Keep it just as handy as your motion detector, and you might even survive out here on the Frontier.

The Game Mother's section, starting on , is for the GM's eyes only, top secret, hush-hush.  Do not venture here if you are to be a player in this campaign.  Just don't—you'll spoil the fun for everyone.


“To Find and Forge Our Future”

The motto of Earth's Expansion Era into space, “To find and forge the future” is the purview of explorers and colonists.  Both paths fall into two categories—the bold and the foolish.  Which role will you play on the untamed Frontier?

Space is infinite and full of possibilities.  For a century and a half, humankind has traveled to exoplanets to find new resources and new lifeforms.  Yes, you know there are dangers—you aren't an idiot.  But the chance to be at the forefront of human expansion in both territory and knowledge is too thrilling to ignore.

THIS IS RUMOR CONTROL

Ask yourself the big questions—where do we come from? What makes the universe work? For the past century humankind has stood on the precipice of the answers to these and other questions about life, space, and our own origins.

Carrying on the legacy of pioneering entrepreneurs Peter Weyland and Hideo Yutani to push the boundaries of human understanding, the company needs inquisitive minds to explore new worlds and help plumb the depths of space.  You're a pioneer—our future is yours to find.  Discover a mineral-rich moon and have a colony named after you.  Catalog a new lifeform and receive shares in its future exploitation.  The secrets of the universe await you out there amongst the stars, along with the resources humankind needs to conquer the Middle Heavens and beyond.

HERE ARE THE FACTS

Exploring new worlds is a dangerous proposition.  Corporate management will make snap decisions to prioritize the success of the mission over your goddamn life.  Alien planets mean alien lifeforms and alien dangers unique to each new world.  While there is often a backup team on your Scientific Exploration Vessel, that's it—if something threatens the ship itself, you are all screwed and on your own.  

Endurance Tests and Cross Training:

Explorers are required to be at their physical peak before being approved by their sponsors for expedition duty.  Many are cross-trained in starship piloting and repairs to help support a SEV's crew as needed.  You want this job, it's time to get ripped.  You prefer a pot belly, colonial life is for you.  

ICC Quarantine:

Upon returning to any space station, major traffic hub, or core system from any exploration mission resulting in contact with an extrasolar lifeform, expedition teams are required to spend anywhere from 24 hours up to 90 days in ICC quarantine.  If any exploration team fails to notify an ICC branch representative of said contact its members will face fines, imprisonment, and confiscation of assets.

Compensation:

Unlike most careers on the Frontier, explorers are well paid for their work.  Incentives often include book deals, dedicated laboratories after a decade in the field, and positions at prestigious universities.

EDUCATION AND EQUIPMENT

Whether they got it via scholarship, legacy, or corporate sponsorship, explorers are required to be graduates of high education.  Some have even been known to pay their own way, but that's increasingly rare in today's corporate owned colonial communities.  Most are company-sponsored, signing over their careers to corporate greed.  The few elites that make a name for themselves are rewarded lucrative incentive packages—and some of those have their education contracts bought out by the prestigious Geholgod Institute (), allowing them the freedom to choose their own career paths after that.

As far as gear goes, most corporations put their products through field trials on expeditions, so explorers usually have access to the very best (if not always the most thoroughly tested) equipment money can buy.

DANGERS OF SPACE

Faraway colonists report strange findings, spaceship crews on the Frontier discover inexplicable signals and encounter creatures and phenomena that defy classification.  It's an explorer's job to investigate and classify these things—but on what particular layer of hell will you find yourself—and what demons lurk there?

Spatial Phenomena:

Black holes, dark matter, neutrino bursts, and quasars— extraordinary things take form in deep space, their very existence spitting in the eye of an absolute vacuum.  Spatial anomalies are disturbances in the natural order of the universe.  They can take the forms of gravity fluctuations and irregularities, ripples in space that can damage equipment and personnel, alterations in the laws of physics, and areas of disruption inimical to the human brain.

Lifeforms:

For the first 40 years of extrasolar exploration, nothing larger than a microbe was discovered on alien worlds.  The first reported (although unconfirmed) alien lifeforms were worm-like creatures discovered by biologist Rafe Millburn and recorded on the Prometheus mission logs in 2093.  By the turn of the century, other species had been discovered.

One outer rim colonial outpost discovered they had a nocturnal pest problem—poodle-sized cockroaches.  Named Pudel Blattoptera, the insects proved to be docile and intelligent enough to be trained as domestic pets—although there wasn't much of a market for them in the core systems.  Eventually other creatures were discovered—arthropods to synapsids, marsupials to tetrapods—all numbered and recorded in the Weyland-Yutani extrasolar species catalog.

There are even rumors of a black list double X addendum to the W-Y catalog—one that includes truly alien lifeforms ranging from deadly bacteria to eyeless ebon and albino human-sized things with metal teeth and acid for blood—but these are, of course, rumors.

Remnants of Ruined Civilizations:

There is nothing more disconcerting than exploring a new world for the first time and finding the archaeological remains of its former inhabitants.  Several colonies have unearthed evidence of previous occupants.  Some in the scientific community believe these to be the remnants of the Engineers—mysterious beings that are said to have created humankind.  Others have a more rational reason for it.  Humankind has been out about the stars for the past 150 years.  In that time, there have been several colonies that have failed and installations that have been closed. When the Weyland-Yutani merger went down, several colonies were dropped from the colonial catalog.  While some of these were simply closed and evacuated, others were left to fend for themselves.  Conspiracy theorists claim that still others were transformed into company blacksites for all kinds of bioweapons research.  One thing's for certain—there are indeed abandoned outposts and derelict spacecraft out on the Frontier.

Asteroids, Moons, and Planetoids:

Airless asteroids, desolate deserts, magma moons and water worlds—a variety of hostile environs await you on the frontiers of civilizations.  Creating such worlds is covered in detail in chapter 12 of the core rulebook.CREATING STAR SYSTEMS

You already know space is hell—the space truckers that visited your colony when you were a kid made that much clear.  The way you saw it, you had three options for a better life—stow away on a star freighter and take your chances hopping ship-to-ship doing menial tasks, join the colonial marines and find yourself in firefights over lines on a map, or sign up to colonize a brave new world.

THIS IS RUMOR CONTROL

Are you tired of working twelve hour shifts and never getting ahead? Why settle for a thankless job flushing waste vents and other menial tasks for the well-to-do elite? In the core systems, you're a nobody—but you're no nobody! Wouldn't you rather be master of your own destiny, helping to forge our future in the Middle Heavens? In association with Weyland-Yutani Corp, the Extrasolar Colonial Administration is looking for brave souls to conquer humankind's latest frontier—the outer colonies.

Additional compensation is available for the experienced—but no skills are required—the company will train you! Best of all—not only will you get to make a new life for yourself, you'll own shares in the colony you help to shape.

HERE ARE THE FACTS

The prospect of frontier life is exciting to be sure—the idea of taming a new world can seem like a dream to the average lower class citizen of Sol and the other core systems.  The corporations aren't blind to this—they exploit it to convince everyday people like you to pick up and leave their lives behind for a dustbowl existence on some barren rock cut off from the rest of civilization.  Before you sign on the dotted line for your new shit life, however, the company needs to make sure you can handle it.

Psychological Profiling:

All potential colonists are subjected to intense psychological evaluations and tests to confirm their fitness for the expedition.  Weyland-Yutani colonists leaving from Sol system receive this training at the research center on the Mars moon Phobos.  Subjects are strapped to a chair and exposed to a number of audio, visual, olfactory, and physical stimuli.  The tests expect the recipient to show both fear of the unknown and empathy for their fellow colonists— essential traits needed to keep a group alive in a barren environment.

Obligations:

Becoming a colonist isn't a free ride—all settlers of legal age are required to contribute to their community.  Each colonist has a role to play in maintaining a balanced ecosystem.  Whether they fill mechanical, mining, or homesteading positions, everyone is needed.  If shifts are missed too often, a colonist can be forced to leave the colony on the next supply ship.  Any travel expenses are billed to the colonist's account, quickly putting them in severe debt to the company.  

Compensation:

Skilled colonists are offered supplemental wages over laborers who will need to be trained, but everyone receives some kind of share in the colony's profits.  As a colonist, you'll receive room, board, three meals a day, and a small monthly stipend for personal expenses.  When a colony's atmosphere becomes self-sustaining, you'll be given the option of keeping your quarters in the main colony or building a homestead of your own using scrap parts and cargo containers.  Any training the company provides is not for free—costs are broken up into twelve monthly withholdings from your first year of colonial paychecks.  For more, see the sidebar Contract of Colonial Rights and Liberties on the next page.

LIFE ON THE FRONTIER

The idealistic sign on to become exosolar settlers because they're looking for adventure.  And everything seems exciting when they first touch down on a new colony, stand on strange terrain for the first time and look up at stars not seen from home.  That fades as the reality of their new lives sinks in.  Sure, it's life on an alien world, but humans have a tendency to become jaded.  A world's extraordinary features quickly become mundane.

The same goes for the other colonists you meet.  Colonies of 100–200 colonists are tight knit communities—for better or for worse.  Everyone knows each other by name, and word of anyone's activities spreads quickly, taking much of the excitement, mystery, and even privacy from one's life.  It is small town living with supply shortages, dirty air, and threats both natural and unnatural.  Out here, the world you are standing on is trying to kill you.  Toxins mixed in the mid-terraformed atmosphere can cause you to age prematurely, giving you early gray, crows feet, and leathery skin—good times all around.

If there is an ecological disaster, no one is coming right away.  In most cases, it will be at least a week until the colonial admin even knows you missed a comcheck.  If they send an inquiry and wait for a reply, that's another two weeks gone by before they even think about sending someone out to check up on you.

HAND-ME-DOWNS

Unlike explorers, colonists don't have access to the latest and most advanced gear.  Frontier philosophy is that if it ain't broke, don't fix it.  Many of the tools and vehicles used by colonists on the frontier have been around for a century or more.  Luckily for them, a lot of this equipment was state of the art when it was designed and therefore is still viable—as long as it's maintained.

CONTRACT OF COLONIAL RIGHTS AND LIBERTIES

Drafted by two organizations that no longer exist in their original form—the United Nations Interplanetary Corps and Weyland Corp.—the Contract of Colonial Rights grants all UA and 3WE intra and extrasolar colonists the right to free speech, religion, subcontract, assembly, and the right to petition the company or government.

Of these five liberties, the right to subcontract is the most talked about—it allows a colonist to negotiate an agreement with a corporation that waives some or all of these other rights in exchange for additional monetary compensation, shares, or other benefits. For the term of the contract, the colonist revokes their UA or 3WE citizenship and becomes indentured to the company.

Corporate colonial contracts have buy out clauses that allow the colonist to move on to another company should the opportunity arise—assuming they can afford their own buy-out. Sometimes, the company will pay the cost for the colonist, immediately putting them in the new company's debt. Conversely, the contract grants corporations the right to terminate a colonist's employment with only ninety days to not only leave the colony but no longer be aboard company transport.

One extreme interpretation of this clause is the company's right to pull the plug on the colonist's cryosleep chamber if their transport takes too long to get them to their next destination. A more typical solution is for a colonist to wake up at their destination with a huge transportation debt. What's constantly under debate is work hours, wages, health and safety issues, and more. The Extrasolar Colonization Administration recommends that colonists do not subcontract. Unfortunately, working on a colony without a subcontract can be difficult. The small extra benefits a subcontract offers can seem to take the edge off, but in the end the company makes out better than anyone else.

IS HUMANKIND ALONE?

The question of the ages—are we the only intelligent species out there? The discovery of the Arcturians in 2124 has cast doubt on that assertion.  Weyland-Yutani very publicly proclaimed the Arcturians to be an alien species who developed independently from humankind, petitioning the UA government to grant them protected status with Weyland-Yutani as a go-between.  The Arcturians’ DNA, however, is the same as ours.  While lithe and pale-skinned with dark eyes, their features are not outside the range of human norms.  

After reviewing the physical reports, several media sources accused the company of sensationalizing what was merely the discovery of a missing colonial expedition of extremists from the 2050s—the Mesones Muro mission.  If the Affiance-class colony ship had crashed on Arcturus, a small number of survivors may have committed their limited resources towards the maturation of the many embryos stored aboard.  Their eyes and pigmentation could have been genetically altered to reflect the eternal twilight of Arcturus’s equatorial environment.  With little surviving tech left to tame the world, the colony’s elders could have drawn upon the traditions of Mesoamerican culture to develop their own traditions and lifestyles.  

Ultimately, the short answer to our lonely status in the universe appears to be yes whether the Arcturians and others with human DNA are out there or not.  The species Homo Genitor is hypothesized to be responsible for seeding space with other lifeforms derived from their own DNA—DNA that the Prometheus transmissions confirm to be the same as our own.  

Whether the Arcturians are the result of their work or just a rediscovered lost colony is in the eye of the beholder.  While the scientific community and upper echelons of government and military believe them to be alien, the average space trucker, colonist, and marine considers the Arcturians to be a company publicity stunt and that they are very much human.

“Some honch in a cushy office on Earth says go look at a grid reference in the middle of nowhere, we look.  They don't say why, and I don't ask.  I don't ask because it takes two weeks to get an answer out here and the answer's always 'don't ask.'”
