Whether answering to corporate, governmental, or spiritual masters, humankind is in the business of expansion.  Colonial missions may be ordered by many different organizations.  In all cases, however, it will be you and your team who find yourselves on the razor's edge of the frontier, cataloging some new deadly organism or poking your head into a dark mine shaft for the first time.

Exploration of a new planetary system usually starts with a corporate probe flyby.  Sometimes that probe will supply promising data that determines a planetoid is ripe for terraforming and colonization.  More often than not, however, a followup exploration team is sent in to make that final decision.

Whenever there are native fauna and flora, or possible xeno-archaeological ruins, or strange spatial anomalies involved, governments, institutes, and corporations send Scientific Exploration Vehicular expeditions to investigate.  

SCIENTIFIC EXPLORATION VEHICULAR (SEV) EXPEDITIONS


EXTRASOLAR EXPLORATION, ASTRONOMICAL AND TERRESTRIAL RESOURCE ASSESSMENT, AND XENOBIOLOGICAL CATALOGING
No one single entity sends out exploration teams—corporations, institutions, and governments are all looking to stake claims out in the cosmos.  And science can be expensive.  Unless you're in the UPP, there's very few new worlds being explored without sponsorship.  Many of these sponsors are covered later in this chapter.  Most exploration teams are assigned to SEVs—FTL Scientific Exploration Vessels—and dispatched to unexplored sectors on the Frontier and beyond.  Many SEV teams are authorized to stake discovery mining and colonial territorial claims.  In addition to their official duties, Weyland-Yutani SEV expeditions have series 900 special orders to retrieve any uncovered xeno-archaeological artifacts.

EXPLORATION TEAM

A typical SEV crew complement is twelve—one officer (the captain), one company rep, two pilot/technicians, four xenoscientists, one research synthetic, two security officers and a scout.  No medical officer is necessary as an AutoDoc or MedPod can readily fill that role.  Each role is vital to the success of the mission, but any SEV expedition can operate with a team of only six.

Captain: While the exploration team dictates the expedition's mission, anything ship related is the captain's purview.  Many captains chose not to accompany any surface-side expeditions, opting to stay on the ship.  It's the captain's job to make sure he can get his science teams out of whatever trouble they make for themselves, and often that means coordinating a rescue from the Holotab on the bridge.  

Pilots: All SEV missions have at least one dedicated pilot if not two.  As pilots on SEV missions seldom leave the ship, they are picked for a combination of flying experience and high level mechanical and technical skills (HEAVY MACHINERY and/or COMTECH).  

Exo-Scientists: The core of the team will, of course, be scientists.  A geologist and xenobiologist are mandatory—often a xenoarchaeologist and astrophysicist will round out the team.  

Research Associate: Usually an android, a research associate can also be a grad student working on their thesis.  Their mission is to make sure the scientists have everything they need to complete theirs.  

Company Representative: The company who sponsored the expedition usually sends a suit to assess the exploitable assets discovered by the team.  

Security Officers: Exploring new worlds is like looking for trouble—planetoids thought to be unclaimed could already be inhabited by either unregistered settlers or native fauna.  As such, security forces are often assigned to protect a SEV team.  While it's a security officer's job to ensure the safety of the mission, that only applies to the company rep's interpretation of those parameters.  In other words—the company rep can order the security team to turn on the scientists in order to protect the company's interests before the safety of the crew.  

Scout: Scouts explore ahead of the rest of the team, mapping out terrain and looking for unseen dangers.  Though the role of a scout can be accomplished by a wildcatter, it is more often than not filled by an LRRV, a pair of Pups (@UUID[Item.bJ65FWpzHIoosqsi]{"Pups" Mapping Device}), or a well-trained dog.  To avoid the risk of contamination on new worlds, many dogs have recently begun to be replaced by synthetic canines.

EXTRASOLAR COLONIZATION ADMINISTRATION (ECA)


SAFETY PROTOCOLS, FAIR LABOR STANDARDS, HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES, COLONY TRANSPORT, ESTABLISHMENT, AND SUPPORT
Often simply called colonial administration, the Extrasolar Colonization Administration's mission is to protect colonial claims and advocate for the rights of all off-world colonists.  The ECA was formed by the UA in the wake of the United Nations Interplanetary Corps' collapse nearly seven decades ago.  They support and monitor all extrasolar colonies and stations belonging to both the UA and their allies like the 3WE.  The ECA maintains toxic exposure safety standards and keeps medicines and supplies flowing.  Since its inception, the ECA has fought for colonists' rights to fair wages, better health care, benefits, stock options, and more down time by proposing numerous amendments to the Contract Of Colonial Rights And Liberties.  Unfortunately, they have been directly opposed by corporate lobbyists.  The ECA has been overtaxed by the Oil and Frontier Wars, causing several sector-wide disruptions in supply chains.

COLONIAL “FIRST FAMILY” SETTLERS

Sometimes when a new world is settled, a small number of colonists are sent to survey the terrain and tame the wilderness before the full colony is established.  Consisting of about a dozen colonists, these initial colonial groups are often referred to as first family settlements.

First families need managers, a deputy marshal or security officer, three wildcatters, four roughnecks, and a science technician.  As the wildcatters and roughnecks often include married couples, it's inevitable that one or more children will be present as well.  First Family colonial missions usually last three months to a year before corporate makes the decision to expand the settlement to full colony status.

General Manager: Essentially a glorified administrator, the general manager is a figurehead position in a colony to keep colonists' complaints from reaching corporate ears.  A general manager's job is to balance the community's needs with the company's quotas—always leaning in the company's favor, of course.  General managers are chosen for their apparent lack of initiative and are intended to act as puppets for their corporate rulers.  

Assistant Manager: Sometimes a potential colony rates high enough to warrant an assistant manager as well.  Either a yes man or an android, the assistant manager's job is to further compartmentalize “unnecessary” complaints to keep them from reaching the manager.  Assistant managers work both sides of the fence—if they can prove themselves more adept than their managers, they can often be advanced to replace them.  

Security Officer or Deputy Colonial Marshal: Someone has to protect the colony's assets—mechanical and flesh and blood alike.  Usually, the company sends a security officer with the rank of sergeant—either an ex-marine or retiring corporate mercenary.  Their job is to not only watch over the new settlement but to teach the colonists how to fend for themselves.  If a new settlement is located in a contested area of space, a sector deputy marshal will take up this role.  A deputy can stay on for up to a year before moving to the next settlement.  

Wildcatters: The lifeblood of any mining colony, wildcatters seek out new resources in the unmapped terrain of a new world.  In addition to their standard salaries, wildcatters are awarded company shares in their finds.  For information on wildcatters, see Wildcatter.  

Roughnecks: Tractors, mineral extractors, and atmospheric processors all have one thing in common—they're all heavy machinery.  As such, they all break down, and are in need of good maintenance teams and technicians to keep them running.  When your prefab housing crate's heater fails in a methane blizzard, you'll be damn happy you have a roughneck or two to swap out a heating coil or tighten a boilerplate.  

Science Technician: A mining colony is going to need a resident science expert.  While different fields apply to different worlds, this usually means a geologist/meteorologist—a terraforming colony is going to need to know about soil, atmosphere, and weather factors.  In the absence of a biologist, an AutoDoc can take care of most health issues, but some medical training is advised.  A science technician is a low-level scientist, usually without a degree.  They are, however, an integral part of a fledgling colonial community, even if they are made to feel like an outsider amongst more rough and tumble hands-on colonists.  

The Kid or Pet: While cats make good companions on space stations and freighters, dogs have long accompanied humankind into the wilderness, offering aid and protection in exchange for food and love.  As colonies are a family business, kids are a big part of taming the Frontier.  At least one member of an initial colonial team will likely bring their offspring along for the ride—for better or worse.

FULL COLONY EFFORT

After a potential colony's First Family has filed its reports, true colonization begins.  If an atmospheric processor is needed to transform the air, a colony transports some 30 to 50 families along with whatever equipment and tools they'll need to terraform the world.  Colonial administrators, wildcatters, roughnecks, and doctors are all needed.  For the first few decades, exploring the planetoid's geology and maintaining the atmospheric processor are paramount.  As the air purifies and more resources are discovered, more families join the colony and migrant miners are brought in to help with the work.

It's important to note that while all explorations start with an expedition team or probe flyover, not every settlement begins with a first family.  Sometimes the exploration team's report is enough for the company to set up a full colonial operation immediately.

GOVERNMENTAL ORGANIZATIONS

With the chaos caused by the Frontier War, the ECA has begun to lose its authority on the Frontier.  Other organizations have stepped up to both help maintain order and take advantage of the chaos for their own purposes.

CENTRAL CONFEDERATION OF AFRICA (CCA)

Formed from the individual nation states of the African continent in the 2050s, the CCA is a parliamentary unitary republic in which the governing power rests in a centralized sovereignty.  That central government commonly delegates authority to subnational units and distributes policy decisions to them for implementation.  The CCA is a permanent member of the UNISC security council.  The CCA parliament is tired of the disputes between its interstellar neighbors and hopes to one day unify the supernations into a United Systems with the individual supernations as member states of one centralized government.

At first glance, the Central Confederation of Africa might seem like a minor interstellar power at best—the star nation doesn't have a significant presence on a map of the Middle Heavens.  Instead, they have independent colonies spread throughout the territories of the ICSC, UA, and 3WE.  At the end of the last decade, CCA SEV teams explored the Nyame Sector—an area of space just spinward of the Far Reach that includes the now infamous space trucker route called the Gauntlet.  The cluster is rich in mineral resources.  The CCA settled Sutter's World and began shipping their precious metals from there to Anchorpoint for international distribution.  The wealth of the Nyame Sector has caused the CCA dollar to rise in value to rival the W-Y dollar—a prospect that Weyland-Yutani finds alarming in the least.

Unlike the other supernations, the CCA has no discernible borders to protect—forcing them to face the same problems with piracy and invasion as individual Frontier colonies.  Because of this, the Central Confederation of Africa has poured resources into jump-starting a peacekeeping organization that will vigilantly stand guard over these isolated worlds.

UNITED NATIONS INTERSTELLAR SETTLEMENT CORPS (UNISC)

PEACEKEEPING, DIPLOMATIC PROTOCOLS, HUMANITARIAN EFFORTS, DISASTER PREVENTION AND RELIEF An intergovernmental and intercorporate colonial peacekeeping organization, the United Nations Interstellar Settlement Corps' purpose is to maintain interstellar peace and security, develop amicable relations among supernations and megacorps, achieve interplanetary cooperation, and be a center for harmonizing the actions of extrasolar colonies.  Diplomatic situations often see UNISC peacekeepers monitoring post-conflict areas and mitigating border disputes.  Called the United Nations Interplanetary Corps (UNIC) when it was instituted in the 21st century, the organization was originally intended to govern the Sol system and near-Earth colonies.  As humanity began reaching into deep space and establishing extrasolar colonies, megacorporations like Weyland Corp took more and more power from both individual and super nations.

By the 2110s, the major corporations had pinned the loss of the far spinward colonies on UNIC and the organization was disbanded.  Soon reinvented as the United Nations Interstellar Settlement Corps (UNISC) with the intention of expanding its involvement in the policing and provision of security for the settlements within the Middle Heavens.  While they have been instrumental in drafting treaties and agreements between warring supernations and megacorps over the decades, UNISC could not find the intercorporate or international support and funding needed to enforce trade agreements, non-aggression pacts, and human rights in the extrasolar community—its services were made all but redundant by the Extrasolar Colonial Administration and the United States Colonial Marines.

But that wasn't the end for the UN.  In 2180, the modest interstellar nation known as the Central Confederation of Africa discovered and laid claim to an area of space rich in mining assets.  They poured their resources into the UNISC in an effort to unite the despondent nations and corporations and put an end to decades of cold wars.  As such, they launched the Great Mother Mission in 2182—a massive colonial undertaking to travel to the far spinward colonies.  Their mandate—reestablish trade with any surviving settlements and recolonize those lost.

With the outbreak of the Frontier and Colony Wars in 2184 and '85, the UNISC began providing aid to the ECA.  Establishing its headquarters on Anchorpoint Station, the UNISC has doubled down on efforts to ensure stability to the war-torn Middle Heavens, both offering relief to colonies cut off by the conflicts and forming the United Nations Interstellar Settlement Corps Exoplantary Peacekeepers (UNISCEP)—a multinational and multi-corporate peacekeeping force to maintain order.  The UNISC Security Council includes the CCA, UA, UPP, 3WE, and—representing the ICSC as of 2181—the Hyperdyne Corporation.

THROOP RESCUE AND RECOVERY ORGANIZATION (TR&R)

RAPID RESPONSE, SEARCH AND RESCUE, CRISIS INVESTIGATION AND MANAGEMENT, SALVAGE AND RECOVERY
Throop Rescue and Recovery is a UNISC sponsored private organization.  Independent and discreet in their operations, Throop R&R is often called upon to save lives and recover assets without corporate or supranational internal politics getting in the way.  Throop is equipped with a fleet of nine Model CM90V Corvus-class salvage vessels (same as the CM-90S Corvus in the core rulebook, but with enhanced gravity drives providing an FTL Rating 4).  These ships each carry two recovery shuttles.

UNITED AMERICAS (UA)

 

With regulatory organizations such as the Extrasolar Colonization Administration (ECA) and the Interstellar Commerce Commission (in the core rulebook) in place to maintain safety standards, the United Americas leaves the exploration and colonization of its frontiers to the private sector.  Other UA governmental agencies involved in the protection of the colonies include the Colonial Marshal Bureau, Colonial Marines, and Outer Rim Defense Fleet—all of which work together with UNISC to maintain the outer colonies.

 
 

COLONIAL MARSHAL BUREAU (CMB)

LAW ENFORCEMENT, BORDER PATROL, HOMEWORLD SECURITY
While a division of the United Americas, the Colonial Marshal Bureau has the authority to work within the borders of the 3WE as well.  Sometimes called the Office of Colonial Marshals, the CMB is the law enforcement arm of the United American Extrasolar Colonial Administration.  The law on the frontier, marshals also double as designated ICC agents in regions where none are stationed.  They are usually assigned based on the number of colonists a settlement boasts.  For less civilized areas, a single marshal's office will service an entire sector of space.  Colonies that don't rate their own marshal or deputy are supposed to be protected by corporate appointed security, but this often amounts to volunteers with a mislabeled crate or two of century-old assault rifles.  Marshals often work in tandem with the USCG and now the UNISC.

UNITED STATES COLONIAL MARINE CORPS (USCMC)

EXPEDITIONARY WARFARE, FORCE PROJECTION, RECONNAISSANCE, INTER­PLANETARY STRIKE

       


The elite fighting force of the United Americas, the United States Colonial Marine Corps is the primary UA force protecting the Outer Rim and Frontier colonies.  Caught in multiple overlapping wars with the UPP, ICSC, and terrorist groups for nearly a decade, the marines are spread too thin to adequately guard all the colonies.  The threat of the recent border bombings and allegations of misconduct by high ranking generals and a shadow government organization buried within the ranks of the USCMC have caused most colonists to lose faith in the corps.  For more on the USCMC and their struggles on the Frontier, see Free League Publishing's Colonial Marines Operations Manual.

 

UNITED AMERICAN COLONIAL GUARD (USCG)

RESERVE FORCE, CIVIC ACTION, DISASTER RELIEF
This reserve force of colonists is usually only activated to assist in natural disaster relief or in times of civil unrest to augment the Colonial Marshal Bureau.  Members of the Colonial Guard only receive basic training.  In times of unrest, a marshal or marine transport can land at a colony and assemble a “posse” of UACG reservists for rescue and/or defense duty.

UNITED AMERICAN OUTER RIM DEFENSE FLEET (UAORDF)

POWER PROJECTION, MASSIVE DETERRENCE, SPACELIFT, INTERSTELLAR WARFARE
The original protectors of the Outer Rim colonies, the Outer Rim Defense Fleet was in the process of being gradually phased out after the Tientsin War—so much so that they were on the verge of being decommissioned when the Frontier and Colony Wars broke out.  After two of the five remaining active star groups were decimated in the initial Border Bombers incident (Border Bombers Pathogen), the United American Allied Command Crestus shipyards were put into action by Secretary of Defense Almirante De La Flota Joëlle De La Cruz, bringing the retired ships out of mothballs.  Thanks to aid from the UNISC, retrofit of the ORDF will soon be complete—hopefully in time to restore order and offer relief to the colonies.

THE UNION OF PROGRESSIVE PEOPLES (UPP)

 

Unfortunately for the Progressive Peoples, the UPP inherited Weyland Corp's mostly tapped out colonies in the once fertile Outer Veil.  The UPP simply does not have enough resources to feed all its people.  Overcrowded colonies have made expansion a must—and the UPP is willing to take new worlds by force if necessary.  

 
 

PROGRESSIVE PEOPLES COSMOS EXPLORATION CORPS (CEC)

EXPANSION, RECONNAISSANCE, ASTRONOMICAL AND TERRESTRIAL RESOURCE ASSESSMENT, MINING AND COLONIAL TERRITORIAL CLAIMS
In addition to their Space Operating Forces (SOF), the UPP has the Cosmos Exploration Corps—a less militaristic branch dedicated to extrasolar exploration.  The CEC's mission is to aggressively seek out potential new colonies to tame and establish new settlements there as quickly as possible.  Typical for the UPP, the Cosmos Exploration Corps operates on a low budget with second-hand equipment and an aging fleet of Model CYG-NS3 Starclippers (CYG-NS3 Star Clipper the core rulebook).  These explorers make the best of it, risking their lives in faulty spacecraft to better the lives of the people.  After they identify a potential resource world, CEC teams stay put until a SOF fighting group can establish a garrison there.

THE THREE WORLD EMPIRE (3WE)

 

The 3WE colonial resources have been dwindling for decades.  Bad deals with the likes of Weyland-Yutani have kept the empire from securing the powerbase it needs to stand on its own.  Of late the 3WE has encountered dissent within its outermost colonies—planets like New Albion in the Weyland Isles Sector have declared their independence, leading to the political clusterfuck the media refers to as the 3WExit.  As the Colony Wars progress, the situation in the Weyland Isles has escalated, causing the UPP and ICSC forces to get involved.  With Frontier worlds changing hands overnight, it's a dangerous time for 3WE colonists.  

 
 

ROYAL EXPEDITIONARY GROUP (REG)

EXTRASOLAR EXPLORATION, XENOBIOLOGICAL CATALOGING, COLONIZATION, ASTRONOMICAL AND TERRESTRIAL RESOURCE ASSESSMENT
Nicknamed Reggies, the Royal Expeditionary Group is an offshoot of the Royal Armed Forces.  Less concerned about cataloging new findings than they are about securing new assets for the Three World Empire, most Reggie SEV missions will see a small group of officers, government officials, and/or royalty along for the ride—thrill seekers who sit on the sidelines while their people do the heavy lifting.  It's these officials' job to make an assessment on the potential benefits of a new world vs apparent threats, putting the lives of their science team in danger for a perceived betterment of the empire.  

SIR PETER WEYLAND'S EXPLORERS ACADEMY (SPWEA)

ACADEMIC AND TECHNICAL EDUCATION
Founded by Sir Peter Weyland in 2036, the Explorer's Academy is a 3WE alternative grad school for underprivileged college students interested in the fields of biotech, nanotech, cybernetics and terraforming.  For the past century and a half, the top graduates of the program have been offered pioneering positions at prestigious military and private organizations like the empire's Royal Expeditionary Group and Weyland-Yutani Corporation.  The academy also sponsors a colonial charity group called the Little Explorers.  Little Explorers is dedicated to the scientific and technological education of troubled middle school students.

INDEPENDENT CORE SYSTEM COLONIES (ICSC)

 

To the average Frontier colonist, the ICSC seems like a dream—independent worlds who own what they produce and work together for a better interstellar community.  This, of course, is a lie.  The Independent Core System Colonies is essentially a dummy government formed by a consortium of corporations seeking both a tax shelter and the autonomy to operate free of governmental safety regulations.  As such, the lush colonies of the ICSC are a dichotomy of the wealthy elite and the indentured working class who labor to keep them content.  While corporations like Alphatech and Steer City Cattle Company have colonies or expeditions throughout the Outer Rim, the organizations listed here outnumber those by far.  

 
 

ICSC INVESTMENT GROUP (ICSCIG)

FINANCIAL BUSINESS OPERATIONS, CAPITAL EXPENDITURE, FINANCING AND EQUITY OFFERINGS, BROKERAGE SERVICES
The UA and 3WE have long left the exploration and colonization of their territories to the corporations.  However, sometimes a speculative mission is rejected by corporate and international sponsors.  That's where ISCSCIG comes in.  Pronounced “ice-sig,” this investment group funds high risk extrasolar capital ventures.  Each project is paired with industrialists, entrepreneurs, and business magnates willing to absorb any financial risks necessary in exchange for potential high gains.  While they sometimes fund shipping concerns, their main focus is the exploration and exploitation of natural resources along the Frontier and Outer Rim.

THE GEHOLGOD INSTITUTE (GI)

SCIENTIFIC ACADEMIA, TECHNOLOGICAL INNOVATION, XENOLOGICAL STUDIES
Based on Alexandria Colony in the ICSC, the Geholgod is a prestigious scientific international and intercorporate research institution that focuses on higher scientific principles.  A gathering of leading minds from all supernations, Geholgod is dedicated to the belief that research in the name of pure science is a worthwhile pursuit.  Their scientists have a keen interest in both exolife and humanity's possible extraterrestrial origins.  The Institute's xenological studies include xeno-linguistics, xeno-archaeological, anthropological, ethnomusicological, and xenobiological research.

WEYLAND-YUTANI CORPORATION (W-Y)

EXOPLANETARY TERRAFORMATION AND COLONIZATION, EXTRASOLAR MINING OPERATIONS, BIOLOGICAL AND TECHNOLOGICAL ENHANCEMENTS, SYNTHETIC SOLUTIONS
Like its predecessor Weyland Corp, Weyland-Yutani is the number one name in colonization and extrasolar mining operations.  Their prefab settlements and atmospheric processors dot the frontier and outer rim.  It's been estimated that Weyland-Yutani sponsors and supports about 63% of the Middle Heavens' mining and manufacturing colonies—and they have well equipped SEV teams searching well beyond the 20 parsec limit of human civilization in search of untold resources and scientific treasures.  Beyond colonial and expeditionary concerns, the company and its many subsidiaries are responsible for modern starship, computer, and hypersleep technologies, as well as bioweapons development

SEEGSON CORPORATION (SC)

COMPUTER GOVERNING SERVICES AND AFFORDABLE SERVICE SYNTHETICS, FORMERLY DEEP SPACE TERRESTRIAL AND SATELLITE COLONIZATION
Seegson aspired to be a discount Weyland Corp since its inception.  In the 2120s, the company made heavy investments in high operating cost deep space orbital platforms.  The company rushed to expand into space colonization via artificial satellite habitations.  Seegson simply missed the point of extrasolar colonization—settlers aren't looking to spend their lives in a metal bottle with tinny air and a confined environment—if they wanted that, they'd simply become space truckers.  Colonists are looking to tame a new world's land and transform air through terraforming.  Boarding a claustrophobic space station is a far cry from touching down on a new world and starting a new life.

Where Seegson went right was with their APOLLO mainframes and Working Joe androids—cost effective substitutes for Weyland-Yutani and Hyperdyne's MU/TH/UR system and full synthetics.  It would never have occurred to these cutting-edge technological industry leaders that a market for lower tech alternatives would be so viable.  Sales of this award-winning integrated AI system kept the company from completely going under after the Sevastopol disaster in 2137.  In 2151, Seegson sold several of its patents to the UPP's Norcom company—including unrealized specs for militarized Fighting Joe androids that have begun to see deployment on the frontlines of the frontier.

APOLLO and Joe systems continue to see employment on starships, space stations, and even ground installations to this day.  Seegson recently made advances into the colonization business once again, selling APOLLO and Working Joe systems as cost-effective mining colony management across the Frontier.  These systems are quite adept at handling planet-bound operations.  Unfortunately, the attacks of the enigmatic border bombers have put a damper on these activities as well.

HYPERDYNE CORPORATION (HC)

EXOPLANETARY COLONIZATION, SYNTHETICS, MINING, CYBERNETICS, AND WEAPONS DEVELOPMENT
Originally a synthetic maker, Hyperdyne exploded onto the scene when the original David designs and software were made open source by Weyland-Yutani.  Hyperdyne was instrumental in the forming of the Central Space Consortium, a conglomerate of corporations that eventually consolidated into the Independent Core System Colonies.  Aside from their android designs, Hyperdyne is most known for its exploitation of the Hyades Cluster.

A series of resource rich worlds were discovered in the Hyades Cluster in the 2110s.  Hyperdyne was quick to colonize these worlds and profit from the hard labor of their far away colonists.  When the company failed to care for those colonies in the 2150s, the disgruntled colonists defected to the UPP.  The resulting conflict between the Colonial Marines and the Progressive People's Army eventually ended with Hyperdyne's forced withdrawal from the cluster.  Facing the ramifications of one bad decision after another, Hyperdyne was bought out by Weyland-Yutani and made a subsidiary.  Eventually the company was able to buy itself out from W-Y and reformed as the Hyperdyne Corporation.  Once again, a major force in colonization, Hyperdyne has backed the UNISC's much publicized Great Mother Mission to gain instant market legitimacy.

OMNI-TECH RESOURCES (OTR)

EXOPLANETARY COLONIZATION, TERRAFORMING TECHNOLOGIES, AND MINING CONCERNS
One of the early corporations to get their start out amongst the stars, this company's original mission statement was to scout distant worlds for resources to send back to an overcrowded and polluted Earth.  Omni-Tech Resources developed several key components in Weyland Corp's atmospheric processors in the 2030s.  When Weyland tried to buy them out, they refused—and soon found their data banks wiped in a cyber-attack reminiscent of the Arceon cult.  All patents and records of Omni-Tech's achievements were lost and Weyland soon filed for similar claims for suspiciously similar tech.  Backed by an industrialist billionaire, Omni-Tech nonetheless refused to give up.  They developed more practical but time-consuming terraforming techniques like atmospheric algae blooms and geothermal taps.  They operate several domed colonies on poisonous or airless worlds that will take hundreds of years to support human life.

GEMINI EXOPLANET SOLUTIONS (GES)

MINERAL RESEARCH AND EXTRACTION TECHNIQUES
A research company specializing in mineral extraction, Gemini develops alternative mining methods for gas giant, comet, and terrestrial asteroid-based operations.  Gemini's innovative research under a Geholgod grant developed the technology to harvest plasma from comets, dying stars, and black holes.  Gemini has worked with Weyland-Yutani, Seegson, and the Kelland Mining Company.

KELLAND MINING COMPANY AND CONSORTIUM (KMCC)

DEEP SPACE PROSPECTING, OIL AND BULK-MINERAL MINING OPERATIONS
A merger of 21st century Earth's major oil companies into a single megacorp, the Kelland Mining Company is the epitome of Big Oil in space.  A major deep space mining consortium which makes use of large Deep Space Orbital Mining Vessels, transporting mined materials via drop shuttles, cargo lifters, and orbital tethers.  Expanding to rare minerals in the 2140s, Kelland purchased many of Seegson's defunct space station-colonies and transformed them into deep space mining platforms.  Famous Kelland-built and/or operated stations include the DSMO Marion trimonite mining station orbiting LV-178, the refit Ariarcus Inc.  oil refinery station at Kruger 60Am, and Weyland-Yutani's DSMO Erebos 01 Plasma Trawling Platform in the 26 Draconis system.  The Kelland Mining Company and Consortium also sponsors the Kelland Panhellanic Prospectors (see below).

KELLAND'S PANHELLENIC PROSPECTORS

Backed by the Kelland Mining Company and Consortium, the Kelland Panhellanic Prospectors is a masonic-like organization of freelance wildcatters that can trace their origins back to self-made oil tycoon Daniel P.V.  Kelland during the oil rush of the 19th century.  Members of the Panhellanic Prospectors are often called free wildcatters.  

Free wildcatters are looking for the next big Frontier find.  They operate out of small freighters, scout ships, tractors, and mining equipment leased to them by Kelland.  When a free wildcatter discovers a rich vein of ore or deposit of oil and signs the find over to the Kelland Mining Company and Consortium, they receive shares just as a colony's wildcatters would.  The benefit of being a free wildcatter is the ability to explore and move on as one sees fit.  Under the consortium's bylaws, Kelland has first right of refusal to any claim.  If Kelland decides to pass, free wildcatters are able to sell their finds to other companies.  All external deals are to be negotiated through Kelland itself—allowing the company to receive a portion of the profits even if they pass.

Working both sides of the fence, Kelland saw a substantial profit gain during the recent Oil Wars.  Their manufactured supply and demand strategies have transformed them into one of Weyland-Yutani's major colonial competitors.

NEW ALBION PROTECTORATE (NAPRO)

A growing collective of self-declared autonomous colonies under the protection of New Albion, NAPRO was founded in July of 2186 when that colony's local government seceded from their supernational and corporate controllers.  Located in the Weyland Isles Sector (The Frontier), the Protectorate has exploited the colonial unrest caused by the Oil, Frontier, and Colony Wars, prompting colonies who have been abandoned during these conflicts to follow suit in a move the media calls the 3WExit.  Led by sector Prime Minister Maurice Pepper and quietly funded over the past decade by wealthy 3WE families, the movement is gaining traction and is beginning to spread from the Weyland Isles Sector to the Outer Rim.  The longevity of the Protectorate is uncertain—it wouldn't take much for the 3WE to retaliate with nuclear strikes.  However, it's important to note that a similar secession from the 3WE in 2147 by Alexandria Colony led to the '51 New Deal and the formation of the Independent Core System Colonies.

NAPRO has their own military forces—former Royal Marine Commandos disgruntled over the 3WE constantly bending to corporate demands.  They also claim to have developed a new weapon—something their Prime Minister refers to as Project X.  While unconfirmed, UNISC fears Project X is a biological weapon—one derived from the pathogen deployed on innocent colonies by the as-of-yet unidentified border bombers who have plagued the frontier for the past two years.  Some have gone so far as to wonder if the border bombers and the Protectorate are one and the same, but that is pure conjecture.  If NAPRO is behind the bombings, they have manufactured the civil turmoil that they now take advantage of—and can be sure to face opposition from UNISC and all its member supernations.

“Jacob had this dream of building a cabin on a new world—like the old pioneers on Earth.  A cabin next to a lake […].  I mean a real cabin, made of real wood.”
—Katherine “Dani” Daniels, USCSS Covenant



You probably think you know what it means to be a frontier colonist.  You have to be the bravest of the brave to voyage across the darkness of space, tread on virgin soil, and forge new frontiers from untouched planets.  You have to be willing to risk the lives of your family with the determination that what lies ahead, despite the dangers and the struggle to come, will be better than what went before.  There is so much uncertainty in this new chapter you are writing in your life.

What a story you will have to tell.

Where did you get that idea, a recruitment brochure? That's all romanticized bullshit.  The truth is you've gone and bitten off more than you can chew.  Sure, the risks are real—but the rewards? Few and far between.  Your best chance at surviving your first year on some newly chartered hellhole is to make sure you have the skills and know-how to hold your own when the shit hits the fan.

How you go about creating your frontier character is covered in detail in this chapter, although you should follow the standard method of PC creation, unless instructed otherwise.  In a Frontier Colonist campaign, you will be playing ordinary folks doing extraordinary things.  Your PCs can be of any career they please, as every career will be needed out on the frontier somewhere.  But under each career there are many possible jobs that need taking care of—see below for guidance over your career options.  Your player characters will have a common background or bond that brought them together in the first place, whether they are crewing an exploration or prospecting outfit, or setting out to start a new life on a virgin planet.

While life on the frontier for the average Joe is all about work, work and more work, there are lots of opportunities to be had, claims to be made, and dollars to be earned.  The naive amongst your colonization team can even expect what they'd call an adventure or two—something the grizzled old veterans simply call hazard pay.  You'll earn that by not only exploring the cosmos and being the first to take a plunge into a new unknown, but by doing your fucking job—building worlds and the political and personal infighting that goes with it.  After all, this hard work isn't for nothing.

CREATING YOUR FRONTIER COLONIST

To create your Frontier Colonist, follow the character generation rules in Chapter 2 of the ALIEN RPG, with a couple of additional things to think about.  So, grab a character sheet, a pencil and don't forget to decide what bond or connection draws your PCs together (below), consider the new frontier careers of Wildcatter and Entertainer when you make your choice, and remember every career has a greater selection of starting talents to choose from (New Talents).

FRIENDS ON THE FRONTIER

Surviving on the frontier isn't just down to your skill, resilience, and resourcefulness—to thrive you need teamwork.  Your players should consider what bond or connection their characters already have that draws them together, bearing in mind the style and direction of the campaign they will be playing (see Chapter 6).  This doesn't confer any mechanical advantage, but adds role-playing color and gives the players a common connection and motivation:

FAMILY: The PCs are all members of a family that has moved to the frontier to start a new life.  And you thought holidays with your in-laws were bad.  Good luck with that.

OLD FRIENDS: There is some old bond, from childhood, or a previous career, or just formed on the long journey to the frontier, that binds them together as a group.  Don't count on that, however—best friends stay besties until there's only one spacesuit left.

CULTURAL TIES: They may have never met before, but the PCs' same social or cultural heritage or place of origin draws them together in the bewildering loneliness of space.

CO-WORKERS: The PCs all work for the same company, where they become fast friends, a fellowship they can rely on.  Or so the company handbook says.

PROFESSIONAL GUILD: The PCs are part of a workers' collective or union and have work together for the good of the little people.  Afterall, someone's got to pay for your union rep's next vacation.

YOUR CAREER

All the character careers from the core rulebook can be adapted for a frontier specialism—this section offers guidance to make those careers your own out on the frontier.  Alternatively, there are two new frontier careers that might interest you, the Wildcatter and the Entertainer (). As the range of jobs needed on the frontier is so vast and varied, we have listed two extra talents for each of the traditional careers.  When selecting your career talent, you can choose from these extra talents as well as those listed in the core rulebook, but you still only get one talent to start with.  You also get an extra gear option on top of those in the core rulebook, but only get to choose a total of two.

COLONIAL MARINE

You can be a colonial marine out on the frontier, but typically that means you're a grunt kept ready to stand on the line, offer disaster relief, or play “my nuke is bigger than yours” with a foreign power's overambitious border force.  On the frontier, the locals are usually looking for muscle rather than firepower, creating opportunities for a former marine to cross over into the private sector.  Colonial security gigs are always available, but they're poorly paid for the perilous risks you're expected to take.  Mercenary work is there if you can find it, but you'd better have something unique to offer—security can usually do what you can, and they are cheaper.  Finally, there's always an out-of-the-way maximum-security prison that needs guarding.

  • FRONTIER TALENTS: Bodyguard, Hard Hitter
  • FRONTIER GEAR: Stun baton OR Handcuffs

COLONIAL MARSHAL

The Company is all about law and order on the frontier, as long as it's their law and order.  That's what the Company heavies are for: leaning on people, making sure the marshal makes the right call, that sort of thing.  But also, if you know the law you can break the law—criminals and corrupt officials can be found everywhere.  Wildcatters aren't the only people heading into the deep of space looking for things, for the deep of space is a good place to hide.  The law won't be going too far out so there's always a good trade for an enterprising bounty hunter or private investigator.

  • FRONTIER TALENTS: Menacing, Tough
  • FRONTIER GEAR: Bounty hunter / investigator license OR Handcuffs

COMPANY AGENT

The Company keeps tabs on everything going on wherever it may be.  You might be a roving trouble-shooter or auditor looking to find gaps in the books or wasteful people to cull from the salary roll.  Your word is Company policy out on the frontier, and you can hire and fire on a whim.  But be careful you don't fire the wrong guy, or you might be the next one getting fired.  Or maybe you're the colony claims agent, the one who has to rubber stamp every stake and claim made on your dusty little world.  Can be a nice way to make some unofficial bonuses.  But then there are those, as slick as company executives but who don't work for the Company: fixers who can get whatever you want, but at a price; union agitators striving for the good of the workers; or rivals trying to horn in on the Company's success.

  • FRONTIER TALENTS: Born Leader, Watchful
  • FRONTIER GEAR: Expedition fatigues OR Computer terminal

KID

They used to say that the frontier's no place for a kid.  Now they've got families there having them.  Frontier life is hard on a kid—there's no playing video games all day.  Everyone is part of the community, and everyone needs to be useful.  You could be an apprentice learning a trade, maybe wildcatting—exciting times sitting in a tractor and waiting.  Or maybe a geologist—sifting through dust and rock looking for hell knows what.  What about the idea of mining? You get to play with dynamite! Then there's the whizz-kid who does nothing but can hack into everything, and that quiet kid who knows every twist and turn of the place.  Just make sure you stay two steps ahead of the adults.  This way when things go belly up, you'll have a running head start.

  • FRONTIER TALENTS: Fast Reflexes, Stealthy
  • FRONTIER GEAR: Patched-up M316 Motion Tracker OR Fake Class-2 rating Powerloader license

MEDIC

On the frontier, you have to stand on your own two feet, even when you've got a fungal infection and a compound femoral fracture.  Out here, a good paramedic is like gold dust.  So much so that a really good one can write their own check or be fast tracked to the position of Medical Officer—which means better pay, better quarters, and better rations.  Also, keep in mind that the stresses of frontier life don't suit everybody—too many colonists find themselves coping at the bottom of a bottle or kicking back with a handful of pills.  The more progressive companies out there are aware of the problem and have started employing full time psychologists or counselors to look after folks at the raggedy end of space.

  • FRONTIER TALENTS: Group Psychology, Counselor
  • FRONTIER GEAR: 3 PDTs for your patients OR Cold weather parka

OFFICER

You might be the champion of the people, giving the working stiff a voice against the Company.  A union steward, a rabble-rousing firebrand or a community worker, you listen to the voice of the unheard, stand up for the rights of the downtrodden, and can bring people together to speak with one voice.  Never forget—this world was made for everyone, and not just some company fat cats.  Unless of course, you're the Colonial Supervisor or on the Command Team, and you are one of the fat cats.

  • FRONTIER TALENTS: Talk Their Language, Hothead
  • FRONTIER GEAR: Megaphone OR Unofficial access keycard to your boss's office

PILOT

Nothing happens on the frontier without you.  You don't need to be a flashy military flyboy pulling bat-turns to do well out here.  Flying a skiff hauler, running the low-orbital taxi or flying search and rescue are all proper jobs on the frontier.  You might be a tractor runner, the first to explore new places, right after the ‘Catters have done the dangerous bit, of course! And if you get to fly one of those big Magellan exploration ships? Now that's the job you want.

  • FRONTIER TALENTS: Hold Your Nerve, EVA Specialist
  • FRONTIER GEAR: A box of excellent (but probably illegal) cigars OR M8A2 Thermal boots

ROUGHNECK

Out on the frontier you get things done.  Maintenance and factory work might be menial and dead-end, but mining hands are skilled people, even if they do call you “drill jockey.” Demolition experts even more so, even if they call you “powder monkeys.” People gotta breathe, and planetary engineers keep the Atmo Processors running.  And people gotta eat, and you might be the farmer to feed them.  It's a rare colony that takes you out across rolling fields under a wide blue sky, so you might be farming bugs or fungi, or growing hydroponics.  People are relying on you to turn the minerals of the soil, the compounds in the atmosphere and the waste of the other colonists into something edible.

  • FRONTIER TALENTS: Husbandry, Jury-rig
  • FRONTIER GEAR: Harvester wrangling equipment OR Daihotai 8x8 Tractor

SCIENTIST

There is an abundance of wonder just waiting to be discovered, and you're going to be the first to find it.  Whether it's chasing the weather on a new planet, tracking the local tremors, analyzing alien critters or hunting for the fossils of ancient life, you scrabble to reveal the hidden secrets of the cosmos.  You might be independent, on the payroll of the Company or contracted by a wealthy client for purposes they truly keep to themselves.  Your drive for discovery will be for the good of humankind, and with a bit of luck, your bank balance.

  • FRONTIER TALENTS: Focus, Stoic
  • FRONTIER GEAR: Expedition fatigues OR Heavy safari pack

PERSONAL AGENDAS ON THE FRONTIER

Unlike Personal Agendas in Cinematic play, which change as the scenario progresses from act to act, Agendas in Campaign play are more enduring.  They are longer term personal objectives, desires, ambitions, or character traits.  They drive PCs' behavior and give them something to aspire to or a yardstick to be measured by.

But no one—and I mean no one—heads to the frontier without a good reason.  Just getting there alive is an achievement in itself these days.  Players should be encouraged to consider Personal Agendas that reflect their reasons for being on the frontier.  For some it may be as simple as having a job, a way to make a living and keep the credit companies off their back, while for others it might be the culmination of years of dreaming, of summoning the courage to up sticks and make a completely new life.

If you need some inspiration, you can choose an Agenda from those listed with your PC's career.  Alternatively, you can choose or roll on the table below to see what drives your PC to the edge of space.
