Frontier colonists are intrepid, courageous, hard-working, and ready to face the unknown in the name of progress, or for a new life, or just for the money.  Some are working stiffs, running expeditions at the behest of their corporate masters, while others are out-and-out explorers, charting the depths of space.  For these PCs their life is on the move, and their ship will be their foundation—it's where they live, it keeps them safe, it enables their passion to sail forbidden seas, for only those who risk going too far can possibly know how far they can go.  Other frontier colonists are just that, colonists—the men and women who by sheer graft make a planet a home.  For them, their colony and home planet will be their foundation—it's where they live, it keeps them safe, it enables their passion to build a place to call home, for the greatest oak was once just an acorn that held its ground.  This chapter gives you guidance for your frontier colonist campaign, whether it be focused on exploration, colonization, or both at the same time.

THE CAMPAIGN SETTING

By definition, a frontier colonist campaign takes place on, or beyond, the frontier.  But while the space you are breaking is pristine and untouched by human hands, you will never entirely escape the long arm of Weyland-Yutani's, or the Extrasolar Colonial Administration's, bureaucracy.

SETTLEMENT CLASSIFICATIONS

There are three classifications routinely used to define the types of settlement found across human space.  So-called “nucleated” colonies are found close to well-established trade routes like the Delos-Earth run, Thesus-Earth run, and the Gauntlet—a route established between Anchorpoint Station and Sutter's World.  These settlements tend to be busy and well-connected trading hubs and interstellar crossroads for explorers, colonists, and space truckers.  Along political and interstellar boundaries you find the “linear” colonies.  They often serve as military or intelligence outposts, political and diplomatic facilities, or forward staging posts, like Rim colony, that stand on the precipice of the unknown.  Finally, there are the “scattered” colonies.  Usually found in newly discovered regions of space before trade routes are formally established, these young colonies are few and far between across a particular sector.  The Weyland Isles and the long abandoned Far Spinward Colonies are examples of this kind of settlement.

SHAKE AND BAKE

A terraforming colony where planetary engineers set up atmospheric processing plants and keep them running while they make the air breathable, a process that takes decades.  Once the atmosphere is right, the Company can make what they will of the place.  Hadley's Hope on LV-426 in the Zeta II Reticuli system was a “shake and bake” colony.

SETTLEMENT TYPES & COLONY MISSIONS

Peter Weyland declared over one hundred and fifty years ago that humankind would hold dominion over the stars.  He pledged to create air where there was none and shelter humanity from the rigors of space.  Nine decades after his passing, Weyland-Yutani continues to uphold those ideals, employing unorthodox methods to create new human settlements and colonies on inhospitable worlds.  These colonies are all established to serve one or more Missions.

Terraforming: The planet needs fixing to make it suitable for long-term human habitation.  “Shake and bake” colonies can be hard to work in, but not as tough as working in an “extra crispy” colony (see the sidebars below).  But the satisfaction of building a new world from something hostile is a great reward.  

Research: The planet has an abundance of scientific opportunities, from rare geology and exotic compounds to the intricacies of its primitive life.  It may be that the local solar neighborhood is full of opportunity too, from a unique sun to nearby planets and stars that are just begging to be studied— and turned into dollars for the Company.  

Prospecting: The planet scored high on the orbital prospecting surveys and dip-sampling of the surface, and someone is sure there's a treasure trove of marketable goodies just waiting to be mined, drilled, fracked, scraped, harvested or just collected.

Prison: You have to put those career criminals, those dangers to society, somewhere—preferably where no one will ever find them.  

Mining & Refining: Ideal for industrial exploitation and production, there may be raw materials just waiting to be gathered, or unlimited sources of renewable energy—an ideal position to harvest solar power, or endless geothermal activity under the colonists' very feet.  This type of mission includes the so-called “giffy popped” colonies (see Giffy Popped).  

New Frontier: This planet is ideal for human life, and it would be a crime not to settle upon it.  Its beauty needs to be explored—there may be little prospecting potential, but there are riches of the heart and soul, as well as of the corporate bank balance.

Comms Relay: A government or corporate facility set up as part of the deep space network, or perhaps a covert comms outpost supporting the military.  Either way, it's a valued colony that needs to run like clockwork.  

Military: A military base, staging facility, or forward mounting post.  It could be enormous, with frequent comings and goings of ships and troops, or it could be a small, covert facility to support special forces.  Whatever it may be, these “armed and hammered” colonies (see Armed And Hammered) will have government and corporate backing all the way.  

Farming: A planet may be a warm and benign place, but it doesn't have to be.  Adding in a plethora of wheat fields and rows of corn, or possibly fishing stocks or insect harvests, could make this place an interstellar breadbasket.  

Corporate or Government HQ: The powers that be can't keep a close tab on everything from offices in the Sol System, no matter how palatial they may be.  From huge regional bases to tiny off-the-grid research facilities and covert headquarters, the corporations and governments are out to make sure their influence is potent.

EXTRA CRISPY

These colonies are necessary when a planet's toxic atmosphere must be burned away before an atmosphere processor can be introduced.  While those living on “extra crispy” colonies grow immune to the nasty odor, visitors often remark that everything smells like burnt cat hair.

GIFFY POPPED

Pioneered by scientist Edmund C.  Giff, these settlements are the opposite of “shake and bake” colonies, where a high resource planet is made less hospitable to gain fast access to its mineral assets.  “Giffy popped” settlements are often controlled from orbital platforms that oversee a newly devastated world.  While unsubstantiated, rumors persist that ICSC's colony Volcus in the Heske 337 system is this type of colony (see Heske 337 System in the core rulebook), after a rogue moon was crashed into the world to unlock its potential.

ATMOSPHERE PROCESSING

Terraforming techniques may have started with big machines pumping out friendly gasses, but there are other ways to make your new home more hospitable.  The earliest model, the Weyland Atmosphere Processing Plant, was the gold-standard of the day.  Built with no expense spared, these monster machines cleaned up Earth's soupy smog before being used off-world for the earliest colonies.  The later Weyland-Yutani Atmospheric Processors did the same thing but with a lower dollar price tag.  Who knew cutting corners and skimping on safety features would be a bad idea for a beast with a giant fusion reactor at its heart? But, despite the concerns, these processors worked, and were ubiquitous during the colonization wave of the 2150s.  An even cheaper option is the Atmosphere Pressurizer, used to boost the atmosphere rather than clean it for humans to breathe, often enough for mining or industrial colonies.  The current pinnacle of Weyland-Yutani's atmo processing technology is the Weyland-Yutani / Seegson Prefab Automated Atmospheric Processor Module.  Fully automated, from planetfall to set-up and operation, these self-contained behemoths are the epitome of fire-and-forget, with Working Joes doing all the heavy lifting under the supervision of a computer mainframe.

Other techniques are available, the primary competitor being the Omni-Tech Atmospheric Bloom Deployment Probe.  A network of probes dumps artificially augmented xeno-cyanobacteria into the upper atmosphere, where they consume carbon dioxide and other unhelpful gasses, converting them into good gasses, most commonly oxygen.  It takes decades, but then so do Weyland-Yutani's metal monsters.

ARMED AND HAMMERED

Placed for strategic or political purposes, “armed and hammered” colonies go where they are needed, not where it makes sense to settle, and are often on inhospitable rocks incapable of supporting an atmosphere.  These settlements are frequently built below ground, using geothermal spikes called Deep Nails to tap the core to power the colony.  Settlers who live on these moons claim there's nothing a little elbow grease and a box of Deep Nails won't fix.

CAMPAIGN STYLES

Out on the frontier there are two main campaign styles—explorer campaigns, stories that see your PCs break the uncharted depths of space, and colonist campaigns, stories that see your PCs break the ground of a strange new world.  Of course, there's nothing to say your campaign can't involve both.

EXPLORER CAMPAIGNS

“Come join the great United American adventure! Three meals a day, a ship to call home, fair wages for all.  Make your fortune and see the open skies of the cosmos.  Opportunity awaits you sir—opportunity awaits!”

—UA RECRUIT MASTER, PLAZA DE LA CONSTITUCIÓN,
MEXICO CITY

Explorer campaigns are mobile stories that allow the PCs to roam where they will in search of new places, new discoveries, and new experiences.  As such their ship will be a key focus for them.  Use the rules in the core rulebook to design the PCs' ship (SPACECRAFT BASICS) or choose from the existing designs (SPACESHIPS OF 2183 AD in the core rulebook), remembering that even if they don't own this vessel outright (or at all) this bucket of nuts and bolts is still their home.

There are many reasons why a group of PCs would call themselves explorers but what you're looking for may well depend on your paymasters.  Ships are expensive so there's a good chance you'll have a wealthy government, corporation or, if you're really unlucky, an obsessed individual sponsoring you.  You could be searching the heavens for potential colony sites, surveying planet after planet in the quest for an Earth 2.0 or seeking the clues to exotic lifeforms and those civilizations that may have come before.  You might be on the hunt for salvage, for there's plenty of it out there, and not quibble too much over how legal that salvage might be—after all, one carved-up hold of metal looks much like another.  You could be on a personal mission of discovery, grasping for the meaning of life, or just the next big find that will satisfy the grasping company executives back home (and maybe make you rich into the bargain).  Perhaps it's just the unknown that draws you, like a moth to a flame, to dive into the vast darkness of space and see what's there.

But whatever you're searching for, an explorer's life will tell stories of revelation, for everywhere you go you will be breaking new ground.  Along with that come stories of hardship and survival in the cold of space, of the tensions and rivalries in your crew and of both the wonders and horrors of discovery.  Exploration is about being the first—the first to unearth that treasure or lay that claim, to uncover the secrets of the cosmos and clues of the past.  It's about beating your rivals and having them know it was you who beat them, making scientific discoveries or simply being the first to gaze on that pristine vista in its purest beauty.  It's about facing the dangers of the cosmos and coming out on top—but never forget that the cosmos doesn't owe you a damn thing.

COLONY CAMPAIGNS

“The journey of a thousand light years begins with the first step.  Take that step with us, to a new world, a new home, a new adventure! Dare to live the life you've always wanted!”

—WEYLAND CORPORATION
ADVERTISING CAMPAIGN

A frontier colony campaign revolves around the colony and the planet where the PCs are putting down roots.  You can find rules in the Appendix: Building Your Own Better World () to randomly create star systems and planets for your PCs to colonize, as well as rules for building your colony and tracking its growth and progress throughout your campaign.

As colony campaigns are focused on one central location, that location has to be intriguing, full of challenge and mystery, full of potential and prospects, full of danger.  The planet itself is a character in this story—its sights and sounds, its smells, its personality, and its moods.  The environment should be an unpredictable thing of beauty, or wonder, or threat—or all three.  It should challenge the PCs and the colony in some way and be an ever-present influence in the campaign.

Colonies are expensive endeavors, and someone will want something for that investment.  The primary purpose, or mission, of the colony will drive the life of the colony, if not always the story that your PCs will be playing through.  But a campaign set at a colony on a virgin planet can tell stories of hardship and survival, planetary exploration, prospecting, and scientific breakthrough (sometimes beneficial, sometimes neutral, occasionally hostile).

It might also bring the chance to hit the bigtime and make the killer discovery that not only has the PCs looking at a future of wealth and luxury but has their rivals casting an envious—and devious—eye in their direction.  Closer to home, a colony will harbor tales of your family's dreams and the strife that comes with them, of the rivalries and competition for promotion and claims not honored, industrial exploitation, of the Company keeping the workers down and production up, of political infighting, intrigue and sabotage.

COLONY CAMPAIGNS “WEST MARCHES” STYLE

A colony campaign will have a cast of at least several dozen characters who call this place home, possibly many more.  As such a colony campaign is an ideal opportunity for a GM to run a “West Marches” style game.  This style of roleplaying allows for a cast of player characters beyond the usual four or five, up to ten or even more.  Each scenario or session only involves a handful of those PCs, and the cast “on screen” will change from story to story.  This way a GM with many players can involve everyone in the game.

EXPEDITIONS

There's no end of expeditions to be played out in a frontier colonist campaign—even before your PCs come across a Xenomorph, Abomination or Engineer relic. Here are notes on just a few.

SUPPLY AND CARGO RUNS

That cargo doesn't move itself, and a jobbing crew of would-be explorers needs to make ends meet somehow.  Those fringe outposts always need more of just about everything to get by.  But what is that cargo? Maybe something illegal has been stashed within those crates of tools and spare parts.  The PCs might be aware of it.  Or not.  It could be dangerous.  It could be deadly.  Who stashed it there and why? And what about their destination? Bad things happen to good colonies all the time, and perhaps the PCs arrive to find that things are not how they expected them to be.  The place could be inundated by terrible weather - dust, water, or something even worse flooding the place.  There may have been political upheaval and their great rivals and enemies are now in charge.  Or maybe the place is deserted, an interstellar Marie Celeste.

SALVAGE OPS

The PCs might be paid-up salvagers working for a corporation or government, cleaning up space debris and recycling it into W-Y dollars.  They could be independent salvagers-for-hire, freelancers doing others' dirty work.  Or our crew of explorers might just happen across a dead hulk, slowly spinning in the depths of space, and choose to take the chance for a quick profit—more scavengers than salvagers.  There are many secrets out there in the vastness of space.  Why are they being directed to salvage that ship in that bit of space? How come that ship became little more than scrap in the first place? Salvage operations might seem an easy way to make a quick buck, but the old saying “where there's muck there's brass” works in reverse too—“where there's brass there's muck.” Who knows what discoveries lurk in the dark corners of cold and dead ships, and what secrets they keep?

SLOPPY JOES

A “sloppy joe” colony is a Seegson sponsored settlement that could be supporting any colony mission.  An APOLLO mainframe and a legion of Working Joe androids are sent in first, to set up the initial settlement while the colonists are still en route.  Unfortunately, unsupervised Joe work is often shabby and lacking in human ingenuity, frequently creating additional headaches for the soon to arrive colonists.

EXPLORATION

The bread and butter of an exploration ship, the possibilities are endless.  The PCs may be exploring systems looking for something specific—a certain kind of rare mineral or ore, extrasolar life forms, or a perfect location for their rich sponsor to set up a religious retreat far from the reach of the unforgiving orthodoxy back on Earth.  But exploration is also the bread and butter for settlers on a new colony—there's a whole new planet to explore, with high mountain ranges, cave systems, plains and jungles of indigenous flora and fauna.  To keep the colony alive, they may need to find new water sources, or ways to generate energy, or native sources of food.  Identifying the variety of complex life is important too, especially if that life thinks their children would make a tasty snack.  But exploration of even a dead world is full of opportunity—has anyone been here before, and if so, why? What did they leave behind? What if those remains aren't human?

PROSPECTING

There's money to be made in the dirt and the PCs are paid to find it.  Prospecting expeditions might be speculative—survey a star system or planet and see what you can find that'll make you money, (and maybe you'll find more than you bargained for).  Others will be targeted—the PCs are paid to look into reports of concentrated ore/minerals/natural gasses/exotic compounds at a certain place and paid to be the first to find it.  Other prospecting teams might be racing them, and who knows what lengths they (or the PCs) might go to, to ensure the find is theirs and theirs alone.  But all may not be as it seems.  The information leading them to the assets might be wrong, either by honest error or deliberate misinformation.  Why might that be? What trap are the PCs walking into? Their paymasters could know there's something else there, a facility or outpost, and want a band of innocent ‘prospectors' to stumble across it, to stir up that wasps' nest and watch the fallout.

SEARCH & RESCUE

Those damn colonists and space truckers always need saving from something, usually themselves.  And it's not always right to send the Colonial Marines to every colony that loses contact with the Network.  There aren't that many Marines to go around these days, what with the Frontier War and all.  So commercial Search & Rescue outfits make a living doing the work that the USCMC can't, or can't be bothered to, do.

The PCs may be one such outfit, receiving commissions to rush to the rescue.  Colonies lose contact, or have a disaster, accident or disease outbreak that requires professional help.  Ships go missing on the frontier, and wealthy parents will pay to get their spoiled, wayward kid back home.  And the war, of course, leaves many adrift and crying out for help.  The PCs' colony, or a ship of explorers, might just be closest when they hear the desperate distress calls of those who have run into trouble.

SCIENTIFIC FIELD-TRIPS

Any colony worth its salt will examine, identify, and exploit the scientific opportunities their planet offers.  Scientific field trips should be a common occurrence on any new world, trekking across the terrain to find underwater caves filled with exotic gasses and a bio-diverse world beyond any xeno-biologist's wildest dreams, or an archipelago of tiny islands with a complex web of insect, plant and animal life, one part of which is intensely valuable to the scientists, but all of which will defend that species.  The variety and complexity of the life and geology of the planet will be breath-taking, and perhaps hostile—sometimes openly with snarling teeth and fangs, other times more subtle and in the shadows.  Surely there's a use for some of this back in the Company weapons labs? The real crunch comes when the Company pen-pushers want to tear up the life to get to the rich ore beneath it, and the scientists stand in the way.

BREAKDOWN OR SABOTAGE

Mechanical systems break down, that's what they do and why Murphy's Law exists.  Some of these will be mission critical and need fixing fast.  The PCs might find that a cascade of failures hits their ship or colony, at the worst possible moment.  If they can't fix it themselves, they will be forced to call “Mayday! Mayday!” to save their lives, despite the exotic, dangerous, stolen or otherwise highly illegal cargo they may be carrying.  While every mechanic knows things break down, they don't always break down that badly, and with such a coincidence of failures—could it be sabotage? Who would want to sabotage the PCs, and why? What have they done to attract this hostility and what do they need to do to resolve it?

POLITICAL INFIGHTING

Life in the colonies is nothing if not political.  The PCs may think they have left the supernational and corporate rivalries light years behind, but they'd be dead wrong.  Even in colonies with only one sponsor, the internal politicking between rivals is intense.  Some people will always play that game, to climb the greasy ladder of promotion and success at the expense of anyone and everyone.  Some go as far as to kill to get ahead—perhaps not getting their own hands bloody or squeezing a trigger themselves, but by subtle manipulation and intrigue.  The PCs may find themselves entangled in a political struggle for control of the colony, or in the middle of a class war—the corporations squashing the workers under their bootheel, only for the workers to fight back through strike actions, go-slow campaigns, civil disobedience and sabotage (“sorry boss, it just don't work no more and the spares are ten parsecs away at Anchorpoint—pity...”).

CIVIL UNREST

At the sharp end of political infighting there's civil unrest: the workers have finally had enough of the Company working them like dogs for a pitiful share of the profits; the Company has finally had enough of recalcitrant plebs making their life difficult, slowing down production and—worst crime of all—bringing a red figure to the bottom line.  Where the PCs stand in this confrontation is down to them.  The Company will want the agitators rounded-up and put out of the way.  The Union leaders will be calling for help from afar, or for someone to get the Company leadership in a room where they can have a frank conversation, perhaps with a bright light and a little ‘physical persuasion' thrown in for good measure.  A contingent of UPP workers, claiming discrimination and harsh treatment, might call for help from the Motherland, and SOF troops are on their way to set things straight.

FAMILY SQUABBLES

Families—can't live with ‘em, can't shoot ‘em.  The PCs' families, living alongside them at their new colony, can cause all measure of bother.  They may get into trouble at home.  Perhaps they don't work hard enough and they're below quota, or they've been in a fight with a notorious bully-boy steward or local criminal.  They may get into trouble out and about.  One may be on a fieldtrip or survey mission and they lose contact, or their kid might have run away after being told they can't go out with their mates, and now they are nowhere to be found.  Or they may be the cause of trouble, disapproving of the PC's stand in a workers' dispute, or distrusting their new friend, that guy from the Company with super-white teeth and the smile that's just too friendly.  Whatever it may be, the PCs' families can be an important factor in their life at the colony.

RAIDERS

There are always raiders.  This might take the form of an actual physical raid, pirates landing near the colony, beating away any who try to interfere and stealing priceless ores, swiping livestock, or driving the colony's Daihotai tractors away.  The colony can track them and knows where they have holed-up to revel in their ill-gotten gains.  What to do about them? Expecting them to return, do the PCs look to mount a preemptive strike and show those bastards this colony is not for messing with? Do they ready whatever defenses they can muster to give them a bloody nose when they raid again? Or does the colony shrink in upon itself in fear, and hope these barbarians go away? Some raiders might take a more subtle approach, making a ‘deal' with the leadership that's little more than theft, a protection racket.  How will the PCs deal with this kind of strong-arm intimidation that comes with an outstretched hand of friendship and a smile?

GO HUNTING

The colony's home planet may have indigenous life that is big, fast, and perhaps dangerous.  It may be a pestilential species that needs to be culled to protect the colony's farms and people.  It may be docile but wary, and a great source of food to add spice to the drab protein cubes most colonists survive on.  It may be a predator, stalking the plains, jungles, and mountain ranges.  Whatever it is, the PCs are sent, or choose, to hunt it, for food, for safety, or for fun (despite the scowls of those back at the colony and their growls of disapproval).  They need to stalk and track their prey, but it proves more cunning than they realize.  Soon the hunters become the hunted.  Alternatively, the PCs may decide to confront those who wish to hunt these wondrous creatures for what they call “sport,” to track them down, disrupt the hunt and protect the animals, while they lobby back at home to make it illegal to hunt and kill just for fun.

CRIMINAL INVESTIGATIONS

Every colony has its police force—the Colonial Marshals in UA and Weyland-Yutani space, the Commissars for the UPP, corporate security elsewhere—and every colony has its share of crime.  The PCs could be a group of Marshals or Commissars, whose job is to investigate crimes and keep the peace.  A simple crime may be just that—an act of passion or anger between a few people with no wider ramifications—or it may be something deeper.  A murder might look like a simple mugging gone wrong, but the victim has secret links with a conspiracy that involves senior figures in the colony, or a corporation or rival supernation.  Or perhaps a series of grisly murders are attributed to the local wildlife, but the PCs suspect a beastly colonist is on the loose.

THE ENVIRONMENT

The planet is a key character in a frontier campaign, and its environment is an ever-present source of challenge for the PCs and the colony—the settlement is only ever one bad storm away from disaster.  Hurricanes, wildfires, tornadoes, and waterspouts may batter the colony.  The atmosphere, toxic and corrosive, might get into everything, causing leaks and breakdowns—perhaps the PCs have to convince the corporate leadership to get an Atmosphere Processor here, but what might they want in return? The earth itself might cause a problem, with volcanic shocks and quakes rattling the colony and sinkholes that swallow everything but reveal something hidden beneath the surface—an archaeological treasure, a nest of nasty creatures, a seam of gleaming gems, or an old human settlement that should never have been there in the first place.  The wider solar environment might be fraught with danger too, with radiation storms, meteor showers or sunspots bringing terror from above.  And then there is the life of the planet, that may pose a threat, a scientific opportunity, or the chance for some recreational hunting.

LIFE IN THE COLONY

Running a Colonist campaign using the rules in the Appendix: Building Your Own Better World brings two elements to the forefront—the choices made by the PCs and incidents that will affect the future of the colony.

During the colony's End of Cycle (The Colony Cycle) the players will choose policies, installations, and projects to help develop the colony. These initiatives are excellent story hooks.  For example: if the PCs choose the Free Enterprise policy but one of the sponsors is the UPP, this may be unpopular and cause tension.  If they choose the Cartels project, they are perhaps allowing organized crime disguised as business a foothold in the colony.  If they choose Lab-Grown Rations, this will displease the people, who have to eat that crappy mush instead of proper food, and lead to angry protests about how the colony is being run.  These are just some ideas from the Economy attribute alone.

Colony incidents, also identified during the End of Cycle, bring excellent story hooks for future scenarios.  The small earthquake that uncovers a seam of resources might also reveal something else, and more dangerous, at the same time.  The unexpected supply run, welcome surprise that it is, might not be an accounting error—perhaps something has been brought to the colony in secret.  Or a member of the command team falls ill and dies—is this just terrible luck, or is this the first move in a plan that threatens the colony? Make the most of these incidents and roll them into your campaign to add to the fun.

COLONY MISSIONS

The colony's primary mission may not be at the forefront of the PCs' thinking as they play through scenarios on their new world.  But these missions provide the backdrop for the entire Colonist campaign and should feature from time to time.  Perhaps there are suspicions that the atmosphere processor is being sabotaged, or the farming outfits are missing the Company-imposed quotas and new sources of food must be discovered, and fast.  Whatever it may be, keep the colony's primary mission as an overarching theme of the campaign.

MANAGING NPCS IN A COLONIST CAMPAIGN

A campaign set in a colony will come with a lot of NPCs.  Most of them will always be in the background, adding to the context and color of the game without needing a name or any stats.  There will be some, like the colony command team and notable members of the settlement, that will play a regular part in the campaign.  Some will be direct rivals to the PCs, especially if a player chooses to play a member of the command team or their PC is working to replace the NPC that is already in that job.  You should create these NPCs with personal objectives and motivations and play them according to those values.  Naturally these NPCs will only come “on screen” when they play a part in the story you're telling, but as key members of the colony they will be prominent in colony life, and it should feel like it in play.

CHALLENGES OF FRONTIER LIFE

There are many challenges that intrepid explorers and colonists will be forced to face, not least new conditions they may not have experienced before.

MINING OPERATIONS USING A “TAMED” HARVESTER

A Harvester is a terrible beast, a cross between a giant tardigrade and a huge worm that burrows through rock as easily as we move through air (see Harvesters in the core rulebook).  Uncontrolled, a Harvester is a mighty menace, but so-called “tamed” Harvesters have been used for years as “organic” aids to mining operations, using their great churning maws to grind up rock and sniff-out valuable minerals.  They are usually handled by two or more wranglers wielding giant electro-prods, nick-named “zappers.” These 5-meter-long devices apply electric shocks to a harness worn by the beast that amplifies the surge and makes the creature move in a desired direction (towards a rock face, say, where you want it to get grinding!).  As an extra safety measure the harness is fitted with an electrical charge and a remote detonation device—when detonated it will temporarily subdue the Harvester (for 2D6 Rounds), but you need to get within MEDIUM range to use it.  

Zappers are heavy and unwieldy bits of kit, requiring a STAMINA roll to use.  They are so tough to manage that you suffer a −3 modification unless you have the @UUID[Item.efRnCvck4q1CQn6X]{Husbandry} talent.  However, you gain +1 bonus die if the Harvester is wearing a harness.  The zapper has Power Supply 6 and requires a fast action (and a Power Supply roll) to prepare by building the electric charge, and a slow action (and another Power Supply roll) to attack.  

If the attack is successful, the wielder can make the Harvester stay still or move one zone of their choice.  If that direction is a solid object, the Harvester will use its grinding maw to chew it up.  If that direction runs the Harvester into a person that person suffers an immediate signature attack from the beast.  A failed attack with a zapper means the Harvester is free to act on its initiative.

THAT'S NOT IN THE MANUAL!

If anyone should be so foolish as to turn a zapper on a human target, they suffer the usual -3 modification for using it, unless they have the Husbandry talent.  The target also gains a +1 modification to their MOBILITY roll if they try to dodge the attack.  A successful zapper attack against a human delivers a signature effect—roll below.

ZAPPER EFFECTS @DRAW[RollTable.StJpVPTUfrrqdL05]{Zapper Effects}

 

D6

 

EFFECT

 

1

 

IT'S A DUD: The charge failed to build, and the attack is harmless.

 

2

 

MILD SHOCK: The zapper fires only a mild electrical discharge.  The target suffers an attack with eight Base Dice, Damage 1.

 

3

 

ELECTRIC BLAST: The discharge causes a shock that blows the target off their feet and throws them back into the next zone—the target takes a six Base Dice attack, Damage 1, and gains +1 STRESS LEVEL.

 

4

 

STUNNING SHOCK: The target suffers a ten Base Dice attack, Damage 1.  If any damage is done (ignore armor) they take just 1 point of damage but must make a STAMINA test.  If they fail they are stunned and cannot act until they succeed at a STAMINA test, made at the start of each Round.  +1 STRESS LEVEL.

 

5

 

LIGHTNING BLAST: The target suffers a huge shock attack with ten Base Dice, Damage 2.

 

6

 

KILLING CHARGE: The target immediately suffers two critical injuries regardless of whether or not they are Broken.

CONDITIONS

HYPOXIA: Hypoxia affects a PC when they are in a low oxygen environment (such as a toxic atmosphere or high altitude) and comes in three forms: mild, severe and extreme.  When suffering hypoxia, a PC must make a STAMINA roll or suffer one point of damage.  The frequency of the roll depends on the form of hypoxia being experienced: Mild is every Shift, Severe is every Turn, Extreme is every Round.  If you are Broken through this damage, you fall into a coma and must make a Death Roll every Turn until you die or are given oxygen to breathe.  

HEATSTROKE: When a PC suffers intense heat, they must make a heatstroke save, rolling STAMINA. If successful they can push through, but if they cannot escape the heat must roll for heatstroke again after one Turn or any strenuous activity.  If the roll is failed, the PC takes one point of damage.  While suffering from heatstroke they gain +2 STRESS LEVEL instead of one every time they push a roll.  The effects are removed after one Turn in a cool environment.  

GRAVITY DYSPRAXIA: Any PC operating in a gravity field half a G or more different from that which they are used to will immediately gain +1 STRESS LEVEL and suffer a −2 modification to all MOBILITY and CLOSE COMBAT rolls.  After a Shift in the new gravity, the PC makes a MOBILITY roll to see if they have acclimatized.  If they succeed, they no longer suffer the negative effect.  

MAKING A LIVING

In the world of ALIEN there are many currencies, from the supernational dollar, yen or yuen, to the widely accepted Weyland-Yutani (W-Y) dollar.  Feel free to make use of any or all of them.  But for most explorers and colonists on the frontier, slaving to earn a living under the yoke of the companies or governments, the W-Y dollar is the currency of choice.

Rates of pay for explorers and colonists on the frontier aren't much better than the average hired hand back home (see Communications on the Frontier in the core rulebook), but there's always the hope of the big find, or negotiating a better salary.  The one perk those on the frontier do get is the free—or at least cheap—accommodation, (a berth on their ship or habitation unit on the colony) and board (the crap that gets dished out as food, and other basic necessities).  These folks might get paid for time in hypersleep too if they're lucky.

WILDCATTING

Wildcatters make their living by prospecting, but prospecting is hard, lonely, and dangerous work, and it takes time.  A standard survey of 1,000 square km takes three weeks by ground or underwater, or one week by air, modified by the difficulty of the terrain, at your discretion.  Prospecting requires the wildcatter to make an OBSERVATION roll, with modifiers based on the regional potential (@UUID[RollTable.w1tCGjKMABWDeqDn]{13 - Resource Potential} @DRAW[RollTable.w1tCGjKMABWDeqDn]{Draw}).  A failed roll means they find nothing.  If successful they can roll on the Prospecting Finds table (below), adding +1 to the tens die for every success beyond the first.  Any find may be worth a finder's fee (in W-Y dollars, calculated by rolling D6, multiplying it by the value of the tens die from the finds roll, then multiply that figure by 10) or the PC can try to hold out and negotiate a better deal for a really tasty find.  Good luck with that!

PROSPECTING FINDS @DRAW[RollTable.JWMz1spWhuy62qjP]{Prospecting Finds}

 

D66 +
D10 MOD

 

PROSPECTING FINDS

 

11-26

31-36

41-46

51-52

 

Sandy silicon beds or salt flats.

 

53-54

 

Deep deposits of natural gas or oil.

 

55-56

 

Volcanic vents rich in sulphur and / or geothermal energy.

 

61-62

 

A supply of underground water, frozen springs or aquifers, clean and fresh.

 

63-64

 

Extensive fossil deposits of long-lost life.

 

65-66

 

A deep basin of clay deposits with gemstones and diamonds.

 

71-72

 

Meadows filled with new plant-life that has medical, industrial or agricultural possibilities OR deposits or vents rich in noble gases (argon, helium, radon, xenon, etc).

 

73-74

 

A huge underground vein of precious metals (gold, platinum, titanium, uranium, etc).

 

75-76

 

The gray stain on that rock is a microbial form of life you have never seen before.

Previously undetected and unknown form of complex alien life OR extensive fossil deposits of long-lost life.

 

83-84

 

Ruined remains of something you can't identify but it doesn't look natural...  An archaeologist's dream find.

 

85+

 

Partially buried remains of an old or ancient spaceship.

UNRULY “PUPS”

The Weyland-Yutani Parameter Uplink Spectrograph Mapping Device—usually just called “Pups”— is a highly expensive and powerful bit of reconnaissance kit.  A successful COMTECH roll is required to operate it, which covers getting it to the right location and running a scan of the target zone.  It can detect lifeforms, atmospheric conditions, toxins and more.  A failed roll means the Pups didn't send a coherent response, but it can be tried again.  Pups run on power, with 5 Power Supply when fully charged.  Each time it's used it must make a Power Supply roll, so a PC might want to be careful if their Pups' juice is getting low—losing it in the middle of nowhere might be an expensive mistake!

BUSTED COMPRESSION SUITS

Compression suits, by their very nature, are sealed environments for working in the vacuum of space, underwater or where you don't dare risk breathing the atmosphere.  When the wearer takes damage there is a risk that the suit itself will be damaged too and may spring a leak.  However, this isn't guaranteed—the attack may have simply battered or bruised the victim, rather than penetrated the suit to hurt them.

Every time a character wearing a compression suit takes damage, roll for the suit's Armor Rating again.  If the roll scores at least one   , the suit has not been damaged.  However, if the roll fails to gain any   (or had no armor protection in the first place) the suit may be damaged and may be breached.  In that case roll on the table below.  If the suit takes another hit, its next roll on the table is at +1, the next after that at +2, and so on.

COMPRESSION SUIT BREACH @DRAW[RollTable.CrnnSz5ZJAqwJqbA]{Compression Suite Breach}

 

D6 +
MOD

 

COMPRESSION SUIT BREACH

 

1-2

 

SCUFFS AND SCRAPES, but no breach.

 

3-4

 

THERE IS DAMAGE BUT NO BREACH—YET. Add +1 to the next roll on this table for that suit (this is cumulative).

 

5

 

BREACH, but the tear has jammed closed again.  Lose one point of Air Supply immediately and every time an Air Supply roll is needed you lose two points of Air instead of one, for every rolled.

 

6

 

NASTY BREACH Roll for Air Supply every round.  The wearer gains +1 STRESS LEVEL.

 

7

 

TERRIBLE BREACH The suit is torn open and will lose one point of Air Supply per Round.  The breach is so bad that there is a –1 modifier to the HEAVY MACHINERY roll to do a jury-rig repair.  The wearer gains +1 STRESS LEVEL and must make a Panic Roll.

 

8

 

RUINED The tear is so bad that the suit loses half its remaining Air Supply at the end of the Round in which it took this hit (round down) and the rest at the end of the next Round.  There's a -2 modifier to the HEAVY MACHINERY roll to patch this up.  The wearer gains +1 STRESS LEVEL and must make a Panic Roll.

To patch-up a breach takes one full Round (both actions) and a successful HEAVY MACHINERY roll.

For example, a Mk50 Compression suit takes a hit for three points of damage.  It has an Armor Rating of 2, and rolls one   , but nonetheless the wearer takes two points of damage.  But did the damage penetrate the suit?

Roll for the Armor Rating again.  This time the two dice roll no   so yes, the suit may be battered.  The roll on the Compression Suit Breach table gets a 3—no breach but there is damage.

text.content:
Welcome to the Alien RPG Building Better Worlds module.

If you are new to the Alien RPG system make sure you check out the MU/TH/ER Instructions Journal. This contains a guide to using the Alien RPG system.


Building Better Worlds

All you need to run a game is imported and organised into folders for each of the asset types.

You can rerun the import script at any time by going to Configure Settings> Module Settings and hitting the import button. Any existing assets will not be overwritten so it's useful if you accidentally delete something.


Journals

The "Building Better Worlds - Journals" folder contains the journal entries for the scenario.

  • Building Better Worlds Player Guide Chapters 1 to 6 of BBW for the players.
  • Building Better Worlds GM Guide Chapters 7 and 8 of BBW for GM's only.
  • Building Your Own Better World Chapter 11 of BBW for for the players.
  • The Art of Building Better Worlds Images from the book.

In the Lost Worlds Campaign folder (covering chapters Chapter 9 and 10 of BBW for GM's only) you will find the 11 journal entries for each of the scenarios, handouts and metapuzzle clues.


Actors

Building Better Worlds - Actors:
Folders for PCs, NPCs and new Territories are set up as per the scenario with any necessary equipment.
Please note that because I am only allowed to use officially artwork (what is in the book) so some of the actors only have the default avatars and tokens.

Additional vehicles have been added to the "Alien RPG - Actors > Alien RPG Vehicles" folder.
Creatures have been added to the "Alien RPG - Actors > Alien RPG Creatures" folder.
New Spaceships have been added to the "Alien RPG - Actors > Alien RPG Spaceships" folder. These are listed at the end of this document.


Scenes

Building Better Worlds Maps:
The "Building Better Worlds - Maps" folder contains the book cover art and a folder for each mission:

Each scene has light/movement blocking walls and doors and FoW enabled to provide a more immersive experience when the players are moving around the map with the following exceptions (which are overview maps):

  • UNCSS ÌYÁNLÁ
  • Tontas Ravine
  • Dylan Colony
  • The Atmosphere Processor
  • The Cliff-Dwellers' Camp
  • Engineer City Profile
  • Juggernaut Hub
  • Site of the Engineer City
  • May Outpost
  • The Pyramid
  • The Pyramid Profile
  • The Engineer Juggernaut - Lower Level
  • The Engineer Juggernaut - Upper Level
  • Pelican Colony
  • The Lychgate

There is no lighting on these maps so you may wish to add this.



If you don't wast to use light/movement blocking for your players just select the Wall Control and hit the Bin icon which will delete them from the map. If you change your mind just delete the map and re run the import script.

Items

Additional Equipment, Armor, Systems, Weapons and Vehicle Weapons are added to the existing folders and is listed at the end of this document.

Tables

BBW builds on the table structure set up by the core system adding new Creature and Mother roll tables from the book to the structure.

Alien Creature Tables:

  • Archdeacon Attacks
  • Automation Attacks
  • Biomorph XX121LV Attacks
  • Empress Attacks
  • Cuddles Attacks
  • Harvester Attacks
  • Octobug Attacks
  • Pathogen Lazar "Shambler" Attacks
  • Pathogen Popper “Xenoixodida” Attacks
  • Pathogen Stalker "Venator" Attacks
  • Squid Baby Attacks
  • Xenocobra “Hammerpede” Attacks
  • Xenomorph Capture Attacks

All Creature macros are available in the drop down menu when you create a new Creature.

Alien Mother Tables:

  • 01 - System Star
  • 02 - Star Type
  • 03 - Planet Position
  • 04 - Planet Size
  • 05 - Atmosphere
  • 06 -Radiation
  • 07 - Climate
  • 08 - Hydrosphere
  • 09 - Day Length
  • 10 - Global Feature
  • 11 - Axial Tilt
  • 12 - Regional Terrain
  • 13 - Resource Potential
  • 14 - Planet Personality
  • 15 - Colony Sponsorship
  • 16 - Government or Corporation
  • 17 - Colony Missions
  • 18 - Colony Incidents
  • NEW COLONY INFORMATION
  • CHAMBER TABLE
  • COMPRESSION SUIT BREACH
  • YOUR PERSONAL AGENDA
  • DEPLOY MODULES
  • PROSPECTING FINDS
  • CONNECTION TO THE MISSION
  • ZAPPER EFFECTS
  • PC AFFILIATION
  • DOWNTIME INCIDENTS
  • THE 26 DRACONIS STRAIN
  • EXPLORING THE OVOID CHAMBERS
  • COLONY SITUATION

You can roll against the tables from within the Journals by clicking on the D20 symbol next to the table title. By Pressing CTRL+Left Mouse you can add a modifier to the roll.

Additionally, for ease of use I would suggest using the "Alien - Roll on selected Mother table V10" (see below).


Compendiums

The import should have created folders for everything you need to run Alien.

You can rerun the import at any time by going to "Configure Settings > Module Settings" and hitting the Re-Import button. Re running the import will only replace missing content and will not overwrite anything.


Macros

BUILD A BETTER WORLD

In the macros directory you will find a macro called Build a Better World. This macro runs code that creates a fully populated Planet Sheet and Journal Entry using the data in the "Building your Own Better World" section. Please note this does not use the Foundry rolltables as roll modifiers are required.

The core Alien system comes with 6 macros that will help you run the game smoothly.

These can be found in the Compendium under Macro>Alien. I suggest you right click and do an "Import All Content" to get them into your library.

  1. Alien - GM Dice Roller Allows you to perform ad-hoc dice rolls. Uncheck the GM Only box to make the rolls public.
  2. Alien - Player Ad-hoc YZE Dice Roller Make this available to your players. They need to have a token selected before running the macro.
  3. Alien - Roll on selected Mother table V10 provides a drop down listing all the Mother Tables available. Allows multiple rolls against the table and modifiers (+/- x to roll not additional dice).
  4. Alien - Roll on selected Creature table V10 same as above for Creature tables but no modifiers and all rolls are private to the GM.

Recommended Add-on Modules

While not necessary to use the Alien system of this module I would recommend installing the following Add-on modules as they make the GM's job a lot easier:

  • Dice So Nice:
    Alien RPG supports 2 dice face types.
  • PnP - Pointer and Pings:
    Useful for pointing things out to the players and pulling their map focus to where you want it.
  • Quick Insert - Search Widget:
    Allows you to quickly search for assets and drag them directly on to the scene.
  • Alien RPG - Motion Tracker :
    The module installs a button just over the chat box that you can hit. When hit, the button will scan for the nearest active and visible tokens based on the selected token. This is still under development but is a really good effect to add tension to a scene.

Building Better Worlds - New Assets Listing

List of assets merged into the standard folder structure. All other new assets are in specific BBW folders.

name: 10.03 LEAVE ALL ELSE TO THE GODS

pages.name: 10.03 LEAVE ALL ELSE TO THE GODS

text.content:
“We have a basic responsibility to our species to venture to other worlds. Sailors on a becalmed sea, we sense the stirring of a breeze”

—CARL SAGAN

The PCs are sent to a pristine planet, to colonize and explore. But they are not the first to make landfall here—they find the camp of a colony scouting team stranded here 75 years ago. Under orders from Governor Abantu, the PCs establish the new colony. But as the colonists set up their new home, the PCs make a terrible discovery—the ancient ruins of an Engineer city, and the remnants of their genetic creativity. Can the PCs uncover the terrifying secrets of the city in time to save themselves and the new colony?

WHAT IS GOING ON?

In 2100, just before the Isolation, a small survey crew from Gorham Colony scouted the KOI-1966 system, and found KOI-1966.03, the third planet. They nick-named it “Aljanna” after the Hausa word for paradise. They set up a forward base camp, but before the planet could be colonized the Isolation changed everything. The scouting crew soon discovered the buried remains of an ancient Engineer city, and the horrors that lay within.

When the Engineers fled this area of space thousands of years ago, the city was abandoned in a hurry. They left behind the preserved remains of their creations—a form of proto-human, a primitive Arcturian, a Fulfremmen, others now impossible to identify, and XX121 Xenomorphs.

The scouting crew disturbed the hibernating Xenomorphs and were quickly taken as hosts. Since then, the hive has grown, the Xenommorphs exploiting the indigenous life on Aljanna and living in the dark halls of the city.

WHAT'S THE STORY MOTHER?

The comms unit buzzes, the incoming ID code showing it's Gaius, calling from UNCSS Ìyánlá.

“Good day Solovetsky Island. I hope all is well.

As you know, a key element of the Great Mother Mission is to re-colonize this sector of space under the collaborative banner of the United Nations, and not any one supernation or corporation. The third planet in the KOI-1966 system, KOI-1966.03, was noted as suitable for colonization before the Isolation, and this has been corroborated by our long-range survey scans. Governor Abantu has taken a close personal interest in the colonization of this planet—between you and me he is desperate for a good news story, and setting up the first colony of the Great Mother Mission will be that story.

Your task is to travel to KOI-1966.03 as the advance party for the colonization. The Ìyánlá will be 24 hours behind you. We have four atmosphere processors riding on Ìyánlá's back and consuming fuel at a terrible rate, so we need to get them deployed soon, and thousands of colonists on ice, to wake up and start making better worlds for all. You will oversee the colonization operation and then survey the planet for valuable resources. As I said, Governor Abantu himself is the driving force behind this expedition and expects to see rapid results.

Don't let him down.”

 

CLUES TO THE
METAPUZZLE

The PCs can learn the third campaign clue during this expedition, by investigating the Gallery of the Ages within the Engineer city and activating the Engineer archives. The PCs will learn that the Engineers created the Xenomorphs and the Perfected but then could not control them. They decided to leave this sector of space behind, using a device they call “the Lychgate.”

 
KOI-1966.03—ALJANNA
KOI-1966.03 is a paradise world, a pristine twin of Earth. It has a warm and temperate climate, with tropical regions at the equator and freezing poles. However, it does suffer from high levels of ultraviolet radiation from the local star, equivalent to Weak radiation that only takes effect once per week—something an atmosphere processor can fix by adding ozone to the stratosphere. Gravity is Earth standard. The only significant difference is the day length of 48 hours instead of 24.

The planetary details for KOI-1966.03—Aljanna—are noted to the right and can be used to expand the story of the PCs' adventures on this world, should they choose to continue the colonization once this expedition has finished, using the rules in the Appendix: Building Your Own Better World.

KICKING OFF THE ACTION

The action starts with the PCs arriving in the KOI-1966 system. They can learn about the system with a simple survey scan, which also picks up a very weak signal from an old colony pathfinder locator beacon on the third planet. This is not a distress beacon but was used by scouting teams to denote their presence and a suitable location for colonization. It's located in the northern hemisphere (Northern Hemisphere West in the diagram on ) in a region of mountains, rivers and river deltas. If the PCs check, they can see that this beacon is using a pre-Isolation code and is thus at least 75 years old.

Further investigation reveals there is a small prefabricated pre-colony base established on a wide plain bordered by large rivers and a low mountain range. There are no signs of human life and there is no reply to any communication attempt. Their scans also detect the following in the vicinity of the pre-colony base:

  • A huge collapsed cliff-face, 25 km to the north, radiating signatures for many rare and highly sought after minerals. A successful COMTECH roll will identify rhodium, iridium and platinum, a prospector's dream find.
  • A group of lakes, 50 km to the south, are blooming with multicolored flashes indicating some form of sea life: red, auburn, green, yellow, and orange—the water is a painter's palette gone mad. Perhaps an indigenous source of food—just what a new colony needs.
  • 200 km to the northeast, the plains are filled with beasts, herds of alien quadrupeds roaming the landscape. A source of food, or creatures to domesticate?
  • There is a large area of increased thermal signatures 100 km to the east. A successful COMTECH roll doesn't give a clear answer but suggests this could be either some low level volcanic activity, or a cluster of lifeforms (it is caused by the underground Engineer city).

It's up to the PCs how they explore the planet. Landing the Solovetsky Island anywhere requires a PILOTING roll. If the roll fails the landing is still successful but the ship comes down heavily, causing D3 damage.

SHORE PARTY

The prospector on the Solovetsky Island, Emily Quintana (), insists she joins the PCs planet-side to assist with prospecting and surveying the environment. She will keep an eye out for the PCs taking any finds and hoarding them for themselves.

PRE-COLONY BASE CAMP

Sitting in the center of a three-kilometer wide grassy plain, the camp consists of six prefabricated rigid tents surrounding the pathfinder locator beacon, a box one meter across with a series of aerials. It has fallen on its side but continues to function, powered by a grimy portable solar panel that stands next to it.

The camp has obviously been abandoned for a very long time—the structures are smeared by ages-old dust and dirt, containers and boxes lie scattered, the grasses of the plains have grown around and through the place. A battered Daihotai 8x8 tractor rests a few meters away, slumped in upon itself with rotted tires and its structure rusted and broken.

PREFABRICATED TENTS

One of the six rigid tents has completely collapsed, and the others are damaged. Some were torn open by the Xenomorphs when they claimed the last of the scouting crew—with a successful OBSERVATION roll the PCs can detect that some of the damage does not appear to be caused by weather.

Despite the damage, there are many sealed boxes of useful supplies—the PCs can find anything they wish that would have been available in 2100, at your discretion, unless it's perishable, in which case it has long since rotted away.

In one of the tents, amongst the camp debris, is a data pad that belonged to the team leader, Daran Bako. If the PCs examine it, they will find Bako's survey of this region, his clear recommendation that it's a perfect place to establish a new colony, and the details of his last log entries. See the sidebar Daran Bako's Log.

DARAN BAKO'S LOG

Daran Bako, expedition leader, Colonization Scout Team Delta-19, Aboki settlement, Gorham Colony

  • 11/07/2109: Landfall on KOI-1966.03, henceforth called “Aljanna” for this planet is paradise.
  • 12/02/2109: Initial surveys encouraging. This planet is ripe for colonization and this location is superb, with access to plentiful resources within hundreds of kilometers. It's such a kind and forgiving world that some of my team are talking about giving up the scouting life, and staying to set up the colony and live here.
  • 01/11/2110: Our retrieval ship hasn't arrived on time. Efforts to contact them are fruitless as there's some interstellar interference. Jamal suggests it could be a solar flare.
  • 03/24/2110: Supplies are running low and still no sign of retrieval. The team is becoming dispirited. We are having to cast our net further. This planet can certainly feed us, we just have to get on with it. There's potentially a verdant spot out to the east, and we go to explore that tomorrow.

COLONIZING ALJANNA

The planet appears ideal for colonization, just what the Great Mother Mission has been looking for. Once the PCs have made their initial exploration of the pre-colony base, they receive a message from the Ìyánlá, that they are in orbit and will commence colonization procedures in one Shift. As such, the PCs are expected to proceed with colonization, by Governor Abantu, Ìyánlá's synthetic overseer Gaius, and the other Solovetsky Island crew members—they not only think the place is perfect for colonization but want the distinction of establishing the first colony under the Great Mother Mission, to be recorded for posterity as founders, and get a fat bonus in their paycheck.

Colonization should take place before the PCs find the Engineer city and the dangers that lurk there. However, if the PCs are determined to delay colonization for any reason, make sure they feel the full wrath and displeasure of Governor Abantu who, if necessary, will get the PCs on comms and give them a direct order to begin the operation.

Once the PCs are ready to start the colonization process you should use the guidance in the Appendix: Building Your Own Better World, and follow these steps:

  1. The colonization will take place at the PCs' location, in the Northern Hemisphere West region of the planet.
  2. If any of the PCs have family in cryosleep aboard Ìyánlá, they can choose to have them join the colony deployment.
  3. An advance party under Colony Supervisor Manisha Kiran arrives but the PCs and their crew are expected to manage the operation to get the machinery on the ground. This requires a Shift of work and a HEAVY MACHINERY roll to control each deployment of the atmosphere processor and three colony modules (four rolls in total)—an NPC crew member can make this roll if their skill is highest. If the roll is failed for any of these, roll on the @UUID[RollTable.DDcdjoEAFPf6WodE]{DEPLOY MODULES}@DRAW[RollTable.DDcdjoEAFPf6WodE]{Draw} table to see how badly things go south.
  4. Once the colony is safely on the ground, the PCs should roll for the colony's starting attribute values and Development Level (The Colony In Play)—then the colony is ready to play.
  5. In honor of Daran Bako and his crew of scouts, Governor Abantu chooses to name the colony “Aljanna.” Colony Supervisor Kiran and the initial colonists celebrate this moment with the PCs. Cartons of prefab meals and bug juice are cracked open, backs are slapped and cheers ring out. Governor Abantu contacts the PCs to congratulate them, and everyone takes a moment to relish their success.

DEPLOY MODULES @DRAW[RollTable.DDcdjoEAFPf6WodE]{DEPLOY MODULES}
D6 ATMOSPHERE PROCESSOR   COLONY MODULE
1–3 It comes down with a bump but is otherwise undamaged.   It comes down with a bump but is otherwise undamaged.
4 It crash lands but is not seriously damaged. However, it will take three months to repair and bring online.   The module crash lands and suffers some damage, but no one is hurt. The colony loses 1 point from a random colony attribute (The Colony Attributes).
5 It lands in the wrong place, blocking a river. The water pools around and inside the processor, creating a new lake.   The module's shielding breaks away. D6 colonists aboard are killed, but it's seen as a terrible accident.
6 A system fails and the processor loses control. It spins and crashes in a huge explosion leaving a twisted mass of wreckage. The incident is seen as an accident, but people blame the PCs.   The module suffers a catastrophic failure and is wrecked, killing 2D6 colonists aboard. The colony loses 1 point from two random attributes (The Colony Attributes). The incident is seen as an accident, but people blame the PCs.

COLLAPSED CLIFF

The cliff is 25 km north of the base camp. A landslide over a kilometer wide occurred some years ago, revealing in cross-section the mineral rich caverns and tubules within. Some are natural, but many are caused by a Harvester-like creature, a fact the PCs can learn with a successful OBSERVATION roll. This constant internal erosion caused the landslide in the first place, and the remaining cliff is highly unstable.

It is littered with mineral ores, including rhodium—exceptionally rare and vital for electronic systems and fuel components, iridium—used to harden alloys and as a catalyst, and platinum—ever in demand. A very rich find and a powerful reason to colonize the planet.

The enormous mound of jagged scree at the base of the cliff stretches along its 1,000 meter length. It requires a MOBILITY roll to climb across. If this is failed, the PC slips and falls on the sharp rocks, taking one point of damage. They must also roll a Stress Die—on   the scree begins to slip. The PC and all within MEDIUM range must make a MOBILITY roll or get swept along in the small avalanche, taking an eight Base Dice attack, Damage 1. Another Stress Die should then be rolled—this time a roll of   sees a 50-meter-wide stretch of the cliff start to come down with an earth-shattering crack. All who witness this gain +1 STRESS LEVELt make a MOBILITY roll to avoid the rock fall. Anyone caught in its path takes a twelve Base Dice attack, Damage 2.

At your discretion, this disturbance may rouse D6 small Harvesters that were within the rock (treat them as @UUID[Actor.xUIY0w9sKMeury7O]{Harvester Juveniles} ). They are angry at being disturbed and will attack the PCs.

ALGAE LAKES

A series of lakes linked by rivers lies 50 km to the south of the pre-colony base, at the apex of a huge delta. They are filled with multicolored weeds and algae, mostly growing around the shallow edges of the water, where it rarely gets deeper than 1.5 meters. If the PCs wade into the water to reach the plant life, they can take a Turn to analyze it with an OBSERVATION roll:

  • For one   the PCs learn that the weeds and algae are all edible.
  • For two   they assess they are fast growing and are food for other creatures, as evidenced by the coin-sized bites taken out of the weeds' leaves. The weeds have electrocytes within their stems that create a low electric current, presumably to keep the predators away.
  • For three or more   the PCs realize that these species are symbiotic, that the weeds use the algae for basic minerals, and the algae attaches to the weeds to grow its spores.

The predatory creatures, Octobugs, also live in the mass of weed-algae. At your discretion, any PC in the water will be attacked by D3 of them.

 
THE OCTOBUGS OF PARADISE

No bigger than an adult's hand and tan in color with three tentacles, each Octobug is equipped with razor-sharp gripping claws. They gain sustenance from a form of electro-synthesis, with the ability to detect the warmth and energy from powered systems and absorb it. They are easily agitated and excitable. Usually found in small groups, they are most dangerous when they act as a swarm.

THE ROAMING HERDS

If the PCs travel 200 kilometers to the northeast, they find herds of alien bovine creatures, calmly grazing the long grasses.
