  • For one   the PCs assess that the creatures are edible and have a silky woolen coat that would be valuable for making textiles.
  • For two   they assess that the creatures are partially mammalian—partially reptilian, and probably lay eggs to reproduce.
  • For three or more   the PCs realize that these creatures are docile and should be easy to domesticate.
THE FLORA OF THE CITY

The Engineer city has become home to a species of pink toadstools of the fungus Ophiocordyceps vehemens. These sweet-smelling fungi live in dark, dank places and can be found anywhere in the city. They disperse invisible spores in response to movement within SHORT range. Anyone exposed must make a Sickness Roll against Virulence 6. If infected, after one Turn they will begin to exhibit angry outbursts at the slightest provocation. Get your players to roleplay this and reward them with a Story Point for good roleplaying.

After a Shift, the victim becomes enraged, goes berserk against any living thing, fighting until they or their victim is dead, Broken or they are restrained. The victims do not eat or drink, so may perish through dehydration or starvation (see OTHER HAZARDS in the core rulebook) if they fail to recover soon enough or are not restrained and given medical treatment. A successful MEDICAL AID roll adds a +3 modification to the victim's subsequent Sickness Rolls. A victim makes another Sickness Roll every 24 hours, against Virulence 6, until they succeed and overcome the disease, or perish.

ENGINEER CITY

The city is 100 km east of the base camp, and is hidden beneath millennia of weathering and erosion, as well as the growth of local plants and creatures. On first examination the place looks natural, sitting on a plain with semi-symmetrical mounds in the ground. Outside this ring of mounds, the grassy earth rises sharply until it meets the surrounding mountains and cliffs. The view to the south, from the sheer cliff, is a breath-taking vista of the planet's awesome beauty.

Access to the area is either by air, or along a 500-meter-wide valley to the west.

The PCs can detect the slight increase in ambient temperature here, either using the Solovetsky Island's scanners or with a Pups device and a COMTECH roll. They cannot detect any obvious volcanic activity or unusually large concentrations of animal or plant life.

MOUNDS

Grass-covered and wet, these mounds cover ancient Engineer structures that are now just archaeological relics. Excavation with a tractor or digger will reveal these stony ruins.

RIVULETS

Rain running off the mountains has turned the ground marshy, with a number of small rivulets running down to a central hollow. Crossing them is tricky, requiring a MOBILITY roll to avoid getting stuck in the mud for one Round.

HOLLOW

The grassy ground here forms a hollow bowl with a slushy pool of water at the bottom. This ground has built up over the sliding iris-valve doors that would have allowed a Juggernaut to dock below ground. They are stuck open, hidden beneath this unstable ground. Any disturbance—such as a PC walking on it—risks a cave-in. Roll a Stress Die each Round a PC is in the hollow—on   the earth literally falls under their feet, and they plunge into the Juggernaut Bay. The hollow caves-in automatically if a vehicle drives across it. Any PC that falls gains +1 STRESS LEVEL, but only takes an eight Base Dice attack, Damage 1, as their fall is slowed by the roots and branches that fill the bay, and they land on the buildup of mud at the bottom.

OPEN MOUND

The earth mounds were formed by the weathering of the site over thousands of years. The open mound has had some of this earth taken away by the Xenomorphs, leaving a narrow tunnel in the earth that accesses the southern Access Tower in the Juggernaut Hub.

INSIDE THE CITY

The Engineer city has been empty for many thousands of years, abandoned before the Perfected could arrive and destroy it. It has some residual power that illuminates its tunnels and chambers with a gloomy blue glow but is otherwise shrouded in shadow. It smells musty and damp, an odor of stagnation and decay.

The ceremonial parts of the city—the Temple and Gallery of the Ages—are acoustically designed to carry and amplify the songs of the dead Engineers but have that effect on any sound made within them.

Doors within the city are either large stone edifices that can be opened by pushing for one Round with a successful STAMINA roll with a +3 modification or are vertically slatted portcullis-style gates that are operated by turning a handle set into the wall beside them, making them retract into the ceiling. The edifice doors cannot be destroyed, but the slatted gates can be, with Health 12, Armor Rating 4.

JUGGERNAUT HUB

JUGGERNAUT BAY

Filled with mud and plant growth, this place is musty and damp. The floor consists of a huge iris-valve hatch large enough for a Juggernaut to pass through, leading to the Juggernaut Docking Cavern below. It is fractionally open, leaving gaps in the floor half a meter wide—just enough to squeeze through. The distance to the floor is 300 meters, so the PCs will need plenty of rope and a successful MOBILITY roll if they want to rappel down to the cavern floor below. A failed roll will see the PC get tangled in the ropes and stuck dangling or fall the rest of the way to the cavern floor, at your discretion.

ANTECHAMBERS

Huge empty rooms, once used by the Engineers to congregate before boarding a Juggernaut.

ACCESS TOWERS

Wide spiral staircases made of stone that allow access to the surface. Only the southern tower has access to the open mound on the surface.

JUGGERNAUT DOCKING CAVERN

This gigantic circular chamber, 1,300 meters across, is big enough to house ten Engineer Juggernauts—and five of these enormous ships, old, cold, silent, empty, and long dead, still rest here now, only accompanied by the lonely echo of dripping water. This place is so awesome that anyone viewing it for the first time gains +1 STRESS LEVEL.

TEMPLE

The only way to access the Temple is from either the Juggernaut Bay or Docking Cavern, all other routes are blocked by rubble and years of decay. A pyramid shape, the Temple's ceiling is 100 meters high, rising to 200 meters over the central altar-dais.

SIX STATUES

Within the depressed area of the altar-dais are six enormous head statues, 20 meters wide by 50 meters tall. In the gaps between them are carvings of various Xenomorphs, looking as if they are climbing and embracing the statues. All viewing this must make an OBSERVATION roll to recognize these are carvings—all who fail the roll are shocked and surprised and gain +1 STRESS LEVEL.

VIEWING PLATFORM

Raised five meters above the temple floor, these are platforms once used for congregations to watch and join the temple ceremonies.

BALCONY

Raised 20 meters above the viewing platforms, these give a better view of the temple.

THE GALLERY OF THE AGES

Both an archive and a laboratory, the Engineers used this place to experiment and cultivate new forms of life, and to record their successes and failures. Raised Walkway: Raised three meters above the Display Floor, this walkway gives an excellent view of the exhibits and access to the whole facility. To scale this in a rush requires a successful MOBILITY roll.

DISPLAY FLOOR

Filled with transparent display cases and cubicles, elegantly arranged around the ornate pillars, it is filled with Engineer creations. The PCs can learn the following, with a Turn of study and an OBSERVATION roll:

  • For one   the PCs see there are many forms of life represented here, including humanoid, quadruped and multi-limbed creatures—they identify a form of proto-human, an Arcturian and three specimens of Fulfremmen Abomination—a Revenant, a Shambler and a Perfected, all dead and preserved.
  • For two   the PCs realize that these are all creations of the Engineers.
  • For three or more   the PCs realize that all creations here are recorded as failures.
CONTROL DAIS

An ornate array of machinery and equipment is designed in the shape of an orrery, with dark metallic arms sporting globe after globe, in a complex arrangement representing hundreds of star systems. Four seats allow a PC to sit cross-legged at the controls, each seat with a vertical or transverse flute of either an upper or lower key. If a note is played on all four at the same time the dais bursts into life, and blue holographic glyphs suddenly rotate in the air. See the sidebar The Engineers' Song. This is the third campaign clue (Clue #3—Translation Of The Engineer Holo-Glyphs In The Gallery Of The Ages). A PC can try to decipher the glyphs with an OBSERVATION roll with a -1 modification, or alternatively DA/UT/UR aboard the Solovetsky Island can do it for them.

CULTIVATION CHAMBERS 1 & 3

Used to grow Engineer specimens, these chambers are empty.

CULTIVATION CHAMBER 2

In their rush to evacuate, the Engineers left behind live specimens of the XX121 Xenomorph. Over the years they managed to escape, opening the once sealed door just far enough for a Drone to squeeze out and explore. Now the hive fills this chamber. A Queen slumbers in the shadows at the far end, her work laying Ovomorphs done for now, as 100 eggs lie dormant before her. She is guarded by two Praetorian Stage VI Xenomorphs, the three of them too large to ever leave the city. The hive has five Stage V Soldiers, and many Stage IV Drones and Scouts. They are all PASSIVE.

The PCs can see this through the observation windows set either side of the ajar door. They gain +1 STRESS LEVEL and must immediately make a Panic roll. If this doesn't alert the Xenomorphs to their presence, the PCs must make an opposed MOBILITY roll against the Xenomorphs' eight Base Dice, to avoid detection. Enter stealth mode.

THE ENGINEERS' SONG

Your eyes are assaulted by the sudden blue glare as glowing hieroglyphs flood the air before and around you, spinning and swirling, dazzling your mind and your vision. Around these arise tall figures, human but not human, chiseled as an ancient statue but graceful as a ballet dancer. You watch as they take up their instruments and play a hypnotic tune and wonder as a horseshoe-shaped vessel rises from the floor, spinning upwards and away, followed by another and another. Eventually the music stops, the figures laying aside their instruments to watch as one last image, of a vast spinning structure before a beautiful be-clouded planet, slowly fades into shadow.

EVENTS

ÌYÁNLÁ CALLING

If the PCs are taking their time over deciding to colonize KOI-1966.03, they receive a message from Gaius. Despite being a synthetic, a faint hint of frustration can be heard in his voice. He's pressing for an answer on the colonization potential of KOI-1966.03, saying that Governor Abantu “is desperate to see progress, and his comments on it are frequent and vivid.” He asks for an urgent progress report and needs a very good reason why the PCs are not getting on with it.

DEVILS IN THE DARK

The Engineer city is home to vermin, and they skitter away if they hear noises or see lights from the PCs. They PCs will hear this. If they go looking for the cause they can catch a glimpse of a rat-like creature with a successful OBSERVATION roll. However, if they fail to find the source, or don't even try looking for it, the constant noises in the distance give them +1 STRESS LEVEL.

THE WILDLIFE OF ALJANNA

When out in the wilderness, the PCs are stalked by an indigenous creature akin to a Lionworm (Lion Worms in the core rulebook). Enter stealth mode. When the Lionworm makes its first signature attack, it instead rushes a random PC, then stops. The PC gains +1 STRESS LEVEL as the creature scrutinizes them, before deciding the PCs are not prey. If the PCs resist the urge to be hostile it will turn and calmly slink away into the undergrowth.

FINALE

Once the PCs have discovered the Xenomorph hive, things will move quickly. Even if the PCs successfully sneak away from the hive, an alert Xenomorph will detect them before they escape the Gallery of the Ages. The chase is on. Three Xenomorph Scouts and three Drones give chase, with many more following behind them, at your discretion.

ESCAPING THE CITY

The PCs can slow down the Xenomorph chase by closing the door to their cultivation chamber. Just closing it will only delay the Xenomorphs by D6 Rounds. If the PCs have a cutting torch, they can do a rush job of welding it shut, with a HEAVY MACHINERY roll with a -3 modification—a success will delay the Xenomorphs by a further D3 Rounds. They can try again if this fails until their torch runs out of power. However, while the PCs are doing this, the Xenomorphs will be trying to force the door open. To resist this, the PCs need to succeed at an opposed STAMINA roll against eight Base Dice.

Closing the slatted gates will also slow the Xenomorphs by another D6 Rounds per gate they have to smash through. If the PCs manage to out-distance the Xenomorphs, in a vehicle or a ship, the Xenomorphs will give up and return to the hive.

DEALING WITH THE THREAT

Even if the PCs escape the city, the threat to Aljanna and the newly founded colony is terrible. The PCs could try to return to the city to seal the Xenomorphs inside, either by sealing the internal doors, or collapsing the structure in on itself with explosives, but this would come with significant risk and the Xenomorphs would oppose it. Alternatively, they could try to convince Gaius and Governor Abantu that the threat is so severe they should use one of UNCSS Ìyánlá's arsenal of terraforming nuclear weapons, and nuke the site from orbit—after all, it's the only way to be sure. Abantu is in favor, in order to protect and keep KOI-1966.03 as a new colony prize delivered by the Great Mother Mission, but @UUID[Actor.nj9Age4WlLuipv5y]{Gaius} and @UUID[Actor.yDlVESpXHBm0Vxcu]{Kamal Vartouhi} of Weyland-Yutani are violently opposed to it. Gaius will suggest they send an exploration team to check out the PCs' claims and offer the PCs the chance to lead it. If the PCs are determined the site should be destroyed, they can attempt an opposed MANIPULATION roll against Gaius, with a -3 modification, to have him relent and leave Governor Abantu clear to give the order. It's up to you how many, if any, of the Xenomorphs escape the blast…

EPILOGUE

The newly formed colony may need help getting on its feet, and the PCs could be a part of that, exploring and prospecting, or gathering much needed supplies for the colonists. A Weyland-Yutani executive may want to take advantage of the archaeology of the planet, and proposes the PCs make a quiet and unofficial return to the city—now better prepared—to acquire samples and data that W-Y would pay handsomely for.

“The gem cannot be polished without friction, nor man Perfected without trials.”

—CHINESE PROVERB

This is the finale of The Lost Worlds campaign.  Having learned what they think is the truth, the PCs must rush to the Lychgate to prevent the Perfected from using it.  They will battle to its heart before they understand it is all a ruse, that the Perfected's real prize is the UNCSS Ìyánlá and all it carries.  Avoiding the Xenomorphs that now infest the Lychgate, the PCs must join the battle for Ìyánlá, a battle complicated by the UPP's treachery and own attempt to take control of the Great Mother Mission.  How the PCs resolve this conflict is up to them, but the fate of humanity is in their hands.

WHAT IS GOING ON?

By now, the PCs will have learned what they think is the truth—the Perfected are planning to use the Engineer Lychgate, in orbit around the super gas giant Ojo in the KOI-1938 system, to instantly travel the 100 light years between the Far Spinward Colonies and the Middle Heavens.  Their infection will spread, and humanity will face its doom.

However, unknown to the PCs, the Perfected cannot operate the Lychgate, and instead have made another plan—to leak knowledge of the Lychgate to the Great Mother Mission, knowing that in their avarice, the humans won't be able to resist seizing it for themselves.  In so doing, they will bring ships, perhaps even the great colony ship UNCSS Ìyánlá, to within the Perfected's grasp.  The Perfected will take these ships, and in triumph journey to the Middle Heavens.  

All they need to do is wait upon the Lychgate, with their ships hiding in the near vicinity, holding their fire until the right moment to spring the trap. Those humans who venture on to the Engineer structure will serve a useful function nonetheless, as the Lychgate itself now has another purpose—the Perfected have established four hives of XX121 Xenomorphs aboard, each with a growing Queen vying for the favor of the one to rule them all, the Empress.

Gaius aboard the Ìyánlá is made aware of the Lychgate, either by the PCs contacting him and briefing him themselves, or the Solovetsky Island's DA/UT/UR computer will have sent the information to him via Ìyánlá's MU/TH/UR.  The fleet sets sail for the KOI-1938 system.

As the Ìyánlá drops from FTL and heads for the orbit of Ojo, the UPP launches its coup to take control of the Great Mother Mission.  They resuscitate their covert soldiers from hypersleep and ready themselves to take over.  But not all the UPP are focused on this treachery.  Unknown to the PCs, a UPP Cosmos Exploration Corps scout ship under Lt Col Sensakovic has already arrived at the Lychgate—she knows the threat the Perfected represent and is already aboard the Lychgate with the same mission as the PCs.

THE THREE PARTS OF THE FINALE

PART I

The PCs arrive in the orbit of Ojo and find the Lychgate.  They should explore the Lychgate in an attempt to prevent the Perfected from using it as a portal, eventually confronting the Perfected and Mother Ma'Kayla in the Lychgate's Core.  They will learn the terrible truth behind the truth, that this is all a honey pot, a trap to bring Ìyánlá within the Perfected's grasp, and that the battle for Ìyánlá is about to begin.

PART II

The PCs must escape the Lychgate and the Xenomorphs.  They may be captured and readied as hosts but will have the chance to escape.

PART III

The battle for Ìyánlá.  Multiple factions are trying to gain control of the ship and its vast resources—the UPP have decided to take control, the Perfected and the Children of the Two Divines are trying to seize it, and the rest of the Mission's crew are trying to resist both of them.  It's up to the PCs which, if any, of these factions they want to support or oppose, and they should return to the vessel to see out the fight, one way or another.

WHAT'S THE STORY MOTHER?

You set sail for the KOI-1938 system in search of the Lychgate, with the Ìyánlá and the fleet just hours behind you in support.  You find the gas giant, Ojo, a planet that makes Jupiter look like a pebble in comparison.  And there before you, orbiting this wonder of nature, lies another wonder—the Lychgate.

You had thought Ìyánlá was impressive, but this structure is truly awe-inspiring.  Not quite circular, kilometers across, with an immense outer ring connected to a central hub by 16 spiraling booms, interlaced with smaller girders that twist and writhe between the spokes.  The outer ring has four great transepts, huge hangers hundreds of meters across and open to space, easily big enough to swallow your ship and still have space for more.  The central hub, a massive flattened sphere seemingly fashioned by the hands of the gods themselves, is itself over one thousand meters across and three hundred meters thick.

Your ship sensors show faint traces of power running throughout the majestic structure.  Spikes of intensity and temperature increase as you scan towards the central core, the beating heart of the gate.  The thermal signature blooms mightily at the very center of the leviathan construction.

The Lychgate spins in breathtakingly elegant laziness, a timeless behemoth that neither fears nor remembers the passing of the eons.  It turns, bathed in the radiant glow from the yellow super gas giant, and waits.

KICKING OFF THE ACTION

The action kicks off in space near the Lychgate.  The PCs can see two Heliades-class ships, the Perfected with their devotee minions from the Children of the Two Divines, maneuvering into position, easing themselves into two of the four Transepts, preparing to dock and board the Lychgate.  They have an hour's head start (10 Turns).

Piloting Solovetsky Island into a Transept and parking it close to the Airlock Spheres requires a PILOTING roll with a -1 modification.  A failed roll means they have scraped the ship or struggled with the Lychgate's rotation—they successfully complete the maneuver, but the ship takes D3 damage.

“If you don't stop it there won't be a home to go back to.  It's carrying death and heading for Earth.”

—DR ELIZABETH SHAW
THE LYCHGATE'S ENVIRONMENT

With the exception of the Outer Ring, which is open to the vacuum of space, the Lychgate is pressurized and has a breathable, if humid, atmosphere.  Residual power flows and creates a low blue glow throughout, that seems to emanate from everywhere but nowhere at the same time.  The solid core is intensely dense, and has an exotic gravitational effect, while the entire structure is spinning on its axis.  This means that the gravity felt in the center, on the surface of the core itself, is much stronger than that felt at the outer surface.  While the gravitational effect is obviously gradual, in game terms the Core is 1.5G, the Antechamber Tunnels are 1G, the Booms and Ambulatories are 0.5G, and it's zero G in the Outer Ring.  The PCs will suffer from gravity dyspraxia (Conditions) as they travel through the different zones.

THE FINALE'S GUEST STARS

Many of the NPCs from the campaign may feature in this expedition, assuming they survive to this point in the story.  You can incorporate them in the scenario as you see fit—some are aboard the Lychgate, others on the Ìyánlá, and the rest can appear when you need them to.  The key ones are:

THE PERFECTED

She is with the Perfected on board the Lychgate, and will confront the PCs when they reach the Lychgate's Core.

GENERAL NURLAN OZOLINSKI

He is leading the UPP's attempts to take control of UNCSS Ìyánlá.  He is a reasonable man, and if the PCs can convince him of the threat posed by the Perfected and their minions, he will order his troops to fight them, instead of taking over the ship.

The purpose of her life, and that of her ancestors, has been to oppose the Perfected.  She and the Gorham's Marauders may arrive to join the final battle against the Perfected, with four ships and 50 fighters.

WARLORD ZHĀNGJIÉ AND/OR BRIGADIER WŎ

(@UUID[Actor.7PlBHjT3ISy19bFI]{Warlord Zhāngjié} AND @UUID[Actor.AvBDV6M9v5hxuNZf]{Brigadier Xìn Wŏ} )

THE LYCHGATE

The Lychgate is unmistakably an enormous Engineer relic, its seemingly symmetrical structure twisted with bulges, curves and swirls that give its biomechanical design an almost organic feel.  Seeing it for the first time brings +1 STRESS LEVEL.

THE OUTER RING

This entire ring is hollow and open to the vacuum of space—a huge Engineer ship hangar bay.  While the height of this ring varies between 500 and 150 meters it is uniformly 800 meters wide.  The interior walls are curved and shaped to allow Juggernauts and other vessels of unknown design to dock, hugging themselves snugly into the shaped docking spaces made for them.  On the outer hull there are similar slots where a Guardian ship could attach, although the Lychgate hasn't played host to an Engineer vessel in millennia.

TRANSEPTS

Huge openings that allow ships to maneuver into the interior of the Outer Ring.  Two of them house Perfected Heliades-class ships.

AIRLOCK SPHERES

Where each Ambulatory connects with the Outer Ring there are six airlock spheres, each 50 meters across and fashioned in organic shapes and lines.  Each airlock has a 10-meter circular opening on one side, the entrance and exit aperture, that allows access to the interior of the sphere, but cannot be docked with—the PCs must spacewalk to gain access to the airlock.  Inside it's full of outcrops and girders—ribbed platforms to stand or hold on to.  Once someone enters the sphere, the ancient automated mechanisms take over, swiveling the entire sphere 180 degrees.  The aperture swings round and slowly reveals the view on the other side.  When the aperture turns from the vacuum of the Outer Ring to the atmosphere of the Ambulatory, the sphere is suddenly flooded by a rush of air.  When turning from atmosphere to vacuum, the air in the sphere explosively decompresses—unless the PCs have prepared for this (by taking hold of the platforms or attaching a cable to secure themselves), they must make a MOBILITY test or be whooshed into the zero-G vacuum of the Outer Ring.

THE BOOM SPOKES

AMBULATORIES

Accessed from the Outer Ring through the Airlock Spheres, the Ambulatories are huge twisted, spiraling tunnels, 100 meters wide.  The spirals make multiple pathways that twist around the edges, allowing the PCs to make their way down the tunnel.  At the base of the tunnel, the PCs see ten hatches set in the floor, five meters wide and made of the same organically shaped substance of the airlock spheres.  Several are open, either fully or just enough for a human to squeeze through.  The Ambulatory has a cathedral-like feel—sounds echo, the air swirls with dust, and the glowing blue haze makes light beams dance in the shadows.

BOOM LATTICES

What look like structural girders from the outside, are actually two-meter-wide tunnels that create a warren of paths between the Ambulatories.  Each Ambulatory has dozens of openings to these twisting, dark and cold pipes.  A source of light is needed to navigate them, and once inside, the PCs need to make an OBSERVATION avoid getting lost within the maze.  They can make this roll once per Turn but gain +1 STRESS LEVEL on the first failed roll, and must make a Panic Roll if they fail a second time.  They gain a +1 modification if they use a Pups to aid them (@UUID[Item.bJ65FWpzHIoosqsi]{"Pups" Mapping Device}).

THE ANTECHAMBER TUNNELS

Entering this space from an Ambulatory the PCs see a bewildering maze of multiple tunnels crisscrossing each other, all heading down.

As the PCs negotiate these tunnels they will come across a number of random chambers—rolled on the adjacent table—before they eventually either reach an iris-valve hatch in the floor that opens, leading to the Lychgate Core (if they are heading downwards), or the hatches to the Ambulatory (if they are trying to leave):

CHAMBER TABLE @DRAW[RollTable.CZvRXqlPCRuPAbDJ]{CHAMBER TABLE}
  D6   CHAMBER TABLE
  1   A cryosleep room with D66 beds lined up vertically around the walls, all empty.
  2   A wide chamber with an obsidian plinth in the middle, watched over by four carved heads.
  3   If the PCs are exploring the Lychgate, this is an empty chamber.  If they are fleeing the Xenomorphs after the confrontation at the Core, it is a Xenomorph hive chamber with D6 Facehuggers, D6 Ovomorphs, and D6 hosts.  If the PCs linger a Drone will appear, at your discretion.
  4   A room with small pools of crystal-clear water, and drapes hanging throughout.  The PCs have to push through them to progress.
  5   The centerpiece of the chamber is a three-meter-wide shaft, dripping water and full of dusty mist.  Roll D6.  On 1-3, it's on the ceiling and goes upwards, on 4-6, it's on the floor and goes down.
  6   A shrine of some sort with images and glyphs lining the walls, but too eroded to make any sense of.

THE LYCHGATE CORE

The core chamber is a 300-meter-wide sphere, with dozens of iris-valve hatches scattered around the ceiling.  There are no obvious controls, but they open when touched.  In the center of the chamber is the Core, a huge sphere that forms a surface, 100 meters below the ceiling and its hatches.  The space in between is crisscrossed by an intricate scaffold of twisted girders, pipes and small platforms.

SCAFFOLD

Built for humanoids bigger than humans, the scaffold forms a set of stairs and walkways for the Engineers to reach the surface from the hatches.  For the PCs, it requires a MOBILITY roll to clamber up or down.  A failed roll means they slip and crash into a nearby girder, taking one point of damage (armor applies).

SURFACE AND SUNKEN TRENCHES

Standing on the surface of the Core, underneath the spider's web of scaffolding, under 1.5G of gravity, is an intensely weird experience.  Being only 200 meters across the ground of the core appears to fall away from the PCs on all sides.  Gain +1 STRESS LEVEL.  The surface is crisscrossed by narrow trenches, all linked and converging on a hexagonal cynosure, the center of the Lychgate.

CYNOSURE

Sunken into the surface, the Cynosure is the Lychgate's control center.  A central chair, high-backed and looming, and surrounded by musical controls, sits between four space jockey platforms, each facing the chair.  The PCs will not be able to activate any of the musical controls even if they sit in the chair.  But if one should climb into a space jockey seat, the suit will automatically start to close over them.  Unless they immediately make a successful MOBILITY roll they are trapped inside, the suit giving them Armor Rating 12.  Roll a Stress Die at the start of every Round thereafter—on   the machine recognizes the occupant is not an Engineer and re-opens the suit.

One Perfected, Mother Ma'Kayla and six devotees are here, calmly waiting for the PCs.  See the sidebar The Fight for the Cynosure.

THE FIGHT FOR THE CYNOSURE

When the PCs arrive at the Cynosure, they find a calm scene: a Perfected (one they have already met, if they survived), Mother Ma'Kayla and six devotees are waiting for them.  They won't start any hostilities, knowing full well that the Xenomorphs are gathering in the scaffold and looking for hosts, but will defend themselves if attacked.

The PCs are swamped with telepathic images of welcome, of a joyful reunion, of hope, shrouded within a cloak of an iron willpower and utter ruthlessness.  Mother Ma'Kayla will then greet them in a non-aggressive way, and say the following:

  • She openly admits she cannot make the machine work but says “feel free to try it for yourselves.”
  • She will tell them that the Perfected have been here for months, and have always known they couldn't operate it, “but making it work wasn't the point—bringing you and your ships here was…”
  • She will try to convince them to join the Perfected: “Why bother fighting us, when you can join us and reap the joys of perfection?”
  • If the PCs refuse her offer, she will seem genuinely disappointed, but will shrug her shoulders: “It matters little, by now our people will be on their way to capture your Ìyánlá and we will soon be on our way to the Middle Heavens.”

During this scene—or as the fight unfolds, if the PCs choose to attack—the Xenomorphs' presence in the scaffolding becomes more obvious.  The PCs can make an opposed OBSERVATION roll to hear or spot movement in the scaffold, before two Xenomorphs sweep down and take two of her devotees.  Two Scouts and two Drones now close in on the PCs, intent on capturing them (use the Xenomorph Capture Attacks below).  Draw initiative.

THE XENOMORPHS AND THE HIVES

The XX121 Xenomorphs aboard the Lychgate behave a little differently from those in the core rulebook.  Four hives are being cultivated, under the overall control of an Empress, and there is competition between the hives.  These Xenomorphs are in “capture mode” with the gathering of live hosts for the hives their primary instinct.  This overrides individual self-preservation, the scouts and drones are driven to capture hosts even if they are attacked themselves.

XENOMORPH CAPTURE ATTACKS @DRAW[RollTable.3l3lwkhzbk1C3zk2]{XENOMORPH CAPTURE ATTACKS}
  D6   ATTACK
  1  

HERDING: The Xenomorph spreads its limbs, bares its teeth and shepherds the victim.  The victim must win an opposed MOBILITY roll against ten Base Dice or be forced to move wherever the Xenomorph wants—near a Facehugger, into the arms of another Drone or Scout, or somewhere else where capturing the PC is made easier.  Make an immediate Panic Roll.

  2  

NO ESCAPE: The Xenomorph pauses and hisses at its victim, before scampering away to an adjacent zone.  But the Xenomorph is only biding its time—when it acts on the next Round, it has been joined by another of the same type, and they both attack the original target.

  3  

BRING THEM DOWN: The Xenomorph sweeps with arms, legs and tail, lashing out to bring the victim to the ground.  It attacks with ten Base Dice against the target's CLOSE COMBAT.  If successful, the target is battered to the ground, drops any handheld items, suffers one point of damage and must make an immediate Panic Roll.

  4  

FACE GRAB: The Xenomorph grasps the victim's face, an opposed grappling attack with eight Base Dice.  If the Xenomorph succeeds, it does no damage, but the victim is grappled, blinded, and must make an immediate Panic Roll.  If the victim does not break the grapple, the Xenomorph's next attack is automatically #6.

  5  

CAPTURE FOR THE HIVE: The Xenomorph attacks with its venom-spiked tail, with ten Base Dice, Damage 1.  If the attack causes any damage, the Xenomorph pulls its punch so only one point of damage is inflicted, and the paralyzing venom takes effect.  The victim must make a STAMINA roll—the number of rolled is the number of Rounds they can stay up, then they fall unconscious for D6 Turns.  The paralysis can be removed with a shot of adrenaline (a MEDICAL AID roll with a medkit).

  6  

STUN THE HOST: The Xenomorph attacks the victim with nine Base Dice, Damage 1, its inner jaw flashing out.  But it's not trying to kill.  If the attack does any damage, the victim is immediately Broken and knocked unconscious by the blow.  They do not suffer any critical effect even though they are Broken, but are unconscious for D6 Turns.

CAPTURED BY THE HIVE

As the confrontation at the Cynosure progresses, the PCs may manage to escape from the Xenomorphs and rush to return to their ship, to protect Ìyánlá from the Perfected's trap.  However, if they fail to escape the Xenomorphs, they may think they are doomed, but they are not.  See the adjacent sidebar Maybe It Was Better Being Dead.

Roll on the @UUID[RollTable.CZvRXqlPCRuPAbDJ]{CHAMBER TABLE}@DRAW[RollTable.CZvRXqlPCRuPAbDJ]{Draw} to see in which type of room they awaken.  But this chamber is a Hive and they are stuck to the walls, hosts for Facehuggers.  There are five unopened Ovomorphs, many opened ones, and dead Facehuggers lying all around.  The walls are adorned with people, some long dead, some being facehugged, some just unconscious (D6 of each).  This includes Lt Colonel Sensakovic and two of her men similarly trapped.  On the floor near them are three AK-4047s and a bandolier with three reloads.

The PCs awaken with Health equal to their maximum minus one point, all the Stress they had before capture, but they have lost any items they were carrying.  Trying to break free of the bonds takes a STAMINA roll with a -3 modification.  One attempt can be made each Round, but every attempt makes noise.  Roll a Stress Die—on   they disturb a Facehugger looking for a host.  If they make a lot of noise (using the AK-4047, for example) a Drone will be alerted and arrive in D6 Rounds.

LIEUTENANT COLONEL SONIA SENSAKOVIC

@UUID[Actor.rwOS5vPUtX063xQW]{Lieutenant Colonel Sonia Sensakovic}
 

UPP COSMOS EXPLORATION CORPS

Courageous, pragmatic, and reasonable, Sensakovic commands one of the four UPP scout ships that secretly came to the Far Spinward Colonies before the Great Mother Mission.  She is learning something about the horrors in this sector of space.  She supports the UPP's desire to ensure the Great Mother Mission is a success for the people of the UPP but has misgivings about the military approach.  She has seen the Perfected firsthand and knows the threat they present.  She has come to stop the Perfected using the Lychgate to reach the Middle Heavens. If the PCs convince her they have a common goal she is pragmatic enough to join forces.

If the PCs save her and help her escape the Lychgate, she will be an ally in trying to convince General Ozolinski to stop the coup and fight the Perfected, although she knows she has been facehugged

 
STRENGTH 4, AGILITY 5, WITS 3, EMPATHY 3
HEALTH:  6
SKILLS:  Close Combat 3, Ranged Combat 2, Stamina 1, Observation 2, Command 3, Mobility 2
TALENT:  Tough, Banter
GEAR:  UPP 6B90 Armor (Armor Rating 6), AK-4047, MP-4043 Grach pistol, combat knife.

NOTE: Sensakovic's Chestburster (see Chestburster in the core rulebook) will erupt at a moment best suited to raise the tension.  However, if the PCs are especially kind to her and win her trust, she will tell them she is doomed.  The PCs can then choose to help save her, by getting her to Ìyánlá's medical center.

 
MAYBE IT WAS BETTER BEING DEAD

Read the following to your players:

“Your last thought had been one of death, a blessed and painless release.  Your life flashed before your eyes in that final moment.  But now, you sluggishly come round, and almost wish you hadn't—your worst nightmare forms before you.

This chamber is a picture of hell.  Gelatinous secretions cover the walls, floor and ceiling, slime drips, steam rises, and you are hanging from the wall, stuck fast.  Before you there are many, many eggs.  Most are open and empty.  A lot of the spindly, long-legged creatures lie dead, curled upon themselves.  One lies on the floor immediately between all of you…”

It's up to you to decide if any, none, or all the PCs have been facehugged at this point, but this scene is intended to get the players worried. If the PCs think they are carrying a Chestburster, their only hope is the medbay on the UNCSS Ìyánlá.

UNCSS ÌYÁNLÁ

Use the ship stats and the vessel layout diagram for the UNCSS ÌYÁNLÁ during the battle.

COMMAND MODULE

Houses the Bridge (which includes control of Ìyánlá's complement of nuclear weapons), Communications Center and the UN Mission Administration offices.

TRANSIT MODULE

The primary module for personnel access to and from Ìyánlá.  It contains airlock access from the SEV docking ring, hangar bays and tactical operations centers, for coordinating off-ship operations, and the security ops room, with armory.  This only contains some small arms weapons (pistols and rifles) at your discretion.

CRYOSLEEP MODULES A-D

Each module contains 2,500 sleeping colonists.

ENGINEERING

Maintenance and control of ship systems are managed from here (with the exception of drive control) as well as bulk hangers for on and off-loading cargo. UNCSS Ìyánlá's security CCTV and environment systems can be controlled from the Engineering Control room at the aft of this module, including atmosphere and power.  This module also serves as bulk storage for everything the mission needs, from food and water, rescue supplies and spare parts, to mining equipment, explosive charges, Powerloaders and anything else an enterprising PC might think of (at your discretion).

The PCs could influence the outcome of the battle by occupying the Engineering Control room and remotely tampering with Ìyánlá's systems using COMTECH — see Running Interference below.

THE THREE SPINES

Three structural corridors that run the length of the ship, one central spine for bulk equipment, and starboard and port spines for crew.  Each has a travelator both fore and aft directions, and safety bulkheads every 50 meters.

DRIVE MODULE

Everything needed to propel the ship.  The reactor complex is a suite of five rooms that surround and support the ship's reactors.  Emergency self-destruct controls are located here, but can only be authorized by UNCSS Ìyánlá's senior flight officer and Governor Abantu.

Without their authorization codes the system can be hacked, but it is hard, requiring a COMTECHth a -3 modification, and a Turn of work, during which tamper alarms will sound throughout the ship.  After that, the ship will self-destruct two Turns later.  

The Drive Module also houses the compressed fuel store.  An explosive charge placed against a critical spot (requiring a HEAVY MACHINERY roll to identify) will breach the tanks and set off a chain reaction that will cause a welter of explosions to destroy the ship in 3D6 Rounds.  The same effect can be gained by piloting an SEV into the Drive Module at the right place, requiring a HEAVY MACHINERY roll to locate the weak spot in the module's structure, and a PILOTING roll to hit it.

RUNNING INTERFERENCE

If the PCs occupy the Engineering Control room, they can use the systems there to affect the Ìyánlá's environment.  Using COMTECH, the PCs can access the CCTV system to find friends and enemies aboard the ship, or survey the situation in critical locations, such as the bridge or drive rooms.  They can track the movement of enemy forces and feed information to friendly troops.  COMTECH will enable them to open and close bulkheads and airlocks, depressurize areas, and hold the enemy to ransom.  The opportunities are only limited by the PCs' imaginations, and your discretion.  Once the PCs start doing this, they are likely to draw unwanted attention from their enemies, who will attack engineering to put a stop to them.

EVENTS

SOUNDS IN THE DARK

While aboard the Lychgate the PCs hear hissing from the darkness, and a bank of steamy fog rolls towards them from a nearby tunnel.  With a successful OBSERVATION roll, they can hear what sounds like scraping footfalls from within the mist—and gain +1 STRESS LEVEL—and their visibility is immediately reduced to SHORT range for one Turn.  At your discretion the steam can hide a Facehugger on the prowl (see Facehugger in the core rulebook).

THE DEAD UPP

As the PCs explore the Lychgate, they stumble across the dead body of a soldier in UPP 6B90 armor, his chest such a mangled mess it's impossible to tell exactly what killed him.  If the PCs search the body they find a name tag, Sergeant Maksim Yurelko, an MP-4043 pistol with 2 reloads, and a combat knife. Sgt Yurelko was one of UPP Lt Colonel Sensakovic's missing soldiers.

SNAKESKIN

As the PCs explore the Lychgate and get closer to the Core they find sticky piles of what look like sloughed-off snake skin.  They vary in size, but some are almost the size of a human.  This may bring +1 STRESS LEVELseeing it, at your discretion.

THE ENEMY OF MY ENEMY

While exploring the Lychgate, the PCs stumble across Lt Colonel Sensakovic, one UPP soldier and her AA83 Davydovich combat android (@UUID[Actor.JHdvNhLpMUEDXeoZ]{UPP Davydovich Combat Android} ).  She has lost contact with the rest of her team, although one has remained on her scout ship docked in the Outer Ring.  She is wary but may divulge that she is there to stop the Lychgate being used and can be persuaded to join forces.

OH NO YOU DON'T

Once the PCs learn of the Perfected's plan and are attempting to flee the Lychgate, Xenomorphs set off to recapture them.  Two Drones are scurrying along tunnels to get ahead.  Enter stealth mode.  Feel free to adjust the number of Xenomorphs where that will help build the tension of the chase, and to use the original Signature Attack tables.

THIS ONE IS MINE

When a PC is about to be killed or captured by a Xenomorph, another Xenomorph attacks, but it doesn't attack the PC.  The two beasts, from competing hives, square off against one another in a display of intimidating ferocity intended to make the weaker creature back down.  The PC gains +1 STRESS LEVEL, but it's their chance to run like hell.

THE CHILDREN FIND YOU

While trying to leave the Lychgate and escape being captured as Xenomorph hosts, the PCs run into a group of three devotees who will block their escape. They will say the PCs are honored to have been chosen by the Destroying Angels and shouldn't insult them by resisting.  They will fight to restrain the PCs and return them to the Xenomorphs.  At your discretion, a Xenomorph may appear, but take a devotee first!

IT'S WEIRD AND PISSED OFF

While escaping from the Lychgate the PCs take a turn and run into a big, hot and humid chamber—definitely a hive.  In the center is the Empress Xenomorph, blocking the PCs' path.  +1 STRESS LEVEL and immediate Panic Rolls for all who see this.  She will make a PSYCHIC LOVE attack every Round against a random PC (Empress Signature Attack #2, Empress Attacks), until this fails, in which case she will MIND MELT (Attack #6) the PC who resisted.  Probably time for the PCs to run like hell the other way.

HAVOC ABOARD ÌYÁNLÁ

Xenomorph Drones have been released on UNCSS Ìyánlá by the Perfected.  The PCs hear the effects of their violence over the radio and come face to face with a Xenomorph of your choice at a critical moment in the action.

PRAY FOR THE CAVALRY

If the battle for Ìyánlá needs spicing up, or the PCs need some extra help, or they have arranged for help, the cavalry finally arrives.  It might be Gorham's Marauders, or the Cooperative, throwing their troops into the fight, or UPP Colonels Drubov or Sensakovic turn up at the right moment.  Remember you have these tools to help direct the battle into the most tense and exciting finale you can.

THE BATTLE FOR ÌYÁNLÁ

The battle for Ìyánlá can play out in many different ways, depending on the actions of the PCs and what you feel builds the greatest tension for this finale.  Options include:

  • The Perfected get the upper hand and look like they will attain victory, and possession of the Ìyánlá, quickly.  This could be indicated by UPP forces falling back from key positions, the destruction of a friendly ship, or Governor Abantu giving the order to abandon ship.
  • The UPP gets the upper hand, indicated by the destruction of a Perfected ship, the capture of key locations such as the Bridge or Drive Module, or Governor Abantu orders the surrender to the UPP, to save lives.
  • The battle is a close run thing, with no one getting the upper hand as soldiers fight, the ship gets increasingly damaged, and people die.

FINALE

The epic finale of The Lost Worlds campaign plays out on and around the home of the Great Mother Mission itself, the UNCSS Ìyánlá.  In space there will be numerous small ships from Ìyánlá, including the UNCSS Umsindisi and UNCSS Chimata-no-kami.  There are four Heliades-class vessels from the Children of the Two Divines, docked or trying to dock with Ìyánlá, boarding their attackers to take the ship.

COMMS CHATTER

The radio waves are full of comms chatter as a result of the fighting—the PCs can learn what is happening by hacking into these comms with a successful COMTECHom aboard the Solovetsky Island, or a suitable console aboard the Ìyánlá, or using a Seegson P-DAT (see Diagnostics and Display in the core rulebook).  You can add whatever information you feel the PCs need to make this final battle as exciting as possible.

THREE WORLD EMPIRE

Colonel David Buston and Lynna Young-Hee put aside their differences and join the UNISC security forces fighting the UPP's attempted coup.

UNITED AMERICAS

Valentina Berezi and the UA contingent aboard the Ìyánlá are glad the gloves are off and it's not the UA's fault—they resist the UPP with everything they have.

WEYLAND-YUTANI

Kamal Vartouhi, in best Weyland-Yutani style, secretly negotiates with General Ozolinski to make sure the company comes out of this shit-show smelling of roses, however the battle turns out.  Gaius, however, remains neutral and keeps the Great Mother Mission's best interests at heart.

THE OTHER CORPORATE INTERESTS

Hyperdyne, Omni-Tech Resources and Kelland Mining realize they are in over their heads and want nothing to do with the fighting.  They all work to swipe whatever valuable discoveries are in the Ìyánlá's science labs and quarantine bays and get off the ship.

BATTLE DAMAGE

To reflect the damage the ship is taking from the battle, roll on the Minor Component Damage table (see Minor Component Damage in the core rulebook) once per Turn after the battle starts.  There should be three rolls before the PCs even reach the ship.  Narrate these results into the ongoing story of the battle for the Ìyánlá.

DESTROYING THE ÌYÁNLÁ
The pcs may decide the only way to stop the perfected winning is to destroy the ìyánlá.  There are several ways they can achieve this:
  • Set the self-destruct sequence using the controls in the Drive Module.  This takes one Turn and will destroy the ship two Turns after that.
  • Set an explosive charge to destroy the compressed fuel store in the Drive Module.  This will destroy the ship in 3D6 Rounds.
  • Crash the Solovetsky Island into the Drive Module which will destroy the ship in 3D6 Rounds.
  • Crash the Solovetsky Island into any other ship's module which will cause the ship to break up in 3D6 Turns and be fully destroyed in 3D6 Shifts.
  • Take control of the Ìyánlá's bridge and either detonate one of the ship's store of nukes, or crash the colony ship into the crushing depths of Ojo.
I CAN'T LET YOU DO THAT

Two Working Joe androids (@UUID[Actor.uCywa65Th8V0rGlD]{Working Joe} ) will see that the PCs are attempting to self-destruct the Ìyánlá or blow up the fuel tanks or intend to crash the Solovetsky Island into the colony ship.  They approach saying: “This activity is highly dangerous, for your own safety I cannot allow you to continue,” and will use non-lethal force to restrain the PCs and stop them completing their task.

DEFENDING THE ÌYÁNLÁ
The battle for the ship will play out in many locations.  The table below explains what the UPP forces, and the Perfected and their devotees, are trying to achieve at the point the PCs enter the action.  You as GM will need to decide, and narrate, the action in some areas to further the excitement of this final confrontation.  This should be driven by the actions of the PCs and the plans they come up with—throw extra challenges in their way or remove a challenge that stands in the way of a great idea.  For example, if the PCs want to go to the Reactor Room, they will have little chance against all the enemy forces listed there, so narrate the battle that sees the opposing forces destroy each other and gives the PCs a fighting chance.
HOSTILE FORCES

THE TWO DIVINES

METAPUZZLE CLUE #1—DATABASE READ-OUT FROM HMCSS JANKU

HMCSS JANKU SHIP’S LOG

NAVIGATION SYSTEMS—OFFICER ACCESS AUTHORIZED…….

NAVIGATION DATA LAYER ACCESSED

  • PRIMARY DATABASE DELETED
  • SECONDARY DATABASE DELETED
  • FACTORY RESET
  • AUXILIARY AND EMERGENCY BEACON DATA DELETED
  • NAVIGATION DATA LAYER DELETED

SYSTEM RE-BOOT

  • NO NAVIGATIONAL DATA FOUND
  • PRIMARY, SECONDARY, AUXILIARY AND EMERGENCY DATA NOT FOUND
  • SHIP DRIVE SYSTEMS—ENABLED
  • WARNING—FLIGHT OPERATIONS WITHOUT NAVIGATION DATA ARE NOT ADVISED
  • COMMUNICATIONS SYSTEMS ONLINE—SIGNAL O/G “Granddaughter, Granddaughter, this is Uncle Five reporting in. We found the outpost on Gorham Colony, no resistance. The people made a dash for their storm cellar the minute they realized we’d spotted them. Only one functional ship. The job is done, no problems—one less set of navigation data for those bastards to get their hands on. See you at the rendezvous. Uncle Five out.”

pages.name: CLUE #3—TRANSLATION OF THE ENGINEER HOLO-GLYPHS IN THE GALLERY OF THE AGES

text.content:
• “THIS GALLERY IS TESTAMENT TO OUR INGENUITY—OUR INTELLIGENCE AND OUR EFFORTS—”
  • “BUT ALSO TO OUR FAILURE—WE MUST NOT BE TOO PRIDEFUL IN OUR ACHIEVEMENTS WHILE THEY TURN ON US—WE MUST BE MINDFUL OF OUR HUBRIS THAT WE COULD CONTROL THAT WHICH WE CREATED—WE COULD NOT—”
  • “WE CAN NOT—THIS HALL WILL STAND IN PERPETUITY—A MONUMENT TO OUR BRILLIANCE—BUT ALSO A MONUMENT TO OUR IMPOTENCE—”
  • “WE MUST NOT MOURN THAT WHICH WE HAVE LOST—BUT LOOK TO THE FUTURE—”
  • “SO WE WILL DEPART—HARNESS THE LYCHGATE ONE LAST TIME BEFORE CASTING ITS GLORIOUS POWER INTO THE DARKNESS OF THE PAST—LEAVING NO PATH FOR OUR PERFECTED CHILDREN TO FOLLOW—CASTING THEM INTO OUR PAST—”
  • “TO BEGIN AGAIN—”

pages.name: CLUE #4—TRANSLATION OF THE ENGINEER HIEROGLYPH IN THE PYRAMID

text.content:
• “AND THAT ONE CREATION—ALONGSIDE ALL OTHER MARVELS—SHALL STAND APART—AS OUR MASTERPIECE TO ECLIPSE ALL MASTERPIECES—”
  • “BAR ONE—NOTWITHSTANDING THE GROTESQUE FEATS UPON WHICH WE HAVE SHOWERED OUR BRILLIANCE—”
  • “WE CAN NOT—THIS HALL WILL STAND IN PERPETUITY—A MONUMENT TO OUR BRILLIANCE—BUT ALSO A MONUMENT TO OUR IMPOTENCE—”
  • “LISTEN TO ME—FOR IN ITS SINGULAR SUBSTANCE THE BEHEMOTH HOLDS ITS OWN SOLEMNITY—A RING BUT NOT A RING—A CYLINDER BUT NOT A CYLINDER—TO OCCUPY ITS PLACE BUT NOT OCCUPY IT—TO INHABIT A PLACE AND YET INHABIT ANOTHER—TO STEP THROUGH AND ACHIEVE THAT TRAVERSE—TO JOURNEY WHERE WE WILL—TO JOURNEY AT A WHIM—TO JOURNEY AGAINST THE PROTEST OF CREATION—THIS LYCHGATE IS THE MARVEL OF MARVELS—”
  • “EXCEPT THAT WHICH ELUDES US EVEN NOW—”

• The Engineer structure—the Lychgate—orbits a super gas giant. The Orrery data provides spatial coordinates but to decode, analyze and identify where the data refers to will require the processing power of DA/UT/UR aboard Solovetsky Island.
  • Arzu, the moon of KOI-2702.07, the gas giant called Palmyra, is highlighted on the Orrery. An interstellar trajectory between it and the Lychgate has been calculated and overlaid on the projection.
  • Engineer hieroglyphs float within the stars and systems. Translation:
  • —THE LYCHGATE IS OUR HOPE OF A FUTURE—ITS LOCATION TO BE PROTECTED FROM OUR CHILDREN—ACCESS TO THIS INFORMATION MUST BE WITHHELD—

pages.name: CLUE #6—TRANSLATION OF THE ENGINEER HIEROGLYPH IN THE GUARDIAN SHIP

text.content:
• “WE MUST NOT MOURN THAT WHICH WE HAVE LOST—LOOK UPON OUR WORKS MY FRIEND AND REJOICE—”
  • “THE SOLACE OF OUR ACHIEVEMENT IS LOST UPON US—FOR WE HAVE CREATED IN SUCH ABUNDANCE—IN THE IMAGE OF OURSELVES—IN THE IMAGE OF OUR ANGELS—IN THE QUEST FOR PERFECTION—BUT NOT FROM THESE MULTITUDES DO WE FIND THE JOY OF THAT WHICH WE SEEK TO RE-CREATE—”
  • “THE PEDESTRIAN—THE DANCER—THE PERFECT—ALL OUR SCION AND YET ALL OUR ADVERSITY—REVELRY IN THE WONDERS OF OUR TRIUMPH SHOULD OVERFLOW YOUR RELIQUARY—”
  • “BUT HOW CAN IT—FOR THE UNGRATEFUL CHILD TURNS ON US—FORCES US TO RELINQUISH THIS PLACE—AS THEY HUNGER FOR THE PERFECT WORLD—TO RE-CRAFT ALL WORLDS AS PERFECT WORLDS—TO USE OUR LYCHGATE TO SPREAD THEIR CONTAGION—”
  • “YET WHILE OUR PROGENY AND WE REVERE THIS ANGEL OF OUR EFFORTS—WE MUST BEAR THE REGRET OF OUR UNGRATEFUL CHILD—AND BEAR THE BLAME FOR UNLEASHING IT—AND RETREAT INTO THE DARKNESS GLADLY—FOR THE REAL DESTROYER OF OUR HEARTS REMAINS LOCKED IN THE LORE OF YESTERYEAR—”

“It is in our nature to explore, to reach out into the unknown.  The only true failure would be not to explore at all.”

—ERNEST SHACKLETON

The PCs are ordered to search for the missing ship UNCSS Typhoon, sent to survey two moons of the gas giant KOI-2702.07, called Azizo and Arzu.  They intercept the Typhoon dead in space, its crew missing after the Perfected tried to capture it.  They trace its path back to the two moons, to find one swamped by the Perfected's living Proto-Hive.  They must explore a derelict Engineer Juggernaut and confront the Perfected, to save the Typhoon's crew, and escape alive to raise the alarm.

WHAT IS GOING ON?

The UNCSS Typhoon, under Captain Leland Barton, was ordered to the KOI-2702 system, to survey the moons of the seventh planet, a gas giant designated KOI-2702.07, called Palmyra.  Amongst the dozens of tiny, rocky moons Palmyra has two of note—Azizo and Arzu.  Azizo is a small watery world, so far untouched by any hands.  Arzu, however, was an Engineer outpost attacked by the Perfected many thousands of years ago.  Preferring death to infection, many Engineers committed suicide.  But some were too late and became Perfected themselves.

Millennia passed, and the Perfected infection, the Proto-Hive, on Arzu slowly spread across the planet while the Perfected themselves slumbered—until the Typhoon arrived and disturbed them.  Too late did Barton and his crew realize what was happening.  Their ship was infected by the Proto-Hive even as it fled.  All the crew bar one escaped in the two lifeboats, one—with Captain Barton and five crew—launching quickly and falling back to Arzu, the other—with three crew, including Barton's wife, Anne Bowers—launching later, and managing to reach Azizo before it crashed.

The one crew member who was left aboard the Typhoon, Alice Dudgeon (the sister of the UNCSS Solovetsky Island's pilot, Andi Dudgeon), could not let the Typhoon fall into the hands of these monsters.  She overloaded the reactor and flooded the ship with radiation, killing the Perfected and Children of the Two Divines, and sacrificing herself.  However, the radiation only fed the growing Proto-Hive that spread through the ship, and warped the positronic brains of the vessel's Working Joe androids, who are now hostile.

On Azizo, three crew survived the crash, and await rescue.  On Arzu, however, the lifeboat with Captain Barton and the other survivors was found by the Perfected.  While some resisted—two of whom were killed by the Perfected—Barton was infected and became one of them, a Stage I Abomination Pathogen Carrier ().  They were taken to the Engineer Juggernaut, the Perfected's base on Arzu.  Having failed in the attempt to capture the Typhoon, they send a distress beacon from the lifeboat, hoping to draw another ship to them, and lay the trail to the Lychgate, the honey trap that will secure their passage to the Middle Heavens.

WHAT'S THE STORY MOTHER?

The PCs receive an unscheduled video call from Gaius aboard UNCSS Ìyánlá.

“I'm sad to report that we have lost contact with your sister ship, UNCSS Typhoon, under Captain Leland Barton.  They had been ordered to survey KOI-2702.07, a gas giant with two moons possibly suitable for colonization.  I am sending a Throop rescue ship but you are the closest vessel by several days.  Your orders are to proceed there immediately, find and assist the Typhoon and her crew should they need help, then complete the surveys of the two moons.  I assume you understand?

The moons are called Azizo and Arzu.  From the preliminary scans Azizo is a sub-Earth sized planet, probably low G, with significant surface water.  Arzu on the other hand is a super-Earth, likely to have high G and seems much drier.  Colonization recommendations for both, please.

Good luck Solovetsky Island, and give my regards to Captain Barton when you find him.”

CLUES TO THE METAPUZZLE

The PCs can learn the fifth campaign clue during this expedition, by reaching the Navigator Orrery on the Engineer Juggernaut and witnessing the orrery display.

KICKING OFF THE ACTION

The action starts with the PCs heading in the direction of KOI-2702.  As soon as they drop out of FTL, they detect the transponder of the UNCSS Typhoon.  It has a minimal level of power, but is drifting, both its lifeboats are missing, and it is emitting Weak radiation.  Any attempt to communicate is met with silence.

As a Magellan-class J SEV, the layout of the Typhoon is identical to that of the Solovetsky Island.  The Typhoon's crew are all fitted with Personal Data Transmitters (PDTs).  A successful COMTECH roll will only detect Alice Dudgeon's tracker on board, and her life signs are very weak.

SHORE PARTY

The ship's pilot, Andi Dudgeon, insists he joins as Alice Dudgeon is his younger sister—he is distraught and desperate to save her.  As the expedition progresses, he will have a burning desire for vengeance against those who attacked his sister.  As the Typhoon is drifting, @UUID[Actor.t54dsoJAGzR3S3IC]{Davor Koblenz} , the Solovetsky Island's mechanic, suggests he also should join the boarding party.

UNCSS TYPHOON

The Typhoon's DA/UT/UR has been destroyed by the radiation, along with many other systems, although the basics of life support and emergency power still work.  The ship's @UUID[Actor.uCywa65Th8V0rGlD]{Working Joes} , nicknamed Jake and Elwood by the crew, have suffered severe damage to their programming.  They are now intensely protective of their ship and hostile to anyone that boards it—see the event Don't Ignore the Joes.

The residual radioactive effects can be felt as Weak radiation (see a>

Radiation in the core rulebook) on board the ship.

ENGINE CONTROL AND THE REACTOR

The doors to this area have been sealed shut from the inside, by Alice Dudgeon, and require a HEAVY MACHINERY roll and a Turn of work to open.  If this fails, they can use a breaching charge from the Solovetsky Island's stores to blow it open.  The reactor is active but not running at full capacity, and its radiation protections have been deactivated.  These can be restored with a HEAVY MACHINERY roll and a Shift of work.  Any attempt to fire up the ship's engines before then increases the radiation released to Strong radiation, and use of FTL brings Extreme radiation.

Alice Dudgeon is here, unconscious.  She is scorched and withered, and very close to death.  When the PCs find her, she needs to be stabilized with a MEDICAL AID roll with a -2 modification, or she will die.  If this fails, her only chance is to get to the medbay aboard the Solovetsky Island within one Turn.  To increase the tension of this race to save her life, Andi Dudgeon will get angry or break down during the rescue.  

The engineering log shows that Dudgeon deliberately removed the safety protocols for the Typhoon's reactor and flooded the ship with Extreme radiation for one Turn.

BRIDGE

There are two Perfected (see The Dead Perfected below), and five devotees here, all killed by intense radiation sickness.  They had been trying to access the nav computer when they died.  The scene is grim, and all seeing it gain +1 STRESS LEVEL.  

A check of the Typhoon's last log entry shows the ship arrived safely in the KOI-2702 system, proceeded to survey the gas giant Palmyra and her moons before inserting into orbit around Arzu.  A COMTECH roll will allow the PCs to see that the ship's trajectory is a straight line away from the gas giant.

DECK C

The Proto-Hive (The Living Proto-Hive) has grown such that it has covered all of Deck C, with a Proto-Hive Node in every zone. Its tendrils are working their way to Deck B, entwining around the mesh walkways that are above, and look down into, the cargo bay on Deck C.  While the Nodes and tendrils could be burned away using an incinerator, the Proto-Hive has already merged with the ship at the molecular level.  The PCs will have to brave the Proto-Hive and its Nodes if they want to access this deck.

EQUIPMENT STORES

The Typhoon has the same stores aboard, in its various storage rooms, as the Solovetsky Island.  These can be found by the PCs, at your discretion.

THE DEAD PERFECTED

Despite the scars of the intense radiation sickness that killed them, the genderless Perfected appear serene and majestic, their lithe forms a little too long, their bodies just a little out of proportion.  Their silver-gray skin lies taught over a biomechanical series of tube-like bulges and protrusions, almost an extra dark skeleton.  If the PCs choose to autopsy either of them, they will find their anatomy is nothing like that of a human, and seems random and disordered.

THE DOOMED TYPHOON

Alice Dudgeon used the reactor's radiation to kill the Perfected that boarded the ship, and the Children of the Two Divines who came with them, before they could extract the navigation data for the Middle Heavens from the Typhoon's computer.  However, while this killed these enemies, it only nourished the living Proto-Hive that infected the ship.  The entire ship will become a Proto-Hive within two Shifts, unless the PCs stop it by overloading the reactor with a HEAVY MACHINERY roll and self-destructing the Typhoon (which would happen one Turn later), but Jake and Elwood, the ship's @UUID[Actor.uCywa65Th8V0rGlD]{Working Joes} will try to prevent this.

THE TWO MOONS OF PALMYRA

AZIZO

Azizo is a watery world of great seas and lakes, with a scattering of island archipelagos.  Volcanically active, frequent eruptions pump a fine dust of iron oxide into the air, giving the high atmosphere a red, hazy tinge.  The planet is cool—temperatures never rise much above 12°C or below 5°C, except at the poles.  The gravity is 0.5G, causing gravity dyspraxia (Conditions).

ARZU

Arzu is a cold and heavy super-Earth, with a dense atmosphere and little liquid water on its surface.  Mountainous and riven with crevasses and canyons, it presents a challenging environment.  The temperature hovers just above freezing, except at the poles where it falls much lower.  Gravity is double that of Earth—the PCs may suffer from gravity dyspraxia (Conditions).  As these planets are moons of a gas giant their day length is eccentric.  The reflection from Palmyra illuminates the moons as well as the red glow from their giant star.  For half their orbital periods the moons never get darker than twilight.

ARRIVAL

When the PCs arrive in the vicinity of Palmyra, they can detect the distress signal from Lifeboat One, coming from the northern hemisphere of Azizo.

AZIZO

Azizo is a pristine planet, an excellent candidate for colonization, should the PCs wish to explore this option.

The lifeboat has landed in the northern hemisphere (Northern Hemisphere West on the planet map), and the PCs can home in on it.  They can detect the PDT traces of the remaining crew with a COMTECH roll:

  • Security Officer Anne Bowers — alive, the wife of Captain Leland Barton
  • Pilot Anka Karsen — alive, but weak life signs
  • ICC Inspector David Gideon — alive, but weak life signs

Attempts to communicate will raise Bowers.  She explains that Karsen and Gideon were severely injured in the crash and are both sedated to keep them stable.  They have landed in a shallow archipelago of a vast sea, with thousands of tiny islands and lagoons, and have been steadily surrounded by slow-moving plant life that is infested with huge insects that are highly aggressive if disturbed.  They are trapped.

LANDFALL

The closest island big enough to land the ship is 15 km from the lifeboat, but the PCs have amphibious Daihotai 8x8 tractors aboard the Solovetsky Island to cover the distance.  Landing is difficult, with a -1 modification to the PILOTING roll.  A failed roll causes D3 Damage.

LIFEBOAT ONE

The lifeboat is battered but has a full complement of emergency supplies.

BIOLAB

Karsen and Gideon are in MedPods, keeping them alive after their serious injuries from the fight aboard the Typhoon and the crash landing.  Once removed from the MedPods they will need to be stabilized with a MEDICAL AID roll to evacuate them from the lifeboat.  If this fails they will die unless they can get to the Solovetsky Island's medbay within one Turn.

THE INSECT SWARM

The lifeboat is surrounded by a four-zone Swarm, Health 20 (see The Swarm in the core rulebook).  However, this Swarm will only attack as a swarm if provoked, by making a big disturbance, driving a tractor through it, or attacking it with fire or explosives.  If a PC tries to walk through the infested plants they must make a MOBILITY roll per zone, with a -1 modification for the bad footing.  If the roll is failed, the PC disturbs D3 insects that attack.  If the PC panics and scores a result of 11 or more, their panic causes a full swarm attack.  Draw initiative.

THE SWARMS OF AZIZO
The Swarms of Azizo are not immediately hostile, although an individual insect can be a nasty pest.  A single insect attacks with three Base Dice, Damage 1 (armor piercing), Speed 1, Health 1.  A PC's CLOSE COMBAT attack that misses an insect may provoke more insects into attacking.  Roll a Stress Die—on   D3 more wasps join the attack.  If a weapon is fired, or a PC gets six or more insects attacking them at any one time, a full Swarm response is provoked.
