THE METAPUZZLE

The six clues to the Metapuzzle will ultimately allow the PCs to reach the following understanding:

The Perfected spread an infection that wipes out life as the PCs know it, and they are intent on spreading it across the galaxy.  But they need ships robust enough to travel the 30-parsec distance to the Middle Heavens, and the navigational data to make the journey—they are actively searching for both. However, the Perfected also believe that an Engineer relic, called “the Lychgate,” will allow them to instantly make the crossing.  This gate can be found in orbit around a super gas giant, called Ojo, in the KOI-1938 system.

But there is a twist—the Perfected know full-well they cannot operate the Lychgate, but it's a technological prize of such value they reason the humans will flock to it once they know it exists.  The Perfected will use the Lychgate as a honey trap, to lure Ìyánlá to them so they can capture it and all its bounty.

Each clue is listed here with details on where the PCs can find it, and handouts are provided for your players (METAPUZZLE CLUES).  As the campaign is a sandbox and the expeditions can be played in any order, some care is needed to ensure the clues build the Metapuzzle picture at the right pace.  The key clue is #5, which gives the PCs the spatial coordinates for the Lychgate itself.  The clue states that DA/UT/UR 2200 aboard the Solovetsky Island is required to decode the coordinates, so it is entirely in your power to decide when that decoding is done, and the coordinates become available.  This should happen towards the end or after you have played the first six missions, setting the PCs up for the race to the Lychgate and the finale.

THE SIX CLUES

#1 DATABASE READ-OUT FROM HMCSS JANKU: Found during the expedition Home Sweet Home, this clue explains that Gorham's Marauders are wiping navigation data from any ships and databases they can find and trying to stop the Perfected from spreading across space.  The PCs should come to understand that there is a threat within the Far Spinward colonies that is seeking navigation data and wants to reach the Middle Heavens.  

#2 MOTHER MA'KAYLA'S CRUMPLED LETTER: Found during the expedition To Go My Own Dark Way, this clue explains that the Children of the Two Divines are looking for ship parts and navigation data, are actively helping the Perfected, and have brought them some “gifts' (XX121 Ovomorphs) from the Middle Heavens.  The PCs learn about the Children of the Two Divines, that they answer to someone or something they revere, and some information on the history of the Engineers and Xenomorphs taken from the journal of the Grand Seer, Jannes Ruedi.  

#3 THE ENGINEER HOLO-GLYPHS IN THE ENGINEER CITY: This clue is found during the expedition Leave All Else to The Gods, and hints that the Engineers created the Xenomorphs and the Perfected.  Realizing they could not control their creations, the Engineers fled this sector of space using a device they called the Lychgate.  

#4 THE ENGINEER HIEROGLYPH IN THE PYRAMID: Found during the expedition The Devil Lives In Still Waters, this clue reveals that the Lychgate exists, and is some kind of gigantic Engineer relic that allows for instantaneous travel to anywhere in the universe.

#5 INTERPRETATION OF THE HOLOGRAM ORRERY ABOARD THE ENGINEER JUGGERNAUT: Found during the expedition Against A Sea Of Troubles, this clue gives the coded coordinates for the Lychgate, and shows it orbits a super gas giant.  It makes it clear that the Perfected intend to go there and that the Engineers wanted to keep this artifact from them.  The PCs need DA/UT/UR 2200 to decode the coordinates, and this may take some time.  

#6 THE ENGINEER HIEROGLYPH IN THE GUARDIAN SHIP WRECKAGE: Found during the expedition Let Sleeping Gods Lie, this clue reveals that the Engineers created the Perfected and the Xenomorphs, that the Perfected forced the Engineers to flee from the Far Spinward Colonies region of space, and both the Engineers and the Perfected worship or revere the xenomorph, what they call the Destroying Angel.

DOWNTIME

EXPEDITION REPORTS

At the end of an expedition, the crew are expected to file a report.  In game terms, the PCs report back to the android Gaius on UNCSS Ìyánlá (either in person or on comms), and he assesses the bonus situation.  This should be role-played with the GM and should cover:

  • A debriefing of the expedition.
  • Recommendations for the future of the planet or colony in question.
  • Requests for crew replacements, re-fuelling and supplies / repairs.
  • Requests for bonuses based on:
    • Activities over and above the call of duty—“that wasn't in my contract!” (1–2 extra weeks' salary)
    • The discovery of something of financial or scientific value but without samples—“we found something weird and pissed off, here are the co-ordinates!” (1–3 extra weeks' salary)
    • The acquisition of specimens or samples of potentially valuable assets—“we found this….  Quick! Grab it before it runs off again!” (1–10 extra weeks' salary, depending on the asset)
    • The acquisition of xenobiological or Engineer specimens or artifacts—“if this don't kill me, I'm gonna buy me a planet to retire on!” (10+ weeks' extra salary)

The PCs should justify their claims and defend against the claims of others (PCs and NPCs) who may try to steal their credit, and their bonuses.  This may require an opposed MANIPULATION test.  However, the PCs should always feel hard done by, and aggrieved at the low rewards their hard work and personal risk seems to earn.  Once this is complete the PCs should decide where to survey next, possibly guided by the GM through the NPC Gaius.

DOWNTIME INCIDENTS

Between expeditions there's likely to be time to kill, either through re-supplies and repairs, or time traveling to the next expedition.  Aside from spending their hard-earned XP, there are two things that can happen:

  1. Each player takes center stage and narrates a scene involving their PC, how they are using their downtime, who they are spending it with and what they are doing.  It might be an emotional moment (eg, checking on their husband in cryosleep on UNCSS Ìyánlá, or bearing their all over the horrors of the last expedition), or funny, exciting or plain mundane.  But whatever the moment is, it belongs to that player and their PC, although the other players should be encouraged to build and develop the scene if they wish.
  2. They can hear about how the rest of the Great Mother Mission is faring.  Roll on the table on and fold the results into your growing campaign.

SESSION ZERO

“Session Zero” is the thrilling start to the campaign.  Your players should create their PCs together and decide what roles each will play aboard their ship, the UNCSS Solovetsky Island.  They will discover their political affiliations, family connections and learn of their NPC crewmates.  They should be given Mission Contract and Colony Status handouts (09.00a PLAYER HANDOUTS), giving them information on the Great Mother Mission and the eighteen colonies the mission is going to re-discover.

Once your players have had the time to ready themselves and ask any questions about the mission and their role in it, read the following text out loud:

WHAT'S THE STORY MOTHER?

Your Magellan SEV docks gently with the UNCSS Ìyánlá, secured to its docking ring alongside the three other SEVs—the Umsindisi, Chimata-no-kami and Typhoon.  As clamps thunder quietly shut, you send a cheerful farewell message to Ìyánlá's captain, Tadesse Kondwani. “See you in two years!” comes the reply from the ship's android, Gaius, before you head to the cryo deck.  Your ship's DA/UT/UR flickers her lights, and your canopy starts to close.  The last thing you see is the distorted image of your ship's Working Joes—James and Miss Sophie, as you call them—and the last thing you hear is one of them whisper: “sleep well.”

102 weeks and 5 days later, and thousands of W-Y dollars banked already—this is the way to make a living! Well, you think that until hyper-sickness kicks in and for the next twenty minutes you wish you were dead.  An hour later and you're ready for the post-arrival briefing.  You and the rest of the crew file quietly through the airlock, board the immense UNCSS Ìyánlá where you eventually take a seat in the spacious mess hall, alongside your fellow pioneers. The room buzzes with conversation, one hundred voices all talking about the same things: Have we arrived? What news from home? This coffee is still shit.

Then Governor Kholwa Abantu stands at the front, and calls for quiet:

“First, the good news.  We have all arrived on the fringes of the Far Spinward Colonies without a hitch.  Home is now more than 30 parsecs behind us.”

“But talking of home, here's the bad news.  The United Americas and Union of Progressive Peoples are at war.  Fighting has broken out across the frontier and hostilities are ongoing.  Furthermore, the world of New Albion has broken away from the 3WE and while there are no hostilities yet, some fear it may come to blows.  But the political stupidities of our governments do not change the situation here.  We are a United Nations expedition and have a mission to fulfill for the good of humankind, so leave your petty political rivalries back in the Middle Heavens!”

“And talking of bad news.  We have not picked up any signals, as we had hoped we might.  What this says about the fates of the people out here, we won't know until we explore.  But as a precaution, for now we will keep two of our SEVs with Ìyánlá and send only two—Typhoon and Solovetsky Island—to reconnoiter the old colonies.  Good luck everyone, and please be careful out there.”

There's a moment's silence, then pandemonium breaks out right before you.  Valentina Berezi of the United Americas leaps to her feet, pointing her finger at the UPP General, Nurlan Ozolinski: “We can never trust you UPP bastards!” Ozolinski pulls himself to his impressive height, tense, restrained.  Others start to shout, while Colonel Buston and Lynna Young-Hee of the 3WE try to intervene until they fall into an argument about the New Albion Protectorate. W-Y Director Kamal Vartouhi stands still to one side, arms crossed, an onlooker, while Governor Abantu waves his arms in a futile attempt to restore peace.  Alecto Throop, the freelance search and rescue captain sitting next to you, leans over—calm and collected—she says:

“Didn't think I'd have to rescue people from inside the mothership!”

KICKING OFF THE CAMPAIGN

The campaign kicks off right here.  If the PCs don't intervene the arguments will escalate, and blows will be exchanged between lower ranked UA and UPP officers.  The likes of Valentina Berezi and Nurlan Ozolinski will control themselves, just.

At a suitable moment, the PCs will notice the android Gaius has sidled up to them.  He says: “Quite a display, wouldn't you say? I'm not convinced that these missions shouldn't be android only, if you ask me.” He hands them a data disc: “Your assignments.  I see little point in delaying your departure any further.  I'll brief you in detail when you're en route.”

The disc contains details of the colonies from the Colony Status handout, with three expedition locations of your choice (not including the finale), highlighted by Gaius as the PCs' initial assignments, to be tackled in any order they please.  Once an expedition has been completed Gaius should give them another assignment, so the PCs have three options for as long as possible.  You should feel free to add colony locations not covered by the expeditions (using the tables in Your Colony to generate a scenario for those locations) or send your PCs on colonial survey expeditions to find new planets to colonize (using the rules on to generate new star systems and worlds), but these are entirely optional—you do not have to do this to have a full and exciting frontier campaign.

EXPEDITIONS

HOME SWEET HOME: Gorham Colony, KOI-2650.01.  An arid and dusty planet, a mining colony of reportedly 1 million colonists in 2100.  The PCs discover just one settlement of only two families, but their arrival re-ignites a deadly feud.  They must prevent the feud killing the last survivors of Gorham Colony, as the planet itself tries to kill them all.  

TO GO MY OWN DARK WAY: Dylan Colony, KOI-784.01.  A humid world of extreme temperatures and tropical jungles, with extensive caverns exploited for mining in 2100.  The PCs find a society on a knife-edge—a primitive community terrorized by feral barbarians, refugees from the Children of the Two Divines begging for help, and the death cult come to demand their wayward children back.  

LEAVE ALL ELSE TO THE GODS: Sent on a colonization expedition, the PCs find they are not the first to arrive here.  But, under orders from Governor Abantu himself, they establish a new colony.  As the colony lays down roots the PCs make a terrible discovery—the ancient ruins of an Engineer city, and the horrors that await therein.  They must confront the secrets of the city, to save themselves and the new colony.

THE DEVIL LIVES IN STILL WATERS: May Outpost, KOI-610.01.  The PCs find a working community, but on the verge of insurrection.  Can they bring peace to this conflicted society, prevent the UPP from taking control, and explore the secrets—and avoid the dangers—of an ancient Engineer pyramid, revealed by an earthquake?

AGAINST A SEA OF TROUBLES: The PCs are ordered to search for the missing ship, UNCSS Typhoon, and find it dead in space, its crew missing after the Perfected tried to capture it.  They trace its path back to the two moons of a gas giant, to find one swamped by the Perfected's living Proto-Hive.  They must explore a derelict Engineer Juggernaut and confront the Perfected to save the Typhoon's crew and escape alive to raise the alarm.  

LET SLEEPING GODS LIE: Pelican Colony, KOI-947.01.  Once a glorious agricultural paradise, Pelican Colony has been swept clean by solar radiation.  The UNCSS Solovetsky Island finds a crashed ship—Gorham's Marauders—come to hunt the Perfected.  Harassed by automatons trying to protect them, the PCs mount an expedition to an Engineer Guardian ship and must face the horrors that lurk in the ancient vessel.

IN THE SHADOW OF PERFECTION: In orbit around the planet Ojo, KOI-1938.  The finale, as the PCs follow the clues to the Metapuzzle, and find the Engineer Lychgate.  They face the Fulfremmen and Xenomorph hives aboard the structure, as both the UPP and the Perfected execute their plans to capture UNCSS Ìyánlá for themselves.

CAMPAIGN EVENTS

These campaign level events are intended to increase the tension of your campaign, as well as signal a countdown to the climactic last expedition, In the Shadow of Perfection.  Some can be introduced at any time, or even played more than once, while others are intended to be introduced as the campaign matures.  Guidance is provided in each event.

THROOP TO THE RESCUE

To be used at any time.  Throop R&R will send one of their vessels, a standard Model CM-90S Corvus (see CM-90S Corvus in the core rulebook, but with an FTL rating of 4), commanded by Alecto Throop herself, to rescue the PCs.  How this plays out will depend on the PCs' circumstances that require their rescue, but the rescue should go wrong, or be hampered in some way.  The GM should decide how many days away rescue is, remembering that the PCs will have to hold out against whatever terrors are facing them until help arrives.

QUARANTINE IS NOT A DIRTY WORD

To be played at any time, but ideally when the PCs have made a big find and want to hide it from the ICC.  The ICC have had enough with the endemic efforts to subvert their regulations and pull the wool over their eyes.  The ICC Inspector, Tan Blatchman, orders all acquisitions and finds to be impounded indefinitely and placed into quarantine, and instructs the security team to enforce his ruling.  All finds, specimens and samples that are aboard the PCs' ship, or brought aboard, will be thoroughly double-checked, and any that might contravene ICC quarantine rules (such as Xenomorph samples or eggs, or any Engineer tech) will be seized.  The security officer on board, Hamidah Amir, is torn—she supports the ICC, but also sees the prospects for extra bonuses. How will the PCs try to convince Blatchman or Amir to turn a blind eye to their misdemeanors?

MU/TH/UR KNOWS BEST

To be played at any time.  Weyland-Yutani, in the form of Gaius and MU/TH/UR 9000, suspect that the PCs are not telling them the truth about the treasures they have discovered.  They put pressure on the PCs to supply their finds only to W-Y, and hint that if this was done without the oversight of the ICC or knowledge of the other factions, the PCs would be very well rewarded indeed.  If the PCs decline, or agree but have no intention of following through, MU/TH/UR takes control of the ship's Working Joe androids, and uses them to covertly search for, and remove, any exciting finds without the PCs' knowledge (with MU/TH/UR's oversight, the Working Joes have OBSERVATION 7, COMTECH 6 and MOBILITY 5).  When the PCs next check they may find their exciting discoveries are gone.

BAITING THE BEAR

To be played at any time.  The PCs hear of unrest on the UNCSS Ìyánlá, with elements of the UA contingent skirmishing with UPP loyalists.  It hasn't blown up into fighting yet, but it's a powder keg and people are playing with fire.  On the PCs' ship, the 3WE ship's counselor and negotiator, Monroe starts gently baiting Koblenz, the UPP mechanic and any PCs who are UPP-affiliated.  If the PCs do nothing, this will turn into a fight, with Koblenz throwing the first punch after Monroe's provocation.  Depending on how the PCs resolve this, either one or both Monroe and Koblenz will hold grudges against them, for favoring the other in the dispute.

NOT SO STATE-OF-THE-ART

To be played at any time.  The SEVs so generously provided by Weyland-Yutani aren't as super as everyone was led to believe—cutting corners and saving costs in construction means they all suffer from relentless mechanical glitches and failures.  Whenever you wish, roll on the Minor Component Damage in the core rulebook, and the UNCSS Solovetsky Island suffers yet another breakdown.  The repair takes one Shift to complete, but if the roll is failed, the PCs cannot make the repair until they dock with the facilities on the UNCSS Ìyánlá.

COOPERATIVE RAIDERS

To be played at any time.  A Cooperative raiding party (one Heliades-class ship with two drop shuttles, each with eight soldiers) appears on the horizon and proceeds to land near the PCs.  They are on a snatch and grab raid, looking for skilled people they can take home and put to work.  If the PCs have completed the expedition The Devil Lives in Still Waters, they will have dealt with the Cooperative before, and this event will play out depending on whether the Cooperative are friends or enemies.  Otherwise, this will be the first time they come across the Cooperative—the soldiers will be wary of the PCs, as they are obviously well-equipped with advanced technology, but will still look to kidnap some locals (or even the PCs).

UPP DEAD IN SPACE

To be played at any time.  A UPP Cosmos Exploration Corps scout ship has been attacked by the Perfected.  Before they were all killed, the UPP commander used a demolition charge to destroy the bridge (and himself) to deny the boarders the vessel (and the nav data).  The PCs detect this vessel in space.  It's lost its air and power, its side door has been blown off and it's in a slow roll.  Three Proto-Hive Nodes, fleshy man-sized blobs, are on board, in Tactical, the Galley, and Maintenance.  They are slowly converting the vessel into a tiny Proto-Hive.  If the PCs board and investigate they can learn the following:

  • This is an advanced scouting vessel, built by the UPP (as far as they know, the Great Mother Mission does not have this class of ship in its flotilla).
  • The bridge was deliberately destroyed, but a successful COMTECH roll can retrieve two snippets: the nav data was deliberately wiped before the explosion that destroyed the bridge, and a reference to “the Great Mother Mission Space Operating Forces contingent...”
  • There are crates of modern UPP weapons and equipment on board, including AK-4047 rifles and 6B90 Combat Armor.

FACING THE MARAUDERS

Should be played mid-campaign.  The PCs detect a ship on their scanners.  It is a Gorham's Marauders' Corvus Model CM-90S, with ten crew and armed with one Long Lance ASAT missile, four Short Lance ASATs and a Medium Railgun Turret.  They intend to wipe the PCs' navigation data.  Hailed by J.V.Gorham, she orders them to stand-to and prepare to be boarded.  If the PCs cooperate, the Marauders will be firm but not violent.  They will proceed to board and wipe the vessel's navigation data, re-installing enough for them to navigate the Far Spinward Colonies.  If the PCs resist, the pirates will use enough force to convince them to surrender.  If they run, the pirates will use their ship's weapons in an attempt to disable them.  If the PCs try talking to Gorham, they may make an opposed MANIPULATION test to get Gorham to respond.  If they succeed, they can learn the details of the first campaign clue (The Metapuzzle), or have those details confirmed, if they have already found it.  If the PCs have completed the expedition Let Sleeping Gods Lie they may have met J.V.Gorham before, and this event will play out depending on the relationship the PCs built with her.

WOLF IN SHEEP'S CLOTHING

Should be played mid-campaign.  The PCs detect another vessel, a Weyland Heliades-Class J Sev.  Unknown to them, it's the Children of the Two Divines who have detected their ship and want to capture it for themselves.  The devotees send a distress signal, calling for medical and humanitarian aid, claiming they have been drifting for days since their engines failed (a scan with a successful COMTECH roll will reveal that the Heliades' engines are warm, and have been recently operational).  If asked, they will claim to be from Sanchez Colony, not realizing that the PCs may know that Sanchez was destroyed years ago.  If the PCs dock, the Children will simply rush the airlock as soon as it opens, gaining surprise unless the players specifically state they are being cautious.  Eight of the crew of twelve will rush aboard, to capture it, but at the least download navigation data from the bridge before fleeing.  If the PCs try to intercept any communications from the devotees' ship, they will succeed with a COMTECH roll. They will hear a short exchange.  

OUTGOING MESSAGE: “Intact vessel identified.  We are moving to intercept.  We will continue the task to locate the navigation data, the parts and fuel that you need for your fleet, but if the Angels are willing, we will bring you this vessel.  Your odyssey across the Isolation's Gap to the Outer Rim can start immediately, and the rest can follow soon after.  Before long, the whole Middle Heavens will be open to you.”

INCOMING: “Acceptance.  Hasten.”

BRING THEM TO HEEL

To be played late in the campaign, but before the finale In the Shadow Of Perfection.  The 3WE, angry at the growing support for the NAPRO, seizes all sympathizers in a coordinated operation.  The commander of the UNCSS Solovetsky Island receives a message from Colonel Buston that all NAPRO sympathizers are to be arrested immediately (this includes Lakota Monroe and PC sympathizers), a command that has tacit support from the UNISC in a desperate attempt to keep the Great Mother Mission together.  It's up to the commander and the PCs how this confrontation plays out on Solovetsky Island.

PLAYER HANDOUTS

MISSION CONTRACT

COLONY STATUS REPORTS

“Come my friends, 'tis not too late to seek a newer world […]
for my purpose holds to sail beyond the sunset.”
—ULYSSES
“An eye for an eye will only make the whole world blind.”
—MAHATMA GANDHI

The PCs head to Gorham Colony, KOI-2650.01, a mining outpost on a deserted, dusty, wind-swept planet.  They find only one occupied settlement, a ragged mining facility with just eight survivors.  Their arrival re-ignites a feud between the colonists, erupting into violence as a huge sandstorm hits, shattering the base and leaving them defenseless against the deadly creatures of this world.  They must deal with the feud and repair the facility—or find another way to survive—before these terrors of nature tear them all apart.

WHAT'S THE STORY MOTHER?

Heading towards your destination, you receive a video call from Gaius aboard UNCSS Ìyánlá.

“Gorham Colony KOI-2650.01 is a mining colony.  Established 2067.  Terraformed.  Our records show the planet is rich in pentlandite, iron ore and some trace elements.  The population in 2100 was noted as one million.  Founded by J.V.Gorham.  Site of the deepest drilling, apparently, at 23 kilometers.  Was introducing non-indigenous life to help with mining operations.  Earth standard gravity, orbits a red giant star with a diurnal length of 36 hours.  Arid with high winds and frequent sand storms.

That's all I have for you.  As you know, our mission is first and foremost exploratory and humanitarian—see what's there and if anyone needs immediate assistance—then establish contact with any political authority and negotiate their return to the United Nations' fold.  If there's no one there, assess the planet for immediate recolonization and don't forget to recover the colony's long data disc so we can analyze their history.  You will need to file a Colony Potential Report—I'm expecting your assessments of future mining potential, scientific research opportunities, any local life that's worth investigating, and of course, any ad hoc opportunities for scientific, commercial or financial benefit.

You will report your findings back to me.  Hail and farewell!”

WHAT IS GOING ON?

The surviving colonists at the Tontas Ravine mining facility, the Morino and Parks families, are old enemies, who put aside their vendetta and worked together out of necessity, to survive.  After the Isolation they continued to mine pentlandite—a common ore they traded with other colonies.

Over the years that trade dried up, leaving them struggling to survive.  Twenty years ago tensions flared, as did the feud.  José Morino, the elder brother to Emilia, Diego and Danny, was shot dead by Patrick Parks.  Patrick had sought revenge for the loss of his family at José's hands some years prior.

Realizing that feeding the vendetta would see them all dead, those left behind called a truce and tried to work together.  Despite their differences, they have only survived thanks to this collaboration.  Over the years they have collected a fortune in precious stones, but the gems have no value unless they can reconnect with civilization.

However, long-standing resentments and hatreds are always just under the surface, and both Diego Morino and Patrick Parks still harbor ice-cold dreams of vengeance.

The last people to visit Tontas Ravine before the PCs were Gorham's Marauders, one year ago (Gorham's Marauders.  They found the NPCs' ship, HMCSS Janku, and wiped the navigation data from its memory banks.

Then the PCs arrive.  Suddenly both the Morinos and Parks see a new future of luxury after so much misery.  But there's no way they are going to share it with their oldest enemies, who necessity made allies but now are just getting in the way.  Under the cover of a terrible sandstorm Danny Morino is murdered, and the feud is let loose once again.

KOI-2650.01 is an arid Earth-like planet orbiting a red giant that gives a pale rusty-orange tinge to everything.  Daily temperatures only reach 10 °C, and not quite freezing at night.  It has a long diurnal cycle of 36 hours, with little axial tilt so day and night are both 18 hours long (three Shifts).  The storms swirl contaminated dust into the air—anyone breathing it will suffer the effects of suffocation every Turn, or after any strenuous activity (see Suffocation in the core rulebook).

KICKING OFF THE ACTION

The action starts with the PCs aboard their SEV, scanning the planet.  In between the frequent storms, they can make out the remains of isolated settlements across the planet's harsh, red-tinged landscape.  All of them look industrial and mechanized, pipes and smokestacks, tanks and containers, all covered in dust.  None of them look anything other than deserted and derelict.

If the PCs issue a radio call, they will get no reply—the Morino and Parks families will hear them but have learned to be cautious.  They will wait at the facility to see what the PCs do.  However, they cannot hide the heat signature and electrostatic noise Tontas Ravine gives out.

The PCs can pinpoint the location, in the middle of a vast rocky plain, cracked like a broken pane of glass with ravines, chasms and canyons.  A fly-over reveals the facility, tucked neatly at the bottom of a wide ravine.  It has power, and on the plain above there's the glint of solar panels and the whirring of windmills.  About 500 meters away along the ravine rests the derelict remains of an old Bison-class ship next to what looks like a crude access ramp to the ravine floor, big enough for a Daihotai 8x8.

It is impossible to land inside the ravine, and landing near it is dangerous due to the uneven and broken ground (-3 modification to PILOTING).  Landing next to the Bison is easy enough, but still requires a PILOTING roll.  A failed roll means the ship has landed heavily, taking D3 points of damage.  

Shore Party: @UUID[Actor.nVnH4FekZaA8qGIx]{Tan Blatchman}, the ICC Inspector aboard the Solovetsky Island demands to come planet-side with the PCs, to see firsthand how they go about applying ICC protocols in the field.  He will not cope with danger well and will need protecting.  Possibly an opportunity for the PCs to get rid of their troublesome inspector, if they wish to do so.

The Calm Before the Storm: When the PCs arrive at the mine, they see six people waiting to welcome them: Emilia, Diego and Danny Morino, and Morgan, Violet and Benny Parks.  Maya Morino and Patrick Parks have taken their @UUID[Actor.amQKYDl0wwOXjNHJ]{WY-37B Transport Sled} to make a food gathering run 100km to the north.  They are all armed, except Benny, but cautiously wary rather than threatening.  Emilia leads the conversation, saying they don't see a lot of folks around these parts, these days.  She will demand to know who the PCs are, where they are from and what they are doing here.

It's up to the PCs how they convince them they are there to help, but when they explain they are a rescue mission from Earth there will be a moment of dawning realization on the NPCs' faces—more than relief or excitement, as they all realize their lives are about to change dramatically, and they don't need—don't want—the other family anymore.  The PCs can notice this dawning realization with a successful OBSERVATION roll, but if questioned the NPCs will simply say they are relieved that help has arrived.  

This is an opportunity for the PCs to question the Morinos and Parks, explore the facility and learn about the history of Tontas Ravine.  They should also learn about the Gorham's Marauders' raid of the previous year, and the NPCs can bring up their agendas with the PCs, and see how they react.

The Storm: After the PCs' arrival, and at a point to best build the tension, a huge dust storm brews up and brews up fast.  The following happens:

They receive a call from their pilot @UUID[Actor.CRuHo9hjlXzVluWw]{“Dudge”} aboard UNCSS Solovetsky Island.  He reports that a storm is incoming, that it's close and it's big.  The PCs are too far away for recovery before it hits, so Dudge is taking the ship into orbit to avoid damage.

Emilia Morino tells the PCs they can weather the storm in their storm shelter, for staying outside could be fatal.  Any PC who insists on staying outside the storm shelter suffers an eight Base Dice, Damage 2 attack from the dust, winds and falling debris each Turn until the storm blows itself out one Shift later.  The other NPCs disappear to secure the facility as best they can before the storm hits.

Benny Parks takes the opportunity to confront Danny Morino about the affair with his mother.  They scuffle outside Danny's pod, and Benny hits Danny with a wrench.  In a panic Benny drops the bloody wrench and leaves Danny, unconscious, where he fell, where the storm will kill him, but not before stealing Danny's keycard to the vault and hiding it inside his boot.  He dashes to the storm shelter, in a sweat.

As the storm hits and Danny doesn't appear at the shelter, Violet becomes distraught.  If the PCs don't intervene, Benny holds her back while Morgan Parks seals the shelter hatch.  Violet punches Morgan, accusing him of leaving Danny to die, and the PCs will learn of the affair.

The Escape: The storm lasts one Shift and destroys the water tanks, flooding the basement and the access tunnel to the storm shelter, from which the PCs must escape.  The shelter's roof hatch opens upwards.  It's stuck by the weight of water above it and needs a firm push to force it open.  When opened, water will immediately gush into the shelter (+1 STRESS LEVEL to all), but if they let go of the hatch the weight of water will close it, trapping them but stopping the flood.  Once the hatch is fully open it will take the water two Rounds to completely fill the shelter.  

When fully submerged, the PCs will need to make drowning tests each round (see drowning in the core rulebook) until they escape.  They may plan their escape before they open the hatch, in which case they act in whatever order they have agreed.  Otherwise, draw initiative to see who goes first.  Each PC needs to make a successful MOBILITY roll to escape, but if they fail, they are stuck for the Round and are blocking the access tunnel.  Those behind are stuck unless they make a CLOSE COMBAT roll to drag the blocking character back down and out of the way.  

The Aftermath: The storm has done terrible damage:

  • The base is dark and silent, with no power—only gloomy red sunlight seeps in.
  • The water tanks collapsed, smashing the Parks' house and leaving a gaping hole running from roof to foundations.
  • The giant door to the Harvester kennel is battered and standing wide open, the Harvester nowhere to be seen.
  • The vehicle bay has collapsed, and the tractor is lying on its side badly damaged, at least one rugged tire shredded and useless.  Any vehicle the PCs brought with them is equally smashed.
  • The comms aerial, that should be standing atop the comms array on the southern cliff, hangs over the precipice, held by a tangle of cables.
  • There is no way to contact the SEV now, with the base comms out of action and the storm still raging in the upper atmosphere, effectively jamming the PCs' own comms.
  • The windmills are bent and broken—some missing entirely—but many still stand and look like they might be operable.
  • Violet Parks is desperate to find Danny Morino, in the hope that he is safe.

TONTAS RAVINE

The ravine walls are 40 meters high and sheer.  They cannot be climbed (although an enterprising player with a Harpoon Grappling Gun can give that a try, with a successful RANGED COMBAT roll to shoot the grappler, and a MOBILITY roll to climb up).

 
HMCSS JANKU

ORE PROCESSING PLANT

Ore is dropped into a huge hopper that produces nuggets of pure pentlandite, then automatically packaged and stored in the warehouse.  If the machine is on and someone falls into the hopper they are killed.

VEHICLE BAY

There is room in the bay for the facility's Daihotai 8x8.

MINING STORAGE

This huge storage bay contains twenty seismic charges (Blast Power 10), four power packs (Power Supply 2 each) and five portable air canisters (Air Supply 3 each).  Additionally, it will have anything that the players can reasonably convince you would be in the warehouse of a frontier mining facility.

THE HARVESTER KENNEL

Built to contain the Harvester, this structure is of the toughest materials available but will be difficult to repair (HEAVY MACHINERY at -3 and a Shift of work).  The adjacent storage shed has five electro-prod “zappers,” and three power packs with Power Supply 3 each.  It also contains the remote switch (Power Supply 1) that detonates the electric charge attached to the Harvester's harness to subdue it.  To activate the switch requires a Power Supply roll, a successful COMTECH test, and to be within MEDIUM range of the beast.  The attempt can be repeated if failed.  If successful, the Harvester will be subdued and not act for a Turn unless it suffers damage.

SOLAR FARM

The solar panels often get clogged with dust which stops them working.  It takes one person a full Shift to clean them all off, but once complete, the power will come back online, as long as there's sunshine.

FIELD NODES

The field nodes transfer power from the solar panels and mini-mills to the rest of the base, as well as power the pylons to create the electric field that repels the insect swarms.  If a field node is broken, it will take a COMTECH roll and a Turn of work to fix.

FIELD PYLONS

The pylons create a 20-meter-high flickering electric field that encircles the top of the ravine and defends against the native insects.  If any of the pylons are broken, the field cannot work.  A repair takes a HEAVY MACHINERY roll to realign the pylon (taking one Turn), then a COMTECH roll to re-connect it with the field (another Turn of work).  Once activated, anyone touching the field will take a twelve Base Dice attack, Damage 1.  However, if the target takes no damage whatsoever, the field has flickered, and they have passed safely through (a desperate PC may try this if the only other option is being eaten alive by the Swarm).

COMMS ARRAY

This needs to be online for any communications with the SEV or the Cargo Lifter.  If the aerial is broken, it needs two people to manhandle it back into place, with a successful STAMINA roll and a HEAVY MACHINERY roll to repair it, a job that will take a Shift to complete.

LIFT TOWERS

The towers are made of thin scaffolding, with an elevator that works when the base has power and a rickety set of steps.

MINI-MILL FIELD

Used to generate power but susceptible to storm damage.

The tunnel runs for 100 meters before it opens into a circular strip mine with concentric circles going deeper and deeper.  This chamber has a self-powered generator and floodlights but there's no way out other than through the ravine.

BASEMENT

After the storm has passed through the basement is flooded to a depth of one meter, bringing a -1 modification to MOBILITY rolls for moving through it.  After the storm, five leggy-snakes, that were nesting under the water tanks, have been washed into the basement.  An OBSERVATION test will spot the ripples they make on the surface of the water as they swim about.  They will try to bite anyone who lingers in the water but won't leave the water and expose themselves to potential predators.

STORM SHELTER

It's basic—benches against corrugated walls, a plastic table that runs down the middle, illuminated by one ceiling panel.  A storage cupboard has rations and a flashlight with Power Supply 3.  Access is down a ladder from the basement and through a ceiling hatch that can be sealed shut with a locking wheel.

The controls to the electric insect defense field are found here.

STORES

This is the main storage area of the facility, with four portable air canisters (Air Supply 5 each) and four power packs (Power Supply 3), as well as anything reasonable the players may ask for, at your discretion.

THE VAULT

Access to the vault requires two keycards to be used simultaneously.  There are only three, one held each by Emilia Morino, Morgan Parks, and Danny Morino (although after the storm Danny's keycard has been stolen by Benny Parks and hidden in Benny's boot).  The vault door cannot be hacked, but could, in theory, be blown or cut open (Health 10, Armor Rating 4).  The hoard of rare gemstones is stored here in a suitcase (a heavy item) and is worth a total of W-Y$100,000, although the Morinos and Parks think its value is 100 times that (naturally there may be repercussions should the PCs choose to steal the stash).  The vault also contains the armory, with two Armat 37A2 Pump Action shotguns (four reloads), one Weyland Storm Rifle (one reload) and two M4A3 Pistols (two reloads).

The long data disc for Gorham Colony is here.  Spending a Turn to analyze the records reveals the following:

  • The population in 2100 was 120,000, with an export/import economy reliant upon regular trading for food and other basic supplies.
  • Trade collapsed after 2100.  Many colonists left but those that remained—25,000 in 2150—could survive.
  • In the 2150s, a decade of extreme storms and the unchecked spread of insect swarms led to much loss of life, and many more colonists died or departed.
  • From about 2160, trading vessels from other colonies stopped coming, and only a few isolated settlements survived.  The population was 350.
POWER SYSTEMS

Everything from lights, doors, lifts, and computer systems requires power.  Any battery can be plugged into these systems to give them the power they need to work, but each time a Power Supply roll must be made.  After the storm has shattered the base, the players can use a battery to fire up diagnostic systems here or on the Control Deck to learn the following:

  • There's no technical reason why the solar farm isn't delivering power, it must be dust (see Solar Farm).
  • One third of the mini-mills are still working but there's a short circuit at the northern field node stopping the power reaching the base (see Field Nodes).
  • The field pylon to the west of the northern field node has collapsed, and the electrical field cannot be activated (see Field Pylons).
THE REACTOR

This has been turned off for months due to a minor radiation leak, but it can still operate.  To bring the reactor back online, the PCs need to devote a Turn of work, install fuel rods with a HEAVY MACHINERY roll (if this roll is failed, all within SHORT range take D3 Rads, but may try again), then make a second HEAVY MACHINERY roll to fire up the reactor.  Once running the power is restored, but the reactor emits Weak radiation (1 Rad per Shift) that affects the entire facility.

EVENTS

POOR DANNY

After the storm has passed Danny is dead, lying outside the ground floor door to his pod.  He will be found by Violet Parks if the PCs do not look for him.  She will be hysterical at finding her lover dead.  He's been scoured by the dust and his skin flayed (+1 STRESS LEVEL to all viewing him).  He also has a severe head wound.  A MEDICAL AID roll will identify that the head blow didn't kill him, and an OBSERVATION roll will find the bloodied wrench nearby.  If his body is searched, the PCs will find that his vault keycard is missing (if the PCs don't search him Emilia Morino will do it and announce this news).  The PCs should have the chance to start investigating what happened.

THE FEUD ERUPTS

Eventually the feud erupts into a violent argument between the Parks and Morinos.  The history comes out, leading to a murderous fight between the families as they each accuse the other of killing Danny to get the second vault keycard (unless the PCs intervene).  Diego Morino will try to kill Benny, Violet Parks will try to kill Morgan, then defend Benny from Diego.  Those left standing after two Rounds will scatter across the compound to avoid being killed but will hunt down their enemies as the scenario progresses.  How the PCs react will influence the outcome.

ANOTHER ONE BITES THE DUST

At any time you should feel free to add in the death or confrontation of any of the NPCs, to heighten the tension as the story progresses.

COMING FOR THE PCS

If either of the families gets the upper hand in the feud, they start to see the PCs as a problem, for they will have witnessed murder.  They will try and get the PCs to keep quiet about the events here, either agreeing to pay them or by persuasion.  If this doesn't work, they will try to kill the PCs to keep their secrets safe.

A VENGEFUL HARVESTER

The Harvester (see harvesters in the core rulebook), still wearing its harness, is out there somewhere, on the prowl.  It's angry and resentful.  When a character ventures outside, the Harvester will detect the tremors caused by their footfalls and track them.  It will attack if it gets the chance but can be distracted by noise or other vibrations.  If things need livening up, it will attack the main base in an attempt to get at its tormentors.

NIGHTFALL

Night will fall at a time best suited to the drama, and Tontas Ravine will be plunged into darkness.  Until the PCs restore the power, they will need flashlights (with power) to see anything, and still suffer a -2 modification to OBSERVATION.

THE CARGO LIFTER RETURNS

This event should be played towards the end of the story after the Swarm has been detected (see Finale), to raise the tension at the worst possible moment.  The Cargo Lifter (a @UUID[Actor.amQKYDl0wwOXjNHJ]{WY-37B Transport Sled} in the core rule book) appears and makes a hasty landing.  Patrick Parks steps from the cockpit pod.  He has his gun drawn.  Maya Morino has been beaten and is restrained with cable-ties.  Patrick Parks says:

“I'm flying us out of the way of that damned swarm, but you're not all welcome.  Parks only get aboard, or the little Morino girl dies here and now!”

He says he will spare Maya's life if the others comply, but he has no intention of doing so (the PCs can make an OBSERVATION roll to detect Patrick's lie).

THE FIELD MALFUNCTIONS

The protective field goes offline.  A COMTECH roll made from the Control Deck or the basement Power Systems will show them that one of the northerly field pylons is faulty, preventing the circuit from closing and the field from working.

THE DEADLY HARVEST

The PCs can try to “wrangle” the Harvester using the “zappers,” to control it and stop it attacking people or causing more damage.  However, this is very hard without the Husbandry talentS.  See Mining Operations Using A “Tamed” Harvester for more on Harvesters and how to control them.

PATRICK PARKS

@UUID[Actor.wF7dgyJgxURreYjN]{Patrick Parks}
 

Bitter and vengeful, the “Old Man of Tontas Ravine” cannot forget that day when José Morino killed his wife and left him for dead—he still has a vicious scar on his face as a constant reminder.  His vengeance will be fulfilled when he takes Tontas Ravine from the Morinos and sees them dead in the dust.  Patrick will try to cut a deal with the PCs, to overlook the “fate” of the Morinos for a generous personal cut of the Tontas Ravine fortune.

 
STRENGTH 2, AGILITY 2, WITS 5, EMPATHY 3
HEALTH:  2
SKILLS:  Close Combat 1, Manipulation 3, Comtech 2, Heavy Machinery 3, Observation 2, Piloting 1, Ranged Combat 2
TALENTS:  Merciless
GEAR:  Protective clothing (Armor Rating 2), 37A2 shotgun, M4A3 pistol (concealed).
 

FINALE

After the power has been restored to the base, the weather warning alarm sounds in the Control Deck.  If the PCs study the radar, they see a large shadow to the east—a huge swarm of “space locusts” (see The Swarm in the core rulebook) and it's coming this way (+1 STRESS LEVEL to all who see this).  It's difficult to tell how long it might take to arrive, but if it makes a beeline for them, it could be within the hour.  

The swarm will finally arrive.  You should time the arrival for maximum effect, and the PCs should feel it coming as they desperately work out how to survive.  If the electric field is active, the PCs will see that the swarm is huge and will eventually overwhelm it.  Each Round, the swarm makes its signature attacks against the field.  On a roll of 6, the swarm strips a pylon.  Read the sidebar The Field Collapsesto your players.

SURVIVING THE SWARM

The swarm is a 4 zone Swarm (see The Swarm in the core rulebook), Speed 4, Health 20, impervious to all attacks other than fire, explosions, and electricity.  Once inside the compound, it will attack for ten Rounds before moving on, eating through walls to get to living flesh.  This is the endgame, the final scene, but there are three ways to survive: hide inside the Harvester kennel (only if it's been repaired), hide underwater (if the PCs have enough Air Supply), or get the hell out on the Cargo Lifter.

THE FIELD COLLAPSES

The flickering petrol-blue lightning field around the clifftop is keeping you safe.  

But the swarm is throwing itself at it, sudden and intense flashes marking the electrocution of insect after insect, a relentless, unending onslaught.  The tall pylons shudder under the assault.

Then you hear it, a wailing groan of metal as a pylon shudders.  Something falls away, a maintenance panel maybe, or some of its shielding.  But either way you watch as the pylon crumbles under the attack.

Its lights flicker and go out.

The reassuring blue glow of the shield begins to stutter, then go dark, setting off an almost instant domino effect around the entire field.

In that moment, and before your very eyes, the shield is gone and the Swarm floods into the compound…

MAYA MORINO

@UUID[Actor.alYQ80Oz5SQlNICc]{Maya Morino}
 

Serious, focused and direct, 20 year old Maya is a pilot and driver.  She hates the feud even though she lost her father, José, to it before she knew him.  This is her home, and she wants the mine to succeed.  She doesn't want to leave after all the hard work they've put in and wants the PCs to help them get back on their feet.  She only cares about her aunt Emilia and the hapless Benny Parks and doesn't want either to get hurt.  She will use force to protect them.

 
STRENGTH 3, AGILITY 5, WITS 3, EMPATHY 4
HEALTH:  3
SKILLS:  Close Combat 1, Comtech 2, Mobility 2, Piloting 3, Ranged Combat 1
GEAR:  Flight suit (Armor Rating 3), combat knife.
 

EPILOGUE

After the storm there is still a viable planet to re-colonize, should the PCs want to recommend that, and possibly a fortune in gems to deal with.  After their report goes in, the PCs might be quietly approached by a corporate executive with a proposal that they should capture the Harvester for use elsewhere, or specimens of the insect swarm.

METAPUZZLE CLUE #1—DATABASE READ-OUT FROM HMCSS JANKU

HMCSS JANKU SHIP'S LOG

NAVIGATION SYSTEMS—OFFICER ACCESS AUTHORIZED…….

NAVIGATION DATA LAYER ACCESSED

  • PRIMARY DATABASE DELETED
  • SECONDARY DATABASE DELETED
  • FACTORY RESET
  • AUXILIARY AND EMERGENCY BEACON DATA DELETED
  • NAVIGATION DATA LAYER DELETED

SYSTEM RE-BOOT

  • NO NAVIGATIONAL DATA FOUND
  • PRIMARY, SECONDARY, AUXILIARY AND EMERGENCY DATA NOT FOUND
  • SHIP DRIVE SYSTEMS—ENABLED
  • WARNING—FLIGHT OPERATIONS WITHOUT NAVIGATION DATA ARE NOT ADVISED
  • COMMUNICATIONS SYSTEMS ONLINE—SIGNAL O/G “Granddaughter, Granddaughter, this is Uncle Five reporting in.  We found the outpost on Gorham Colony, no resistance.  The people made a dash for their storm cellar the minute they realized we'd spotted them.  Only one functional ship.  The job is done, no problems—one less set of navigation data for those bastards to get their hands on.  See you at the rendezvous.  Uncle Five out.”

name: 10.04 THE DEVIL LIVES IN STILL WATERS

pages.name: 10.04 THE DEEVIL LIVES IN STILL WATERS

text.content:
“In waking the tiger, use a long stick.”

—MAO TSE-TUNG

The PCs find a rare thing in the Far Spinward Colonies—a society that, on the surface at least, is working well.  May Outpost KOI-610.01, was once a 3WE Royal Marine outpost until it was taken over by the Chinese Asian Nations Collective (CANC, The Golden Age Of Expansion).  Now, the society is at war with itself and at odds with the Xenomorphs that inhabit the nearby ruins of an ancient Engineer pyramid.  The PCs must negotiate the deadly forces at work, deal with the UPP, explore the wonders of the pyramid and prevent the colony falling into a full-blown insurrection.

WHAT IS GOING ON?

May Outpost KOI-610.01 was once a 3WE Royal Marine outpost, with—according to the Weyland Corporation files—nearly a billion people in 2100.  This was a typo, the fat finger of an administrator hitting “zero” too many times.  The real figure wasn't even a million.

The colony survived the Isolation.  Then, thirty years ago, the Chinese Asian Nations Collective arrived, fresh from the disaster that was their home, Curzic Colony, begging for somewhere to settle.  Permission was given, but the relationship was never friendly.  Ten years ago, the CANC took control.  After a bitter struggle, their leader, Colonel Zhāngjié, declared himself Warlord of the newly formed “Great Kĕnéng Cooperative.” The Royal Marines who surrendered were ruthlessly murdered, and the rest fled into the wilderness to carry on the fight.

Ten years later, seismic activity at the far eastern end of Xián Hú (literally “salty lake”) led to the collapse of the cliff, revealing an ancient Engineer pyramid, and rousing the Xenomorphs that were sleeping there.  Those who went to explore were never seen again.  Since then, on the three nights of the spring and winter equinoxes, XX121LV Bioluminescent Xenomorphs leave the pyramid to roam.  They wreaked havoc in the colony until Zhāngjié learned that leaving human sacrifices would gain their attention, preventing further death and destruction—except for their doomed sacrificial victims, dragged away into the lake.  These victims were taken to feed the growing Hive in the depths of the pyramid.

The pyramid was put off limits by Zhāngjié's order, and life went on.  Then, a month ago, a scout ship of the UPP Cosmos Exploration Corps arrived under the command of Lt Colonel Victor Drubov.  Offering gifts of advanced tech with the promise of more, Drubov tried to persuade the Cooperative to join the UPP.  Zhāngjié is not convinced but sees these soldiers as his way to finally unearth the pyramid's secrets.  The arrival of the PCs is another golden opportunity for Zhāngjié to get what he wants for the Cooperative, and to play them off against the UPP.

WHAT'S THE STORY MOTHER?

The PCs receive a video call from Gaius aboard UNCSS Ìyánlá.

“Your destination is May Outpost, designation KOI-610.01.  This is a Three World Empire military base, first colonized in 2061 under the Weyland Corporation then transferred to 3WE authority on its establishment in 2088.  The records suggest a population of 900 million people in 2100—seems a bit steep to me.  The colony was not just a Royal Marine base, it also had mining facilities to support an electronics production industry.

The planet is highly volcanic, with considerable seismic activity and localized release of toxic gasses, with a saline and caustic atmosphere.  Basic maintenance costs for May Outpost were three times equivalent averages.  It is also rather warm, average daytime temperatures of 33°C and not dropping much lower at night.  The year lasts 180 Earth days, and the day is 18 hours.  At this point in its cycle the planet should be approaching the winter equinox.

That is May Outpost.  It will be interesting to see how accurate those 2100 reports are.  Remember you are exploring and seeking to understand the current state of the colony and will offer any humanitarian aid that may be required.  If a 3WE military authority still exists, you should have little trouble re-incorporating them under official authority.  We will still need access to their long data disc so we can assess their long-term development, and I'm expecting the usual Colony Potential Report: industrial output; trade opportunities; political set-up and stability; and any ad hoc opportunities.

All the best, Solovetsky Island.”

 

CLUES TO THE
METAPUZZLE

The PCs can learn the fourth clue of the campaign (Clue #4—Translation Of The Engineer Hieroglyph In The Pyramid) during this expedition, by exploring the Engineer pyramid and deciphering the glyphs that adorn the wall of the Shrine.  They can also have the first campaign clue (Clue #1—Database Read-Out From Hmcss Janku) corroborated by Warlord Zhāngjié—if asked he will say there is a band of pirates called Gorham's Marauders who attack ships to wipe their navigation data, but they don't dare raid the Great Kĕnéng Cooperative.

 

GORHAM COLONY'S LONG DATA DISC

May Outpost's long data disc can be found in the Monitoring Center, on the basement level of the CANC Intelligence HQ.  Once Zhāngjié knows it's important to the PCs he will use it as leverage to get the help he wants.  He will be reluctant to give it up as it will show his ruthlessness during the coup.  He will expect immunity from prosecution for his past deeds, and a great bargain, to do so.

 
KOI-610.01
KOI-610.01 is an Earth-like volcanic planet, with daily temperatures reaching 33°C and not dropping much lower at night.  The air is breathable, but pockets of toxic gas can emerge anywhere, along with the frequent geysers and ground bursts.  With so much toxic gas and salt-blown particles in the air, corrosion is a constant problem.  For every Shift that a mechanical device (including spaceships and pressure suits) is exposed to the weather roll a Stress Die—on it malfunctions either immediately or when next used.  To repair it takes a HEAVY MACHINERY roll and a Turn of work.  The planet is severely tilted on its axis, bringing extreme seasons in its 180-day year. When the PCs arrive, it's the winter equinox at May Outpost, with equal hours of daylight and night and the weather is stormy and wet.  

The planetary map gives you all the details you need for KOI-610.01 should your PCs want to further explore or even colonize it, using the rules in the Appendix: Building Your Own Better World.

KICKING OFF THE ACTION

As the PCs approach the planet, their scans reveal the following: the planet is volatile with high levels of volcanic gasses in the upper atmosphere; there's lots of radio chatter—the signal that a living settlement still persists; and pockets of twinkling civilization link together around a central town by a lake that shimmers with a bluey-white glow.

Then the comms unit crackles, and a message first in Chinese, then English:

“Unidentified vessel, this is the Great Kĕnéng Cooperative Orbital Authority.  Identify yourself and state your destination and purpose.  Be warned, any act deemed aggressive, hostile, or non-conforming with instructions will be met with relentless defensive force.  Respond.”

Unless the PCs say or do something to anger the Orbital Authority, they will be instructed to land at the Landing Strip.  Landing requires a PILOT test with a +1 modification, thanks to the support of the ground crew.  A failed roll means the ship has landed heavily, taking D3 points of damage.  

As the PCs make their approach, they see the layout of the town, built up at the western end of the briny lake.  All roads lead away, snaking into the distance where much smaller settlements can be seen.  On the north-east shore of the lake lies what must have been an old settlement, now derelict and ruined.  It sits adjacent to a large cliff that forms the east end of the lake.  Part of the cliff has fallen away leaving exposed an awe-inspiring relic, once buried beneath the earth.  It looks like a pyramid set into the rock, one side of which has been sheared away by the landslide.

SHORE PARTY

As the Solovetsky Island's negotiator, @UUID[Actor.yWGOj2k0gp062kdO]{Lakota Monroe} insists she be allowed to join the shore party.  Once the UPP's presence is revealed she will take a very hard line with the Cooperative in negotiations, and cause Zhāngjié to lose patience with her and the PCs.

ON THE GROUND

Assuming the PCs comply with these instructions to land they will be met by a group of ten armed guards (@UUID[Actor.RwEA3lfBgWrxuVjn]{Weylander Guards} ) under the command of Captain Guanting.  She will politely but firmly invite them to a meeting with Warlord Zhāngjié, as they are clearly important visitors.  Weapons are not allowed.  If they agree they will be escorted in an open-topped personnel carrier to the Warlord's compound.  As they rumble through the colony, the PCs cannot fail to notice the frequent guard checkpoints with five or six well-armed soldiers.  They can learn more with a group OBSERVATION roll:

  • One   : There are a lot of people in decent clothing and looking well fed, no obvious signs of poverty or destitution, and building work is competent if not fancy.  But few people are smiling, while at the same time none are showing obvious signs of unhappiness either.  They seem docile.
  • Two or more   : They sense a seething undercurrent of tension, a tangible hostility in the air.

MEETING THE WARLORD

Eventually, the PCs arrive at the Warlord's Compound where they are met by Zhāngjié (The Cooperative) and Brigadier Xìn Wŏ.  Zhāngjié appears unarmed (he always has his two-shot derringer in his boot) but Wŏ is carrying a UPP sidearm gifted to her by Colonel Drubov, an MP-4043 Grach.  This gun was not produced until after the Isolation.  If a PC is UPP, they will immediately recognize it.  Otherwise, a successful OBSERVATION roll will notice the weapon as being in superb condition, two   identify it as a UPP-style weapon, while three or more   will fully identify it.  If Wŏ is questioned, she will say it's a treasured family heirloom from before the Isolation.  The PCs may make an opposed MANIPULATION vs MANIPULATION to spot the lie—if she fails, she cannot hide her feeling of dishonor at lying, but will not admit the lie.  

Zhāngjié will ask the following questions:

  • Who are the PCs, where are they from and why are they here?
  • What are they offering (he is particularly interested in weapons, ship parts and upgrades)?
  • He will explain there is an ongoing terrorist problem.  A small group of insurrectionists, encouraged by the Union Mutual Society, are making trouble for the peace-loving people of the Cooperative.  What help can the PCs offer to resolve this?
  • He will invite the PCs to tour the town (with a protective bodyguard of five soldiers (@UUID[Actor.RwEA3lfBgWrxuVjn]{Weylander Guards} ) under @UUID[Actor.sVl0stBIJ45oLKTt]{Captain Guanting} ) as long as they leave a negotiator (either a PC or Solovetsky Island's counselor and negotiator, Lakota Monroe) with his people to further explore the future relationship.

If the PCs ask about the pyramid Zhāngjié will explain its history, say it is off-limits (unless explicitly authorized by him alone) and inquire as to why the PCs asked.

If the PCs ask to meet the Union Mutual Society they will be allowed to talk to the Speaker of the Union, Stanley Sheppard, who can be found at the Three Lions tavern in the town.  They will not be allowed to speak with him alone, of course, for their protection.

ZHĀNGJIÉ'S AGENDA

The Warlord wants to guarantee his personal position, strengthen the Cooperative with weapons and support to crush the insurrection and acquire the secrets of the pyramid all for himself.  He feels he is in a very strong position, now that both the PCs and the UPP contingent are here and will play them off against one another—although at this stage he will not reveal the presence of the UPP to the PCs.  He will agree to adopt the authority of the UN once the PCs have helped him with these three objectives, although he's happy to backslide on the deal later on if it suits him.

CAPTAIN GUANTING

@UUID[Actor.sVl0stBIJ45oLKTt]{Captain Guanting}
 

Honorable and professional, Guanting is especially loyal towards Brigadier Xìn Wŏ, as she fears Warlord Zhāngjié's brutal nature and arbitrary temper.  She takes her job seriously and will do everything in her power to prevent harm coming to the PCs while they are under her protection.  She wants the insurrection to end, but believes negotiation is the way to assure that, not repression and violence.

 
STRENGTH 3, AGILITY 4, WITS 3, EMPATHY 5
HEALTH:  3
SKILLS:  Close Combat 2, Ranged Combat 2, Observation 1, Command 1, Manipulation 2, Mobility 2
TALENT:  Bodyguard
GEAR:  CANC Combat armor (Armor Rating 6) with wrist-blade, AK-4047.
 

BRIGADIER XÌN WŎ

@UUID[Actor.AvBDV6M9v5hxuNZf]{Brigadier Xìn Wŏ}
 
STRENGTH 4, AGILITY 4, WITS 3, EMPATHY 4
HEALTH:  6
SKILLS:  Close Combat 3, Ranged Combat 2, Observation 3, Comtech 2, Command 3, Manipulation 2
TALENT:  Tough
GEAR:  CANC Combat armor (Armor Rating 6) with wrist-blade, MP-4043 Grach pistol.
 

SECOND IN COMMAND AND HEAD OF INTELLIGENCE

Honorable, insightful and with a great sense of fair play, Xìn Wŏ is Warlord Zhāngjié's right hand.  An expert combat leader, she holds the loyalty of the troops.  Since the UPP arrived, she's been having ever greater reservations about them.  Their methods have no dignity or honor, something she quietly loathes.  She agrees with Zhāngjié that power through strength is the best way to build a secure community, but it must be honorable, even if she and the Warlord have not always lived up to that ideal.

She wants to ensure power remains with the Cooperative, so they can negotiate the best deal for their people from the newcomers, and not be strong-armed by these UPP barbarians.

 

MAY OUTPOST

May Outpost is built of stone and metal, crowded buildings and narrow streets filled with subdued people, keeping their heads down to avoid the interest of the Warlord's Guard.

WARLORD'S COMPOUND

Ringed by a 5-meter-high stone wall with an imposing wrought iron gate, the compound contains a luxurious palace with gardens and pools as well as a garden atelier where Zhāngjié holds court.  There are always two or three guards within a zone of the PCs.

BARRACKS

Housing 200 soldiers and their equipment, training facilities and vehicles, the three buildings are ringed by a 3-meter-high wire fence.

YŎUYÌSÀI BARRACKS

Ostensibly built as another barracks, everyone knows this houses the underground prison of the Kĕnéng Cooperative.  Several hundred political prisoners are held here.  A ballot is held at every equinox to choose six of them as sacrifices for the Xenomorphs, two per night over the three nights.

INTELLIGENCE HQ

A three story tower housing the CANC's counter-insurgency teams, and where the UPP scouts are based, it also contains the long data disc for May Colony. Outside it stands the UPP's @UUID[Actor.dqKk8zrRXK2fSQkN]{Mikoyan-Liu OX Series HAMPV 6×6 Multi Purpose Vehicle} , first built after the Isolation.  It stands out against the run-down vehicles of the CANC.  If a PC is UPP, they will immediately recognize it, otherwise, a successful OBSERVATION roll will notice the vehicle's condition, two   identify it as a UPP vehicle, while three   or more will fully identify it.

GALLOWS

Set up on the beach, this wooden structure is used both to hang those considered criminals by the CANC, and to chain up the sacrifices for the Xenomorphs. A wooden viewing platform is set up to one side and a low metal barrier fences off the area.

GUARD CHECKPOINTS

Each has a movable metal fence that can block the road and is manned by between three and six guards.

LANDING STRIPS

Open fields marked out with landing lights, small hangars and re-fueling facilities.  Three Bison CM-88B Freighters are here, although two are obviously not space-worthy.  The UPP scout ship has been maneuvered into an open hanger and covered in tarpaulin, in a fruitless attempt to keep it out of view. While the UNCSS Solovetsky Island is here, it will be guarded by five soldiers at all times.

CONTROL TOWER

Runs traffic control.

UNION OFFICES

The Cooperative allows the former 3WE people to belong to a workers' union, to make them feel better.  However, the union holds no power whatsoever, and those in the union realize that all too clearly.

THREE LIONS PUB

The covert center of resistance in the colony.  The pub is both a throwback to old British pubs of Earth, as well as Japanese izakaya, and merges both the mahogany and hardwood floor feel with the red lantern vibe of the Japanese sake shop.  It is always busy.  Stanley Sheppard runs his resistance network from here.  If the PCs come searching for him after the event The Insurrectionist's Message, they will see the young woman who passed the note, and she will direct them to Sheppard.  If they come with their guards, Sheppard will say he'd rather not be overheard while talking about Union business.  The PCs can persuade Guanting to give them a few minutes with a MANIPULATION roll with three   , or two   if they have been particularly friendly and honorable towards her up to now.  Once they get to talk in private Sheppard will:

  • Tell them about the history of the CANC coup and the war but leave out the incriminating tales of the 3WE's own atrocities.
  • Tell them that the resistance exists to overthrow the CANC, with old 3WE Royal Marine partisans waiting to liberate the people.
  • Ask for their help through materiel support, political support, the removal of Zhāngjié or outright military backing.  He will hint that Brigadier Wŏ may be more honorable and reasonable—if the PCs are interested in helping, he will gently suggest they could stop the civil war by killing Zhāngjié themselves.
  • He can cause much disturbance across the city, to keep the CANC guards busy, if that helps.
  • He will tell them of the UPP visitors.
HUÁNGHÒU SQUARE

A huge plaza where the Warlord holds rallies and parades.

ZUÌ HĂO DE DISTRICT

The ruling elite of the old CANC live here, in finely architectured homes and villas.

AMPHITHEATER

Bread and circuses, that's what keeps the people happy.  Here they get both, with frequent gladiatorial contests (between criminals with the prize of freedom for the survivors) and sporting events (that are often as bloody as the gladiator bouts).  Warlord Zhāngjié loves both.

KĀIXĪN DE RÉN FIELDS

Playing fields and parks for recreation.

XIÁN HÚ

The lake is highly salty and when the winds pick up during the winter salt “sculptures” are often formed around the edge and in the shallows.  The shallows themselves are no deeper than a meter, although the lake is 200 meters deep at its center.  The water has flooded into the lower levels of the Engineer pyramid through the parts smashed by the rockfall, and there is an underwater tunnel into the Cistern, used by the XX121LV to get in and out.

RIVERS

Three rivers flow out of Xián Hú: the Xīn Tàiwùshì Hé (“New Thames”), the Xīn Sāi Wēn (“New Severn”) and Xīn Chángjiāng (“New Yangtze”).  Of these, only the Xīn Tàiwùshì Hé can be crossed easily without a bridge.  The other rivers are so swift that a MOBILITY roll is needed.  If the roll is failed, the PC is swept away by the current and needs another MOBILITY check each Round, as a fast action, to avoid drowning.

BEACH FRONT

A nice place to spend a sunny day with the kids.

WATER PLANT

A desalination plant of stacks, pipes, valves, and towers, that provides all the clean water for the nearby town.

WAREHOUSES

Piled high with useful resources: minerals, ore, raw materials, surplus food, construction equipment, emergency settlement kits.

STANLEY SHEPPARD

@UUID[Actor.Wxhisl0qCdm18J7k]{Stanley Sheppard}
 

Intrepid, eager but ruthless, Sheppard is the Speaker for the Union Mutual Society, and covertly a leader of the 3WE insurrectionists.  He's not an unreasonable man, and while he would admit that general living standards under Zhāngjié have improved, he cannot forget at what cost—kidnappings, murder, and sacrifices.

His network knows of the UPP visitors (he hasn't heard the term “UPP” and wouldn't understand it if he did).  Despite the risk to himself he is desperate to meet the PCs and get their help (see the events The Insurrectionist's Message and The Raid).

 
STRENGTH 4, AGILITY 3, WITS 4, EMPATHY 4
HEALTH:  4
SKILLS:  Close Combat 2, Ranged Combat 2, Stamina 2, Observation 3, Command 3
TALENT:  Subdue, Hard Hitter
GEAR:  None.
 
RUINED OLD TOWN

Formerly the site of the Royal Marines garrison and the town that grew around it, the entire settlement was destroyed during the war with the CANC.  Now it is a dusty, salty, desolate ruin.

EXECUTION ALLEY

The site where the last of the marines, those who surrendered, were lined up and executed.  Their desiccated bodies lie where they fell, deliberately left as a reminder of Warlord Zhāngjié's brutality.  +1 STRESS LEVEL to those witnessing the scene.

OLD ROYAL MARINE BUNKER

The entrance is through a disused sewage overflow pipe in the southeast of town.  If it is being searched for a successful OBSERVATION roll will find it, with a +3 modification if the PCs have been given directions to find it.  A ladder goes down 30 meters to a small complex of five rooms off a central chamber.  There is no power, but the air is good and it is warm.  Captain Snell and five marines are here—they will defend themselves unless the PCs make it clear they are friends.

CAPTAIN HANNAH SNELL

@UUID[Actor.hem3Jdql4ESREfdu]{Captain Hannah Snell}
 

ROYAL MARINES

Resilient, obsessive, with only one thing to live for—to take revenge against Warlord Zhāngjié.  Ten years ago, when the defeat of the remaining marines was inevitable, Snell's commanding officer ordered her to take her unit and flee, to set up as partisans and continue the fight.  This she did with a heavy heart.  Since then, the 16 surviving marines under her command have been a thorn in the side of the CANC, but never able to force an uprising, even with the resistance network.

She knows some important visitors have arrived (the UPP scouts) and is planning a raid to assassinate them.  For now, she has returned to the old Royal Marine bunker in the Old Town, to await intelligence from Sheppard and the resistance.

 
STRENGTH 2, AGILITY 4, WITS 5, EMPATHY 4
HEALTH:  2
SKILLS:  Close Combat 2, Ranged Combat 3, Stamina 2, Observation 2, Command 3, Mobility 5
TALENT:  Weapon Specialist (sniper)
GEAR:  Battered armor (Armor Rating 4), RMC scope rifle (equivalent to the M42A), RMC SA8082 (equivalent to M41A Pulse Rifle), sword.
 

THE PYRAMID

Hidden for centuries, the pyramid still has enough residual power to illuminate its interior with an eerie blue glow that seems to come from nowhere, just bright enough to see, but not bright enough to banish the shadows.  The air inside is salty, and sound echoes a very long way.  The Main Level is flooded by the lake to a depth of 1 meter, and the Cistern, with the exception of the rear vestibule and the Hive, is submerged.

ENTRANCE

A low and wide opening narrows as it goes deeper, eventually revealing the deep shaft and the down ramp.  The Shaft goes directly to the Shrine, 200 meters below, but its walls are sheer.  Any attempt to climb down brings a -2 modification to MOBILITY rolls, and one roll is needed for each 100 meters traversed, which also takes one Turn.  The down ramp is wide enough to take a vehicle as large as a Daihotai 8x8 and spirals down to the Shrine.

SHRINE

The Shrine is flooded to 1 meter deep.  The path that leads down to the Cistern is not immediately visible, requiring an OBSERVATION roll to spot it (or the PCs might stumble across it).  On either side of the Shrine are Engineer murals, covered in glyphs—the fourth campaign clue (Clue #4—Translation Of The Engineer Hieroglyph In The Pyramid).  The glyphs can be recorded and deciphered, with an OBSERVATION roll with a -1 modification, otherwise DA/UT/UR on the UNCSS Solovetsky Island can help.

CAVERNOUS CHAMBERS

FINALE

Tensions come to a head and the insurrectionists start a vicious uprising.  The Royal Marine partisans launch an attack on the Intelligence HQ, while elsewhere across the city bands of resistance fighters arm themselves and take the fight to the CANC.

Zhāngjié will call the troops out and issue an order that anyone on the streets must be shot on sight.  Wŏ is very worried that this will bring about a needless bloodbath and tries to convince Zhāngjié that if they can repel the attack on the Intelligence HQ this will be enough to quell the uprising, and then they can negotiate a settlement.  Zhāngjié will see this as a sign of weakness and disloyalty.  How this confrontation plays out should be down to the PCs' actions and who they support.

The PCs have several options: they can join the fight on the CANC's side, supporting either Zhāngjié's or Wŏ's approach; they can join the fight on the side of the insurrectionists; they can attempt to bring calm, stop the fighting, and broker a peace; or they can get the hell out of there until the carnage dies down.  How the uprising pans out, and who wins, is up to you as GM, but obviously the PCs' actions should influence the outcome.
