The PCs are sent to survey Pelican Colony, and find a planet swept clean of life by radiation.  They also detect the smoking wreckage of a crashed spaceship.  The colony is kept operational by primitive automatons, little more than automated Powerloaders with no resemblance to androids or synthetics, that view the PCs as a problem that needs cleaning up.  They learn that the survivors from the crashed ship are the pirates, Gorham's Marauders, here to destroy the Perfected.  Mounting a mission into the bowels of an ancient Engineer Guardian ship they uncover the terrifying truth and find themselves in a desperate race to not only survive, but to stop the horrors they have unearthed.

WHAT IS GOING ON?

Pelican Colony KOI-947.01 was a flourishing agricultural society—the “breadbasket of the frontier”—boasting a population in the millions in 2100.  Although the colony survived the Isolation, it shrank to one city of 100,000.  Then, a year ago, disaster struck.  The local sun, a gentle G7 main sequence yellow star, turned angry, flooding the system with radiation.  Pelican Colony became uninhabitable overnight.

A few people managed to escape the planet, while some took refuge in the tunnels behind the great Godafoss waterfall or in the Skritio Caves, an ancient Engineer Guardian ship that's been lying in the mountains so long it has merged with the landscape.  All the rest died, their irradiated bodies still lying where they fell, macabre statues to a once flourishing city.  Those who fled into the tunnels behind the Godafoss waterfall eventually starved to death. Those who fled to the perceived safety of the Skritio Caves were saved from the radiation but stumbled across the slumbering Perfected that inhabit the ship, and the 26 Draconis strain.  They were infected.  Most died hideous deaths, but some survived.  They lie, sleeping within the bowels of the vessel, in altered states of Abomination.

Since then, the colony's automatons have continued to work without missing a beat—facilities are well-maintained, streets are clean, fields are tended, although little grows in the radiation.

J.V.Gorham, the leader of Gorham's Marauders, traveled to Pelican Colony to check out information she extracted from a captured devotee of the Children of the Two Divines—that Perfected exist in a cave in the mountains near the city.  In her pirate vessel, the Spirit of Trafalgar, she encountered a ship of the Children of the Two Divines and chased it into orbit.  However, the Spirit of Trafalgar suffered a catastrophic mechanical failure—in fact sabotage by her traitorous crew member, Nessa Majken—and the ship crashed south of the city.  Five of the crew were killed in the crash, but Gorham and four others, Rashid Ravindra, Martina Willamar, Dijana Klaasen and Majken, survived.  They wiped the Spirit of Trafalgar's navigation computers, but Majken took a secret copy of the data to pass to the Perfected.  They headed into the city, finding refuge in the Godafoss Caverns.

24 hours later, Gorham and Majken left their injured crewmates at the Godafoss refuge and traveled to the Extrasolar Colonial Administration Center to figure out how to send a distress beacon.  Majken convinced Gorham, against her better judgment, to reconnoiter the Skritio Caves.  When they find what they are looking for, Majken intends to betray Gorham and hand her, and the navigation data, to the Perfected.

WHAT'S THE STORY MOTHER?

The PCs receive a video call from Gaius aboard UNCSS Ìyánlá.

“Your next assignment, Solovetsky Island, is Pelican Colony KOI-947.01.  It is an agricultural settlement that used to provide significant imports of food into the Middle Heavens before the Isolation.  The environment is fertile and climate temperate, average daytime temperature a balmy 24°C. Established by the Weyland Corporation in 2049, Pelican came under the Three World Empire later in the century.  Population in 2100 reported to be 6.5 million.  And it's big.  Gravity of 1.5G and a diurnal duration of 48 hours.

As usual, you will operate under the initial survey and assessment responsibilities of the Great Mother Mission.  You will need to establish contact with the local authorities, should they exist, and offer assistance.  Naturally, your Colony Potential Report should focus on the future farming opportunities and how soon imports back home can resume, but also scientific research possibilities and the usual ad hoc opportunities that may arise.  Good luck, Solovetsky Island.”

CLUES TO THE METAPUZZLE

The PCs can learn the sixth campaign clue (Clue #6—Translation Of The Engineer Hieroglyph In The Guardian Ship) by exploring the Guardian ship and translating the Engineer glyphs in the Shrine.  They can also corroborate the first campaign clue (Clue #1—Database Read-Out From HMCSS Janku) by checking the Spirit of Trafalgar's logs and seeing that its navigation data has been wiped, or by rescuing and talking to J.V.Gorham.

The long data disc can be found in the Extrasolar Colonial Administration Center.  It's safe from the radiation while in place, as it is shielded, but once removed, roll a Stress Die every Shift the disc is exposed to radiation—on a   the radiation wipes the data.  If this happens, the PCs will lose any bonus for this expedition, for being so careless.

 

KOI-947.01

The planet is scorchingly hot, exceeding 40°C with potential for heatstroke for careless PCs (Conditions).  The land is prone to wildfires and firenadoes fanned by the winds.  It's a big planet too, with a surface gravity of 1.5G, resulting in gravity dyspraxia () and a day that's 48 hours long.  But the biggest problem is the radiation.  At all times on KOI-947.01 the PCs will suffer the effects of Weak radiation, unless they are protected by a sealed compression suit (don't forget their Air Supply rolls), are inside their ship or a vehicle, in the Godafoss caverns or the Guardian ship.  The local star is unpredictable, and at any time Pelican Colony can be swept with a radiation storm (see the event Bring Me Sunshine).

KICKING OFF THE ACTION

The action starts as the PCs arrive in the KOI-947 system.  The PCs immediately detect the activity of the host star and the high levels of radiation it's kicking out, a bad portent for Pelican Colony.

Pelican Colony is built in the steep foothills of the mountains, a beautiful sight—two great rivers ride down from the heights and split into what was once a lush and fertile delta.  Stunning waterfalls create a spray that leaves the colony with almost permanent rainbows, culminating in the glory of the Godafoss falls, right in the center of the city.  From a distance, Pelican Colony looks fully functioning, clean streets brightly illuminated, well-maintained buildings gleaming in the sun and machines working the fields.

But on closer inspection the PCs notice the following:

  • There is a complete absence of life, and an absence of radio or other transmissions you would expect from a functioning society.
  • There are no cloud formations, the sunlight is very bright, and the planet looks arid.
  • The surface temperature is above 40°C and is bathed in Weak radiation.
  • And they detect a weak transponder beacon from a recent crash site, to the south of the city.
ON APPROACH

Once the PCs start their approach to the city, they receive an automatic beacon, signaling them to land at the spaceport.  If they ignore this and choose to land somewhere other than the spaceport they will receive these sequential messages from the spaceport's automated Traffic Control, increasing in urgency with each message:

“You are diverting from your allocated course.  Please resume your course for the safety of all traffic.”

“You are not on your allotted course.  Do you require assistance?”

“Emergency assistance is en route to your position.  Please wait.  Help will be with you soon.”

If the PCs say they are landing elsewhere the automated system won't understand, and will respond:

“Landing is only permitted at the spaceport.  Any diversion implies mechanical failure or other emergency and danger to your lives.”

LANDING

Landing requires a PILOT test.  If the roll is failed, the ship has landed heavily and takes D3 damage.  Wherever they land, they will be met by D6 automatons one Turn after they have touched down.  The automatons have been sent to rescue the PCs, thinking they have landed here due to malfunction or misfortune.

SHORE PARTY

As there is a crashed ship, @UUID[Actor.yWGOj2k0gp062kdO]{Lakota Monroe} suggests they should see if anyone needs help, and that she should join the shore party as a medic.

@UUID[Actor.uzg5ba9avANJPrqw]{The Automatons}

Pelican Colony is entirely automated, the farms, factories and utilities all running themselves.  Other activities are carried out by the automatons, little more than automated Powerloaders.  Their programming is simple—fulfill basic tasks and protect life.  They will also protect themselves against being deactivated, as they must be active to succeed in their primary tasks.  To deactivate an automaton a PC needs to access the control panel on its back, using MOBILITY to climb up the hand and footholds built into the machine for that purpose, and make a COMTECH roll. The automatons will use force to protect the PCs, from the radiation or other threats as the robots see it, using the automaton attack table.

3WE ADMINISTRATION

This four-story building was the center of the 3WE's administration and operations, and as such houses the Colonial Operations Control Room.

UNIVERSITY

The facility is a sweeping but deserted campus.  An automated registrar will welcome them and ask which courses they are considering.

HOPPIPOLLA LAKE & DAM

A huge hydro-electric facility built within the folds of the mountains.  A small army of automatons keeps it maintained.

RESIDENTIAL ZONES

These would be perfect places to live, except for the scorching radiation.

FARM FACTORY ZONES

Buzzing with robotic activity, these places are running flat out to feed and support a population that's long since gone.

LEISURE ZONES

Parks, malls, sports facilities, and nightlife centers are all ready for people to kill time on their off days, including a fully operational theme park with roller coasters, log flumes and a giant Ferris wheel.

LOG ENTRIES
 

36 HOURS AGO:
Automated log entry: “Unidentified vessel inbound—distress beacon activated—unresponsive to communication—unauthorized planetfall in sector B-11—units sent to inspect.”

Automated log entry: “Five nominals identified and transferred to Godafoss falls refuge—vessel to be salvaged and site cleared of obstruction.”

 

TEN MONTHS AGO:
Warden Henrik Lohengrin reporting: “My last log entry.  The radiation storm is worse than we feared.  Some have escaped, but many died in the crush to board the last ships.  Everyone left here is doomed.  Some have taken refuge in the caverns under the Godafoss falls and worker teams from the dam have hidden in the Skritio Cave.  Now I wish we'd explored it more deeply, but superstition is powerful.  I don't suppose it will do much good. I'm too weak now but will try to make it to the falls.”

 
FINDING THE REFUGE

There are four ways the PCs can learn of the refuge beneath the Godafoss falls: an automaton may capture a PC and take them there for their safety; they can follow an automaton as it returns a victim of the crash to the refuge; they can access the logs at the Administration Building; and they can find and examine the remains of the survivor camp within the Guardian ship.

BREAKING AND ENTERING

The PCs cannot access any buildings in the city, as automated systems will deny them entry.  To hack in requires an opposed COMTECH roll versus eight Base Dice.  Whatever the outcome of the roll, an automaton will appear after D6 Rounds to investigate. If hacking doesn't work, the PCs can break the door down or smash a window with a STAMINA roll, but again an automaton will arrive in D6 Rounds to repair the damage and protect the PCs from their own hazardous behavior, by restraining them.

GODAFOSS

Godafoss falls is a wonderful sweeping crescent-shaped waterfall, 300 meters wide and 100 meters high—a local beauty spot.  Roads and walkways lead down to the river below.  One of these forms a wide rocky shelf that goes behind the falls themselves.  This leads to the Godafoss Caverns.

CAVERNS

The caverns are deep and adorned with semi-transparent stalactites and stalagmites, all illuminated with tastefully placed lighting to enhance the ambiance.  The entrance tunnel goes 200 meters before opening into a wide cavern full of equipment, wires, cables and 150 dead bodies—survivors who starved to death, now just bones and rags.  There are five coffins here, containing the dead crew of the Spirit of Trafalgar, and three survivors: Rashid Ravindra, Martina Willamar, and Dijana Klaassen.  Unless the PCs actively sneak into the caverns, they will assume the PCs are Children of the Two Divines, from the ship they had been chasing.  They lay an ambush and will attack when the PCs enter the room.  Enter stealth mode.

If the PCs subdue the Marauders through violence, they will be defiant in defeat—they will not cooperate or answer any questions.  In this case, a communicator crackles and the PCs hear the following message:

“We've arrived at the ECA ops room and can't find a way to send a distress beacon, so we'll have to think again.  Majken has convinced me we should take a look at those caves we came for, by the dam, although it's risky with only the two of us.  I'll call in again in three hours.  Gorham out.”

If the PCs ended the confrontation peacefully and convinced the Marauders they are friendly, they will help the PCs and offer them this information, as well as details of the Marauders' reasons for opposing the Perfected.

THE WHISPERING GALLERY

The bulbous head of the Engineer ship has been designed to channel and amplify sound.  It's not only hard to place the location of any given noise—it might be hundreds of meters away, but you'd swear it was whispering in your ear, or something close echoes as if it were far off—the structure is also designed to amplify it.  A scream, a gunshot or explosion immediately fills the ship's empty spaces with booming noise that builds on itself before seeping away.  Everyone aboard the vessel who hears this for the first time gains +1 STRESS LEVEL and must make a STAMINA roll or spend a Round holding their ears against the onslaught.

THE GUARDIAN

This ship, an elegantly elongated horseshoe with a giant bulbous head to one side, measures 1,000 meters from top to tip, the head itself nearly 400 meters across and 600 meters long.  It crashed on this planet millennia ago and the world has grown over and around it.  A small part of one side of the head is all that remains visible, now a part of the mountains.  The interior has been molded by time and the pressure of mountains growing around—its layout bears little similarity to any other Guardian ship that may still exist in the universe.  The vessel will never fly again, but power still hums.  The inside is bathed in an eerie blue glow—just bright enough to see, not bright enough to dispel the shadows.

The interior of the vessel is cool, with breathable air, and protects against the planetary radiation.  The walls and floors look almost carved in a dull obsidian that swallows the light and prevents any comms in or out.  In places, it seems the structure has been twisted by some irresistible force.  Sounds echo upon themselves, a noise in one part of the ship is channeled and heard in another, hundreds of meters away.  Just stepping aboard this vessel for the first time is so awe-inspiring that all PCs gain +1 STRESS LEVEL.

ENTRANCES

Oval openings in the side of the ship can be reached by climbing up sloped gravel-strewn ground.  The incline is too steep for a vehicle, and climbing in is not straight-forward.  A successful MOBILITY roll is required to avoid sliding back down with a rush of stones.

CAVERNOUS CHAMBERS

Enormous, misshapen, and twisted, with deep shadows.  From the twisted portico entrance the PCs can see the chamber opens into a huge nave, with ribbed surfaces covered in undisturbed dust and debris.  A distant drip of water can be heard.

In one of these chambers, the PCs come across scuffed footprints in the dust.  If they follow the trail, they reach a darkened corner to find a survivor. He seems almost normal, although his arms are a bit misshapen—he is a Stage II Mutated Abomination (Stage II: Pathogen Deviant “Mutate”).  He begs for forgiveness and for mercy (without saying what for), and to be killed.  He will become distraught and attack them within five Rounds if the PCs don't do something to prevent it.

HEADS

These chambers are filled with a forest of tall Engineer head statues, with less than five meters between each.  There are hundreds, so many in fact that it's ridiculously easy to get lost amongst them, especially given the echoes that make following the sound of someone's voice almost impossible.  Each PC must make an SURVIVAL test with a -3 modification or they will get lost amongst them.  Any PC who gets lost must make a Panic Roll.

NAVIGATION ORRERY

A huge chamber with a raised dais in the middle and an unoccupied Engineer navigator's chair.  Nothing responds to the PCs' touch.  An intense blue glow can be seen coming from the adjoining Power chamber.

POWER

Dominating this space, set into the floor like an electric wound, is a five-meter-wide gash glowing an intense electric blue, spitting sparks into the ozone-filled air.  Almost too bright to look at directly, the gash has dozens of smaller offshoots branching in every direction.  Any item that uses power is fully recharged just by being brought within SHORT range of the gash—the PCs will notice the items getting hot.  A COMTECH roll will identify these as power conduits feeding the entire structure but saturated with power and highly unstable.  If a point of power from a Power Supply, or a weapon or tool, is discharged into the gash the whole network shivers and sparks fly—the PCs can see how close to catastrophically overloading the system is.  If a grenade or explosive charge is detonated on it or it is overloaded by connecting a power generator to it with a HEAVY MACHINERY roll, a feedback loop is created that will cause the whole ship to self-destruct in one Turn (see The End of the Ancient Mariner below).

THE END OF THE ANCIENT MARINER

Once the power conduits in the Guardian ship's Power chamber have been destroyed or overloaded the destruction of the ancient vessel is inevitable.  As relentless energy surges through its nervous system, the Guardian ship starts to shudder.  This earthquake is felt all across Hoppipolla Lake, as the ship beneath the ground builds to its own destruction.  Saturated by titanic forces, the very fiber of the ship can no longer resist and suddenly implodes.  The bulbous head, the Skritio Cave, crumples inwards, annihilating itself as the mountains above come crashing down.  The effect ripples along the horseshoe spires and the ground begins to give way in stages.  The dam collapses, releasing the water to flood down and into the city, destroying all as it sweeps past, before the lake itself disappears into the wrecked and ruined landscape.

SHRINE

A Xeno­morph sculpture high on the wall looks so lifelike that the PCs need an OBSERVATION roll to realize it's a statue, with a failed roll adding +1 STRESS LEVEL.  Around the sculpture the wall is covered in Engineer glyphs—the sixth campaign clue (CLUE #6—TRANSLATION OF THE ENGINEER HIEROGLYPH IN THE GUARDIAN SHIP). The glyphs can be recorded and deciphered with an OBSERVATION roll with a -1 modification, otherwise DA/UT/UR on the UNCSS Solovetsky Island can decode it.  This chamber was also the campsite for the 30 survivors that made it here when the radiation came.  It's been abandoned for months, with scattered cartons, sleeping rolls, boxes, and bags.  If the PCs search the remains, they will find the journal of a survivor called Pablo Bengochaea, and can read his last entry (see Pablo's Last Words below).

PABLO'S LAST WORDS

The journal charts the events that led to the destruction of Pelican Colony—the increased solar activity, the flares and radiation bursts, the panic among the people, and Bengochaea's escape from his job at the dam into the Skritio Caves.  The last entry reads: “About 30 of us have made it into the caves and went deeper than we ever did before.  Shit, this place is freaky and gives us all the creeps, but at least we're safe here for now.  I got through to the refuge at the Godafoss falls, it seems only a couple of hundred made it in there, but at least they are safe for now too.  I can only hope lots got off planet before the last rad storm hit us.”

PULPIT

A raised platform that looks like the pulpit of a cathedral.  There is space to stand at the top and hand-shaped indentations on the plinth.  These allowed the Engineers to sing their songs throughout the vessel.  If a PC places their hands there, they feel a tingle, and the next sound that the PC makes is turned into an echoing song that flows around the ship time and again, getting louder with every pass (for up to five Rounds).  If you wish, this may trigger the event The Abomination Horde.

AMPULE CHAMBER

The stone hatchway is ajar and inside are hundreds of empty ampules, but no black goo—all the 26 Draconis strain that was here has already been absorbed into the Abominations aboard the ship.

SLEEP CHAMBER

Filled with five rows of low Engineer cryosleep cubicles, a total of 250.  All are open except for one, which contains the skeletal remains of a millennia-dead Engineer.  If the PCs open it—with a COMTECH or HEAVY MACHINERYgush of rancid air will assault them, and the body will disintegrate.  

At the far end of the chamber two open cubicles are each occupied by a slumbering Fulfremmen (Fulfremmen “The Perfected”), blanketed by the fleshy tendrils of a Proto-Hive Node.  With a successful OBSERVATION roll the PCs will notice that the Node's tendrils are trying to penetrate the ship's structure, but cannot.  On the floor by the cubicles are what appear to be Engineer hieroglyphs marked out in chalk.  These are not the same as those on the Guardian ship but are from the ruined Engineer city on KOI-1966.03.  See The Chalked Glyphs below.

The Fulfremmen will awaken and calmly approach the PCs, initially curious.  See The Fulfremmen below.

The PCs immediately sense a feeling of welcome, images of togetherness filling their heads, and an intangible call of “join us.” All PCs must make a test against their EMPATHY (attribute only).  If this is failed, they are entranced, and cannot act until they succeed at a subsequent test (made once per Round) or suffer damage.  The Fulfremmen will reach out to touch those entranced, exposing them to the Perfected's infection—treat this as a disease with Virulence 6.  If the Sickness Roll fails, the victim becomes a Stage I Humanoid Abomination (Stage I: Pathogen Carrier “The Tainted”).  

Once one or more PCs succeed at their EMPATHY test, and resist the Fulfremmen's telepathy, the Fulfremmen become resentful and bitter. The PCs now sense a feeling of anger, images of violent retribution filling their heads.  The Perfected will attack.  If Nessa Majken is here she will be deliriously happy and offer the Fulfremmen the data pad with the navigation data.  Gorham will fight to the death to stop this happening.

THE CHALKED GLYPHS

These glyphs, chalked on the floor by the Perfected, are the third campaign clue, and are also found in the Engineer city on KOI-1966.03 (see the expedition Leave All Else To The Gods).  Finding them scrawled here by the Perfected should allow the PCs to connect the Lychgate with the Perfected and start their suspicion that the Perfected may want to use it to travel to the Middle Heavens.

THE FULFREMMEN

Tall, lithe, and majestic, the two Perfected approach with grace and elegance.  Their black eyes scan the scene, heads tilting this way and that. Their silvery-gray skin shines in the blue glow.  One of them, with a crimson marking—a birthmark or blemish sketching a “V” shape on its cheek—peers at you intently.  The other—similar in every respect except the golden mottling of the skin of its neck and shoulders—reaches out a hand.  You feel something, an itch in your head, in your mind.  Then you see it—a grotesque image of twisted figures writhing in an ecstatic orgy of pain and joy.  You feel the pull, the invitation, to be one with the hive, to be one with perfection.

AMBULATORY

This 800-meter cylindrical passage is 50 meters wide, its ribs and structures forming a rough spiral that coils the entire length—an awesome spectacle.

THE SPINE

A massive obsidian door stands ajar between the Spine and the Ambulatory.  Behind the door, a multitude of narrow passages disappear in all directions.  Any PC venturing here must make an OBSERVATION roll to find the way back, but for every failed roll the next test is at a cumulative -1 modification.  Using a Pups device gives a +1 modification to the OBSERVATION roll.  If the PCs OBSERVATION dice pool is reduced to zero dice, they are hopelessly lost and will eventually die unless rescued from outside.  Two Stage III Revenant Abominations (Stage III: Pathogen Husk “Revenant”) are within these tunnels and will surprise the PCs.

EVENTS

CLEAN UP CREWS

The automated system at Pelican Colony swiftly spots anything that is out of place and sends D6 automatons to clean it up.  That includes the PCs, their vehicles and Solovetsky Island itself.  One Turn after the PCs stop in any location, they will see these robots approaching.  They will immediately proceed to disassemble, salvage and take away anything they can.  It will take them one Shift to salvage and remove a vehicle like a Daihotai tractor.  For the SEV, they will salvage one point of hull or armor per Shift, completely salvaging a Magellan-class in three days.

RESCUE THE MARAUDERS

Whilst exploring the city the PCs hear a shout for help and the toneless voice of an automaton saying: “Please do not resist.” The PCs see J.V.Gorham and Nessa Majken in the grasp of two automatons.  They have been captured and are being returned to the Godafoss Caverns for their own safety.  When they see the PCs Gorham and Majken fear they are devotees but will shout for help as soon as they realize the PCs are not from the death cult.  If the PCs win Gorham's trust she will suggest they join forces, and Majken—the traitor—will be very keen to have the PCs along if it further convinces Gorham to explore the Skritio Caves.

FEAR THE FIRENADOES

A spark near the PCs bursts into flame and, whipped up by the winds, immediately swirls into a terrifying tornado of fire.  It moves at a rate of two zones per Round, in a random direction, and burns everything it touches with an Intensity 12 fire.  Automated robots will appear within D6 Rounds to put the fires out, but they will also be desperate to remove the PCs from danger, by force if necessary.

BRING ME SUNSHINE

The sun sends a Strong radiation storm across KOI-947.01, causing 1 Rad per Turn for characters in the open without protection.  The storm lasts 2D6 Turns. However, the storm is so strong that even those protected by a ship, vehicle or compression suit still suffer Weak radiation.  The only safe place is inside the Guardian ship.  At your discretion, to really turn up the heat, a storm could be so strong that it brings Extreme radiation instead.

DIVINE JOY

While on the Guardian ship Nessa Majken cannot conceal her wonder and joy at the majesty of the place.  She is becoming increasingly ecstatic that she has found the higher power she is looking for.  The PCs will notice this, but it's up to them if they think there may be a nefarious reason behind it.

THE CHILDREN RETURN

At a point to best heighten the tension, the Heliades-class ship that Gorham had been chasing before the Spirit of Trafalgar crashed, reappears.  Crewed by six devotees, they will be searching for the survivors from the crash and will detect the Solovetsky Island if the ship is in the vicinity.  They want to prevent the survivors from escaping and capture the PCs' ship for themselves.

FINALE

THE ABOMINATION HORDE

After the encounter with the Perfected, the PCs will have made enough noise that the Abominations in the Spire have awoken.  The PCs suddenly hear echoing shrieks and caterwauls from all over, no idea where they come from—the Abominations are after them.  This should become a desperate chase to escape the Guardian, not a stand-up fight.  Have the PCs spot some Stage III Revenants in the distance, and spring one on them as a surprise.  A Stage IV Beluga-Head and Stage V Shambler block the corridor they have chosen to flee down.  Once outside, the PCs are safe from the Abominations, as they are reluctant to brave the radiation.

THE GUARDIAN SHIP IS DESTROYED

If the Guardian ship is destroyed it implodes, bringing down the mountainside and destroying the dam.  Anyone (or anything) on the plain by the dam and Hoppipolla lake will have three Rounds to escape before being swept away.  If the UNCSS Solovetsky Island has landed here a PILOT roll is needed to avoid the water, which does three points of damage every Round the ship does not escape.  Those driving a vehicle must race away from the water, making a PILOT roll each Round to keep ahead—a failed roll and the vehicle is caught, and all aboard take an eight Base Dice attack, Damage 1, for each of the next three Rounds as they are swept up.  If the PILOT roll achieves three   they have swerved into a safe spot, and the flood passes them by.  Any characters on foot will be swept away to their deaths.  

If the PCs destroy the Guardian ship, by blowing up or overloading the power conduits in the Power chamber aboard the ship, the threat is destroyed, but if not, the Perfected will eventually claim Pelican Colony for themselves.

EPILOGUE

There is little to recommend Pelican Colony for future re-colonization, although some overzealous corporate executive might sponsor a covert mission to acquire any remains of the Engineer vessel.  They may find more than they bargained for, and return as an Abomination to the fleet.
